On 28 February 2025, overnight, M23 broke into Heal Africa Hospital in the town of Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu) and abducted at least 15 wounded male patients. They entered the hospital and searched for patients with bullet wounds, suspectedly assuming they were FARDC soldiers or Wazalendo. Only a few people were released.
On 28 February 2025, overnight, M23 broke into CBCA Ndosho Hospital in Goma - Ndosho (Goma, Nord-Kivu) and abducted at least 116 wounded male patients. They entered and fired weapons and searched for patients with bullet wounds, suspectedly assuming they were FARDC soldiers or Wazalendo.
On 28 February 2025, unidentified armed group killed at least 5 people in Bukavu - Kadutu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu) and Ibanda (coded separately). 5 fatalities split across two locations, coded as 2.
On 28 February 2025, unidentified armed group killed at least 5 people in Ibanda of Bukavu, coded to Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu) and Kadutu (coded separately). 5 fatalities split across two locations, coded as 3.
On 28 February 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group killed a woman in Mongbwalu (Djugu, Ituri). This area is surrounded by the presence of different armed groups, due to being a gold mining zone.
On 27 February 2025, suspected M23 shot killed a deaf and mute man in Goma town (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 27 February 2025,overnight, unidentified armed group attacked and looted 34 sealed barrels of cassiterite in the Nguba district of Bukavu, coded to Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), beating and tying up two guards before abducting two others. The minerals were loaded onto buses in the middle of the night.
On 27 February 2025, unidentified armed group attacked civilians in an unspecified location in Bukavu, coded to Bukavu (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), leaving multiple people dead (unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3).
Around 26 February 2025 (as reported), M23 'arrested' the provincial director of the RTNC and representative of Journalist en Danger in Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 26 February 2025, ADF attacked 6 villages: Credit, Gbado, Balisoma, Mekingi, Samboko and Matolo, all coded to nearby Samboko Centre (Babila Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri) 17 bodies found in Matolo the next day. 23 fatalities split across two events. 25 February: 6 bodies found in Matolo; 26 February: 17 bodies found in Samboko.
On 26 February 2025, an unidentified armed group shot dead three youth in Bukavu - Panzi (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). Witnesses said the attack might be linked to a mob violence that occurred the day prior (coded separately).
On 25 February 2025, CODECO shot dead two gold miners in Tsewe, coded to nearby Nizi (Mambisa, Djugu, Ituri).
On 25 February 2025, suspected M23 set fire to a bar and shot at customers in the Don Bosco Ngangi area of Goma - Kasika (Goma, Nord-Kivu). 15-20 fatalities. A witness said M23 learned that the bar belonged to a FARDDC officer.
On 25 February 2025, M23 abducted a pastor of CBCA Katoy Church in Goma - Katoyi (Goma, Nord-Kivu). His whereabouts remain unknown.
On 25 February 2025, M23 'intelligence services' abducted a journalist and Provincial Director of RTNC from an unspecified location in Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). According to a local NGO, M23 spokesman confirmed to have taken him for investigation purposes. M23 also took control of RTNC.
On 25 February 2025, overnight, ADF attacked 6 villages: Pesa, Kadika, Mekanya, Bawenzi, Bandenge, and Leta, all coded to nearby Samboko Centre (Babila Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri). 6 bodies found in Matolo the next day. 23 fatalities split across two events. 25 February: 6 bodies found in Matolo; 26 February: 17 bodies found in Samboko. 20 people were taken as hostage, also split in two events, many were released on 2 March.
On 24 February 2025, overnight, unidentified armed men killed three civilians, including a teacher, in Kibirizi (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), over unknown reasons. The area is under M23 control.
On 23 February 2025, CODECO attacked Ngazba (Djugu, Ituri) and Buki villages (coded separately) burning at least 11 houses. Casualties unknown.
On 23 February 2025, CODECO attacked Buki, coded to the closest town Djugu (Djugu, Ituri) and Ngazba villages (coded separately) burning at least 11 houses. Casualties unknown.
On 22 February 2025, overnight, CODECO attacked simultaneously civilians in Banana, near Dhego (Djugu, Ituri), Largu, and Djugu center (coded separately). 7 fatalities split across three locations. Coded as 2. The victims were killed by machete.
On 22 February 2025, Mobondo militia attacked Ntomo village, 5km away from Kwamouth (Plateaux, Kwamouth, Mai-Ndombe). There was a displacement observed towards Ngabe (Republic of Congo) via Congo river, and towards Bolobo border territory. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3. Following this attack, FARDC clashed against Mobondo militia (coded separately).
On 22 February 2025, suspected M23 shot dead an alleged phone thief in Bukavu - Bagira (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu).
On 22 February 2025, suspected M23 killed at least ten young men, and their bodies were found in Goma - Katindo (Goma, Nord-Kivu). Some sources (including the government), mention that the men were drinking and consuming drugs when M23 surprised them. Others mentioned a failed attempt of recruitment by M23. M23 spokesman stated that this crime 'was part of a sweeping and cleaning operation' and that these men were 'military family members, members of militia or drug users'. M23 suspectedly also committed sexual abuse against some young girls. One day later (23/02/2025) M23 was seen picking up some bodies and carrying them in their vehicles.
On 22 February 2025, overnight, CODECO attacked simultaneously civilians in Largu (Djugu, Ituri), Banana and Djugu center (coded separately). 7 fatalities split across three locations. Coded as 2. The victims were killed by machete.
On 22 February 2025, overnight, CODECO attacked simultaneously Civilians at Camp Platon, near Djugu center (Djugu, Ituri), Banana and Largu (coded separately). 7 fatalities split across three locations. Coded as 3. The victims were killed by machete. Hundreds of people, especially women and children were displaced towards Lopa and Iga Barrier shelters.
On 22 February 2025, overnight, ADF militants attacked and killed 1 civilian in Kokola (Beni, Nord-Kivu) and injured two others. The attackers also caused significant material damage.
Around 21 February 2025 (as reported), FARDC soldiers, suspected without command, raped women in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) several times, as well as looted and extorted the population. M23 was announced to be a few km away. All the authorities have fled to Kalemie or Burundi. Casualties unknown.
On 21 February 2025, UPLC beat to death a civilian around Ngazi (Beni, Nord-Kivu), for suspectedly being a Wazalendo fighter. Another young man arrested at the same time was taken to Kalunguta under similar accusations.
On 20 February 2025, M23 shot dead two men in Goma - Himbi (Goma, Nord-Kivu), who had just abducted a young boy and were demanding a ransom. The boy's family called M23 who killed the kidnappers.
On 20 February 2025, CODECO abducted 5 people in Bethlehem, coded to nearby Fataki (Walendu Djatsi, Irumu, Ituri), and brought the victims near by Djiwi. The victims were feed in the evening after the Djatsi sector chief negotiated with CODECO and paid a ransom. CODECO stole the victims' goods, including phones, laptops and money.
On 20 February 2025, an unidentified armed group abducted five people near Fataki (Djugu, Ituri). They were released later following the intervention of the local customary authorities.
On 20 February 2025, ADF militia attacked civilians while they were sleeping in Mayimoya (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu). At least 8 civilians were killed.
On 20 February 2025, ADF militia attacked and killed an unknown number of civilians in Samboko (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu). An unknown number of civilians were abducted. No further information available. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.
On 19 February 2025, M23 shot dead six alleged thieves/bandits, two of whom were armed, in Goma - Himbi (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 19 February 2025, either FARDC or M23 (coded as an unidentified armed group) killed a FARDC colonel who was off-duty sick at his home and his two bodyguards in Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). No fight occurred. Sources said FARDC soldiers dressed in civilian clothes may have killed him because he was suspected of joining M23; others say M23 killed him.
On 16 February 2025, CODECO stopped and took a group of people as hostages on a road near Tali village (Djugu, Ituri), killing 15 people. The victims were undressed before being killed and had signs of torture. At least 20 people escaped after FARDC's intervention. It was not clear if a clash occurred.
On 15 February 2025, CODECO attacked Gina (Djugu, Ituri), on the National Route 27. 8 fatalities.
On 14 February 2025, overnight, CODECO killed 6 civilians in Zanyo (Mambisa, Djugu, Ituri), including 3 children and 2 women.
On 14 February 2025, CODECO coming from Sesele groupement abducted a pastoralist and looted his 29 goats in Juli village, near Djuba (Bahema-Bahuru, Djugu, Ituri)
On 14 February 2025, Wazalendo shot several times at a youth belonging to the Banyamulenge community whom they accused of being M23 in Mulongwe (Bavira, Uvira, Sud-Kivu). The youth was severely injured.
On 14 February 2025, overnight, CODECO attacked Maze (Djugu, Ituri) and killed summarily 6 civilians.
On 14 February 2025, CODECO ambushed Djugu-center (Djugu, Ituri). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3.
Around 14 February 2025 (weekend of), M23 allegedly killed three children in summary executions in an unspecified location in Bukavu, coded to Bukavu (Bukavu-Sud-Kivu) according to the UN High Commissionate for Human Rights after they refused to give up weapons they had taken from an abandoned military camp. M23 denied this accusation through their spokesman arguing that children misused weapons that were abandoned by their parents and shot at each other. UN OHCHR also reports about conflict-related sexual and gender-based violence, child and forced recruitment, and other violations.
On 13 February 2025, an armed group (likely M23 due to its control of Goma) shot dead musician Delcat Indengo in Kilijiwe, an area of Goma - Mapendo (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The musician was filming a music video for a song that came out some days before where he was criticizing Congolese authorities, the M23, CODECO, and the ADF. M23 denied any involvement, instead pointing fingers to FARDC and Wazalendo.
On 13 February 2025, an unidentified armed group shot dead a woman in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu), over unknown reasons.
On 13 February 2025, Wazalendo killed a youth in Kalundu (Uvira, Bavira, Sud-Kivu), over unknown reasons.
On 12 February 2025, M23 killed 5 civilians in Muhongoza (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu). The group initially arrested 8 people to have them carry supplies and killed 5 of them, one of whom was a LUCHA activist. LUCHA said the 5 who were killed were targeted because of their activism.
On 11 February 2025, M23 killed a civilian over unknown reasons in Goma - Mabanga Nord (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Around 11 February 2025 (between 10 - 14 February), overnight, suspected ADF (another source claims UPLC or FPP/AP could be responsible) abducted 'at least' 70 civilians near Mayba, closest town Manzia (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu). Their bodies were found on 14 February in a local Protestant church of Kasanga.
On 11 February 2025, overnight, CODECO attacked civilians in Lodja village, Djaiba groupement (Walendu-Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri), killing at least 56 people (fatalities coded according to more recent report by Mediacongo.net). They also set 50 houses on fire. Residents of Lodja and neighboring villages fled.
On 11 February 2025, a FARDC soldier sexually assaulted a woman in Lubahemba in Kyondo (Beni, Nord-Kivu).
Around 10 February 2025 (between 9 - 10 February), CODECO attacked civilians in Laudjo (Walendu-Pitsi, Djugu, Ituri). 1 IDP woman was killed, and 10 others were injured, including 5 women and 5 children. MONUSCO forces were deployed to contain the violence.
On 10 February 2025, FARDC-Wazalendo attacked civilians in Mikenke, also known as Mikenge (Itombwe, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown. The civilians spent the night in the surrounding bushes.
On 10 February 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group killed the village chief and his family (his wife and their three children) at their home in Kiziba II (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). 5 fatalities. Civil society said the killing might be a reprisal following the mob killing of an alleged bandit the week prior (coded separately).
On 10 February 2025, CODECO attacked civilians and IDPs in Sanduku (Djugu, Ituri) and at the Sanduku IDP site. 3 IDPs were killed, and 10 others were injured. Some injured are in critical condition. MONUSCO forces were deployed to contain the violence.
On 10 February 2025, overnight, CODECO militants (in large numbers) attacked civilians in three locations: Laudjo, Lindu and Lodja, all in Djaiba groupement (Djugu, Ituri). The victims were mainly IDPs of the Hema ethnic group staying with host families who had fled other CODECO attacks in the days prior. The attackers set people on fire, shot bullets and beheaded residents. 52-84 dead (including 18-28 children), 9 people injured, and 49 houses were set on fire. FARDC said the attack was in reprisal for an attack committed by the Zaire militia days earlier.
On 9 February 2025, an unidentified armed group attacked civilians at a shop in Kanzuli (Beni, Nord-Kivu), shooting at customers and the owner. 2 civilians were killed, and 2 others were injured. The attackers headed for the Butsili neighborhood of Beni (coded separately).
On 9 February 2025, FARDC attacked civilians on motorbikes on the national road 3 in Bitale (Buloho, Kalehe, Sud-Kivu) when the civilians prevented the soldiers from seizing a motorbike. 3 civilians were injured. The extent of their injuries is not known.
On 9 February 2025, Mobondo militia attacked civilians at a farm in Mongata (Maluku, Kinshasa, Kinshasa). Casualties unknown. The militia looted goods, two civilians were abducted.
On 9 February 2025, M23 shot a suspected criminal in the Goma - Mabanga Nord (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu) after civilians called the M23 'military police' to take action. 1 civilian was killed. The victim had fired shots and looted mobile phones and money.
On 9 February 2025, ADF attacked 'Christians' in Tabora, near Mavivi (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu), abducting and beheading 4.
Around 9 February 2025 (between 9 - 10 February), FARDC 'tortured' civilians (means unspecified) in Lusenda (Tanganyika, Fizi, Sud-Kivu) for an unknown reason. Casualties unknown.
Around 9 February 2025 (as reported), an unidentified armed group (likely CODECO, based on recent activity in the area) attacked civilians in Fataki (Walendu Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri). Casualties unknown. Several were injured. The extent of injuries is not known. The attackers set fire to civilian houses and looted property.
On 9 February 2025, CODECO killed two IDPs and injured 10 others in Djaiba (Walendu-Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri). 5 of the injured (including 2 children) were evacuated by MONUSCO to Bunia.
Around 9 February 2025 (as reported), Zaire militia attacked an unidentified locality in Walendu Pitsi, coded to Loda (as per reference of recent clashes) (Djugu, Ituri). Several houses burnt and looting reported. Zaire had surrendered a couple of months ago, but their attacks are still reported in Lidha (also spelled as Loda) and Wanyali Kilo. No fatalities, and several injured.
On 8 February 2025, Zaire militants opposed to ongoing peace processes attacked civilians in Buchama (Walendu-Tatsi, Djugu, Ituri), during a wake, killing 8 civilians (including two women, a girl, and an elderly). The militants also set fire to 30 houses. Residents of Buchama and nearby Mbuchu and Arr fled. FARDC later intervened (coded separately).
On 7 February 2025, police officer responsible for the security of a gas station, shot and killed a motorcycle-tricycle driver in Kisangani (Kisangani, Tshopo). The victim went to the gas station with a 10 USD note to buy 5,000 FC (USD $1.75) worth of fuel . An argument over change led to a tense exchange, after which the police officer on duty intervened and fired on the driver, killing him instantly. The officer later fled the scene.
On 7 February 2025, ADF attacked 'Christians' in Luna (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), killing 2 and burning homes, as per an IS claim.
On 7 February 2025, ADF attacked 'Christians' in Tabora, near Mavivi (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu), killing 4 and burning homes, as per an IS claim.
On 7 February 2025, overnight, ADF killed at least two women in Eringeti locality (Beni, Nord-Kivu). One man was injured. At least 5 houses and kiosks were burnt.
On 7 February 2025, overnight, FARDC killed 9 people in Katana (Kabare, Sud-Kivu) for unclear reasons. 9 fatalities split across three locations (Kavumu and Miti). Coded as 3.
On 7 February 2025, Mayi Mayi Militia (UPLC faction) attacked civilians in an unknown location in the Beni territory (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu). 5 civilians were killed, and 4 others were injured.
On 7 February 2025, overnight, FARDC killed 9 people in Miti (Kabare, Sud-Kivu) for unclear reasons. 9 fatalities split across three locations (Kavumu and Katana). Coded as 3.
On 7 February 2025, a police officer shot and killed a tricycle driver outside a gas station in Kabondo (Kisangani, Tshopo) under unclear circumstances. The event provoked riots amongst residents (means unspecified), shop owners closed their doors, and the police officer escaped.
On 7 February 2025, FARDC soldiers shot dead 7 civilians in Mulungu village, in the Miti groupment (coded to Miti, Kabare Sud-Kivu).
Around 7 February 2025 (between 7 February - 8 February), FARDC and Wazalendo forces attacked civilians in Kabamba (Kabare, Kabare, Sud-Kivu), and Kavumu, Miti, and Katana (coded separately). 9 civilians were killed. Fatalities split across four events. 2 fatalities coded.
On 7 February 2025, overnight, FARDC killed 9 people in Kavumu (Kabare, Sud-Kivu) for unclear reasons. 9 fatalities split across three locations (Miti and Katana). Coded as 3.
On 7 February 2025, UPLC shot and killed at least 11 people and injured 4 others in Mabalako (Beni, Nord-Kivu), following a misunderstanding between attackers and the victims, who were shot dead while escorting a body to a burial in Runzayi. Residents fled to safe areas.
On 6 February 2025, ADF beheaded two 'Christians' 'near' Eringeti (Beni, Nord-Kivu), as per an IS claim. No further details.
Around 6 February 2025 (as reported), suspected Mayi Mayi Bakata Katanga militia injured a man with an arrow and looted several goods in Katonge (Moba, Tanganyika). The territory administrator said they were no militia but 'armed civilians' coming from Moba and Pweto. Military forces intervened (means unspecified) and one person was arrested. The injured person was hospitalized and a massive displacement of people was observed.
On 6 February 2025, ADF beheaded three 'Christians' 'near' Idohu (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), as per an IS claim. No further details.
On 5 February 2025, FARDC killed a civilian at the Katana shopping center, in Katana (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). The attackers attempted to rob the victim of everything he owned while returning home from the market before shooting him.
On 5 February 2025, Mobondo militiamen killed 3 farmers on a farm located one kilometer from Mongata village (Maluku, Kinshasa), on the RN17. The victims' throats were cut off.
On 5 February 2025, suspected Wazalendo killed 3 aid workers from a Swiss aid organization known as HEKS/EPER in Kabirangiriro locality, between Kikuku and Ihula, coded to Ihula (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The victims were killed while working to provide essential aid to vulnerable populations affected by the ongoing humanitarian crisis in eastern DRC. The NGO suspended all their activities
On 4 February 2025, suspected ADF rebels abducted several civilians in Mayuano village (Mambasa, Ituri). Two hostages escaped and reported that at least three civilians were captured by the rebels.
On 4 February 2025, suspected ADF killed civilians in the village of Kangakiro, in the Bandavilemba groupement, near Mayalibo (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), and the villages of Butumani and Lulueba (coded separately). 9 people, including 3 Batwa, were executed with machetes, while engaging in agricultural activities in the area. 9 fatalities split across 3 events. 3 coded to this event.
On 4 February 2025, ADF attacked the village of Butumani, in the Bandavilemba groupement near Idohu (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), and the villages of Kangakiro and Lulueba (coded separately). 9 people, including 3 Batwa, were executed with machetes, while engaging in agricultural activities in the area. 9 fatalities split across 3 events. 3 coded to this event.
On 4 February 2025, suspected ADF killed civilians in the village of Lulueba, in the Bandavilemba groupement, near Maimunde (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), and the villages of Butumani and Kangakiro (coded separately). 9 people, including 3 Batwa, were executed with machetes, while engaging in agricultural activities in the area. 9 fatalities split across 3 events. 3 coded to this event.
On 3 February 2025, ADF killed 4 civilians in the village of Kazaroho (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri). The victims' lifeless bodies were discovered on 4 February.
On 3 February 2025, FARDC shot and killed a motorcycle driver near the Musamaria Mwema 2 center in Kabamba (Kabare, Sud-Kivu) under unclear circumstances. .
On 3 February 2025, unidentified armed men held families captive near Balindu primary school in Goma - Ndosho (Goma, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 2 February 2025, ADF attacked civilians in Ndimo Coton, a location in Ndimo village (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri), killing 4 and injuring 4. They also set fire to houses.

graphRAG_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**Key Developments:**

1. **M23 Movements and Control:**
   - M23 forces were observed moving towards Alimbongo and Kirumba in Nord-Kivu, causing civilian displacement and looting in Goma (DRC34677, DRC34712, DRC35133, DRC35174).
   - M23 reinforced its troops in Kisale, near Mukwija in Sud-Kivu, and declared a unilateral ceasefire in Goma and the East of DRC (DRC34898, DRC34667, DRC34952).
   - M23 overtook several strategic locations, including Bukavu and Walungu in Sud-Kivu, and Kipese, Lubango, Kasima, and Vulera in Nord-Kivu (DRC35069, DRC34855, DRC34852, DRC34858, DRC34859, DRC34864).

2. **FARDC and Allied Forces:**
   - FARDC and allied forces, including Ugandan and Burundian troops, were deployed to reinforce positions in Nord-Kivu, Ituri, and Sud-Kivu (DRC34678, DRC34896, DRC34654, DRC34758, DRC34657).
   - FARDC recruited additional personnel in Sud-Ubangi and Lualaba to bolster its ranks against M23 (DRC35435, DRC35178).
   - FARDC faced internal issues, including looting incidents and desertions, particularly in Uvira and Lubero (DRC34771, DRC34870, DRC34874).

3. **International and Regional Responses:**
   - The UN Security Council adopted a resolution condemning M23's offensive and calling for an immediate ceasefire, urging Rwanda to stop supporting M23 (DRC34961, DRC35157).
   - The Congolese government banned Rwandan aircraft from its airspace and appointed Uvira as the provisional capital of Sud-Kivu following M23's takeover of Bukavu (DRC34757, DRC35073).
   - South African and Malawian elements of the SADC mission in DRC left the territory through Goma (DRC34983).

4. **Humanitarian and Security Measures:**
   - The Ministry of Health opened a humanitarian corridor in Goma to facilitate aid delivery (DRC34882, DRC34888).
   - The provincial government of Haut-Katanga extended curfews in Likasi and Lubumbashi due to increased insecurity (DRC34958, DRC34959).
   - The Congolese government launched measures to double the salaries of FARDC soldiers and improve their social security, aiming to boost morale and combat desertion (DRC35072).

5. **Civilian Impact:**
   - Significant civilian displacement was observed, with IDPs fleeing from various camps in Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu due to M23's advances and ultimatums (DRC34799, DRC34715, DRC34717, DRC34716).
   - Looting and property destruction were reported in multiple locations, affecting both civilians and public establishments (DRC34954, DRC34713, DRC34849).

6. **Other Notable Events:**
   - The OHCHR agreed to launch an urgent commission of inquiry into atrocities committed in Eastern DRC (DRC34797).
   - The military tribunal of Butembo sentenced 55 FARDC soldiers to death for various offenses, including desertion and looting (DRC35071).

These developments highlight the ongoing conflict and strategic maneuvers in the DRC, with significant implications for regional stability and humanitarian conditions.
simple_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**Military and Security Developments:**
- **M23 Advances:** M23 continued its offensive, capturing several strategic locations, including Bukavu (28 February), Nyakundubi (27 February), Kipese (20 February), and Lubango (20 February). M23's control over these areas has led to significant displacement and looting (28 February, 27 February, 20 February).
- **FARDC and Allied Forces:** FARDC faced significant challenges, including desertions and internal conflicts. The military tribunal in Butembo sentenced 55 FARDC soldiers to death for various offenses (28 February). FARDC also faced internal conflicts with Wazalendo, leading to clashes and looting (15 February, 16 February).
- **International Involvement:** The UN Security Council adopted a resolution condemning M23's offensive and calling for a ceasefire (21 February). The SADC mission saw the departure of South African and Malawian elements (24 February), while Ugandan forces reinforced their presence in Ituri (16 February).

**Government and Political Measures:**
- **Salary Increases:** The DRC government announced a doubling of salaries for FARDC and policemen, aiming to boost morale and retention (28 February).
- **Administrative Changes:** The government nominated Uvira as the provisional provincial capital of South Kivu following M23's capture of Bukavu (25 February). The government also banned Rwandan aircraft from Congolese airspace (12 February).

**Humanitarian and Social Impact:**
- **Displacement:** Significant displacement was observed, with thousands of people fleeing from conflict zones to safer areas or across borders (28 February, 24 February, 15 February).
- **Looting and Violence:** There were numerous reports of looting by various armed groups, including FARDC, M23, and Wazalendo (23 February, 21 February, 20 February). Civilian populations faced severe hardships, including sexual violence and forced recruitment (14 February, 15 February).

**Economic and Social Tensions:**
- **Resource Strain:** The influx of displaced people in Kabimba led to rising prices and strain on local resources (28 February).
- **Public Protests:** There were several instances of public protests and unrest, including a sit-in by moto-taxi drivers in Kindu (27 February) and clashes over customary power in Mari-Minza (24 February).

**International Relations:**
- **Regional Dynamics:** The presence of Ugandan and Burundian forces in DRC highlighted ongoing regional tensions and the complex dynamics of international involvement in the conflict (16 February, 7 February).
- **Human Rights:** The UN Human Rights Council agreed to launch an inquiry into atrocities committed by all parties in Eastern DRC, focusing on the recent seizure of Goma by M23 (7 February).

These developments underscore the ongoing instability and humanitarian crisis in the DRC, with significant implications for regional security and international relations.
corpus:
Displacement: Around 28 February 2025 (month of), displaced people from North and South Kivu arrived in large numbers in Kabimba (Kalemie, Tanganyika) fleeing the war. Their presence has led to rising prices of food, transport, and housing, straining local resources.
Other: On 28 February 2025, the military tribunal of Butembo sentenced at least 55 FARDC soldiers to death in Musienene (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). They were accused of fleeing before the enemy, violating orders, raping and looting. Other mobile court hearings will be organized soon with more soldiers arrested in Beni, Oicha, etc. In July last year, around 50 FARDC soldiers were also given death penalty.
Other: On 28 February 2025, the DRC Government launched a key measurement in the Ministerial Council in Kinshasa (Kinshasa) to double the salary of FARDC men, and policemen, as well as improvements in their social security and dependents conditions. This measurement aims to encourage security forces to stay in their positions and fight M23.
Non-violent activity: On 28 February 2025, M23 appointed a local businessman as its new governor of South Kivu province, coded to provincial capital Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), following the capture of Bukavu.
On 27 February 2025, police arrested 245 suspected bandits in Kinshasa (Kinshasa).
Around 27 February 2025 (as reported), M23 overtook Nyakundubi, coded to the territorial town, Lubero (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), without clash. The area was previously under FARDC control.
Other: On 25 February 2025, the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of the Interior, Security, Decentralization and Customary Affairs nominated Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) as provisional provincial capital, coded to Kinshasa (Kinshasa). This measure intends to maintain administrative order following the occupation of Bukavu in mid-February by M23.
Change to armed group: On 24 February 2025, about 200 South African and Malawian elements of the SADC mission in DRC left the territory through Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu) to Rwanda to repatriate back home.
Displacement: Around 24 February 2025 (as reported), around 5 thousand people who were expelled from Katindo camp found shelter in schools in Karisimbi, coded to Goma - Majengo (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Displacement: Around 24 February 2025 (as reported), around 5 thousand people who were expelled from Katindo camp found shelter in schools in Karisimbi, coded to Goma - Majengo (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Looting: Around 23 February 2025 (as reported), FARDC were reported harassing local population in Bobo CK (Kutu, Mai-Ndombo) with barricades and illegal fines of up to 1,500,000 FC. The civil society demanded an investigation by the military auditor's office.
Recruitment: On 23 February 2025, hundreds of police officers, who joined 'voluntarily' M23 arrived from Bukavu to an unspecified location in Goma by boat (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The policemen will receive 'ideological training' before returning to the field. Some police officers confirmed they came on their will and declared to be following the advise from the chiefs of 'quartier'. According to AFC, around 1,800 police officers surrendered and were going for retraining during the past days, plus other 500 who will allegedly join shortly.
Other: On 21 February 2025, the UN Security council adopted a resolution that strongly condemned the M23 offensive in eastern DRC, coded to Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu), asking for an immediate ceasefire, and called in Rwanda Army to stop supporting M23. It also condemns any attack against civilians, and medical and humanitarian personnel, as well as diverse human right violations, and urges the parties to resume diplomatic talks.
Looting: On 21 February 2025, Mobondo militia stole sixty cows in Mongata (Kinshasa, Kinshasa), and they were recovered the next day along with two weapons.
Other: On 21 February 2025, the UN Security council adopted resolution (UNSC Resolution (2773) that strongly condemned the M23 offensive in eastern DRC,)that strongly condemned the M23 offensive in eastern DRC, coded to Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu), asking for an immediate ceasefire, and called in Rwanda Army to stop supporting M23. It also condemns any attack against civilians, and medical and humanitarian personnel, as well as diverse human right violations, and urges the parties to resume diplomatic talks.
Change to armed group: On 21 February 2025, Twirwaneho joined AFC, the political alliance created by M23; coded to Minembwe (Fizi, Sud-Kivu), from where Twirwaneho issued their communique.
Looting: On 21 February 2025, for the second of two consecutive days, FARDC and Wazalendo looted the population in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu).
Non-violent activity: On 21 February 2025, AFC 'momentarily suspended' services for state employees and officials in Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), except for the General Directorate of Migration (DGM), with a vie to 'optimize the public services of efficient and effective management'.
On 20 February 2025, M23 overtook Kipese (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). The location was controlled by FARDC before it was taken by M23. No clash occurred.
Movement of forces: On 20 February 2025, M23 troops were sighted in Lubango (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu).
Movement of forces: On 20 February 2025, M23 troops were sighted in Kasima (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu).
Movement of forces: On 20 February 2025, M23 troops were sighted in Vulera (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), a few kilometers from Lubero town, sparking panic among residents.
Security measures: On 20 February 2025, the provincial government of Haut-Katanga extended the curfew by two weeks, starting on 20 February until 6 March 2025 from 00:00 - 05-00 in the city of Likasi (Likasi, Haut-Katanga) and Lubumbashi (coded separately). This measure, now active for the past month follows a concerning increase of insecurity, and is producing positive results.
Security measures: On 20 February 2025, the provincial government of Haut-Katanga extended the curfew by two weeks, starting on 20 February until 6 March 2025 from 00:00 - 05-00 in the city of Lubumbashi (Lubumbashi, Haut-Katanga) and Likasi (coded separately). This measure, now active for the past month follows a concerning increase of insecurity, and is producing positive results.
On 20 February 2025, M23 overtook Walungu (Walungu, Sud-Kivu). Walungu was controlled by FARDC before M23 overtook it. No clash occurred.
Looting: On 20 February 2025, for the first of two consecutive days, FARDC and Wazalendo looted shops and houses, including the BRALIMA depot, in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu), including from employees at the Bishop's See, whom they briefly sequestered. Gunshots were heard.
Looting: On 20 February 2025, FARDC looted civilians in Lubero town and its surroundings (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). FARDC fired shots in the air and looted shops, containing clothes, phones and suitcases. Residents, hearing gunshots, panicked. Officers announced sanctions the next day.
Movement of forces: Around 19 February 2025 (as reported), hundreds of FARDC men were seen leaving Uvira / Kalundu Port (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) towards Kalemie after clashing with Wazalendo. (clashed previously coded).
Movement of forces: Around 19 February 2025 (as reported), over 500 FARDC men fled Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) by boat towards Burundi. This retreat created panic among the population.
Non-violent activity: On 19 February 2025, M23 held a meeting in Bukavu - Ibanda (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), where they called on the population not to leave the city or other localities under M23 control; asked youth to join the M23 army and police; and announced a city-wide 'Salongo' cleaning operation. They also called on residents to notify them of any 'suspicious people'.
Movement of forces: Around 18 February 2025 (as reported), FARDC withdrew from Mutongo, Mambasa and Kanyambi, coded to Mambasa (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) to Katondi, near Kitsombiro, attempting to reconquer (without success) this village (coded separately)
Movement of forces: On 17 February 2025, the military administrator of Walese Vonkutu announce he will settle in Ofayi (Ofai) (Irumu, Ituri) with his committee. The objective of this decision is to reassure that the army and the police can deploy in this part of the territory, constantly hit by ADF.
Other: On 17 February 2025, schools in Fataki, Djaiba and Lilo, coded to Djaiba (Djugu, Ituri) extended its closure due to the security situation, as CODECO attacks continue. At least 5 thousand chldren are affected by this closure.
Other: On 17 February 2025, Bukavu (Sud-Kivu) observed a relative calm, with circulation of local population and transportation. Some small shops reopened while bigger markets, bars restaurants remained closed.
Defusal: On 17 February 2025, specialized police anti-mine units discovered a grenade left by an unidentified armed group in Biautu quarter of Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu).
Other: On 16 February 2025, around 6 thousand Mbororo nomad herders came to the forest of Nkedere groupment and Mborondamo village, in Sokoro groupement, coded to Mobayi-Mbongo (Mobayi-Mbongo, Nord-Ubangi). The local population fear going to the fields, as the Mbororo are armed. They had invaded other forests in the past in Yakoma territory.
Movement of forces: Around 16 February 2025 (as reported), the Ugandan army/UPDF reinforced their troops presence in Burasi (Bunia, Ituri). The chief of the Ugandan Army announced in a tweet that they'd take control of Bunia to protect the Hema population against CODECO militia. Four military tanks, two armored vehicles and Ugandan soldiers were seen. FARDC clarified in a speech by its spokesman for Ituri (Bunia, Ituri) that UDPF presence in Ituri is part of the joint operations with FARDC against armed groups and it is not an attack, contrary to rumors.
Movement of forces: On 16 February 2025, M23 jeeps were seen in Nguba in Bukavu - Muhungu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu).
Security measures: On 16 February 2025, for the second of two consecutive days, crossings at the border post were blocked in Kamanyola (Walungu, Sud-Kivu) due to an uncertain security situation.
Looting: Around 15 February 2025 (weekend of), Wazalendo looted a FARDC truck full of weapons in Sange (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) and handed out rifles to passersby. It's unclear if the event involved a clash.
Movement of forces: On 15 February 2025, M23 was sighted in Murhesa (Kabare, Sud-Kivu).
On 15 February 2025, the Presidential Guard arrested a Colonel in an unspecified location in Kinshasa, coded to Kinshasa (Kinshasa) who used to serve as security guard of a late influential Intelligence chief found dead in unclear circumstances in 2020. There is no information on his current location after the arrest.
Security measures: On 15 February 2025, the Ministry of Health announced an agreement to open a humanitarian corridor in Goma, coded to Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu) to facilitate essential aid reaches populations in need. WHO will transport equipment via Kigali and Nairobi.
Other: On 15 February 2025, the Ministry of Public Health announced the opening of the humanitarian corridor in the Goma region, coded as Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). WHO obtained the agreement to deliver equipment and essential aid via Nairobi and Kigali.
Displacement: On 15 February 2025, people were observed crossing the border from Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu) towards Rusizi (Rwanda). Some of them flee for the second time, coming initially from Goma.
Looting: On 15 February 2025, M23 and residents looted several big shops, the main market and the town hall in Bukavu - Kadutu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). An unspecified number of shops were set on fire after being looted. Several FARDC escaped, leaving their weapons behind.
Other: On 15 February 2025, young civilians seized weapons left behind at Saio military camp by fleeing FARDC/FDNB (coded separately) and started patrolling Bukavu, coded to Bukavu - Ndendere (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu).
Movement of forces: On 15 February 2025, residents saw FARDC in Bukavu - Kadutu (Kadutu, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu).
Security measures: On 15 February 2025, for the first of two consecutive days, crossings at the border post were blocked in Kamanyola (Walungu, Sud-Kivu) due to an uncertain security situation. Sporadic gunshots were heard. An unspecified number of trucks were blocked at the border post.
Other: Around 14 February 2025 (as reported), all IDPs/refugees from Bulengo Camp (Masisi, Nord-Kivu) were forced to leave, as M23 set an ultimatum for them to empty the camp. Looting: On 14 February 2025, CODECO stole the motorbikes of 5 gold miners coming from Lopa, coded to Lopa (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri). It is unclear what happened to the men.

Looting: On 12 February 2025, CODECO ambushed one transportation vehicle in Kpengbele (Djugu, Ituri), stealing all the merchandise and money in cash.
Looting: On 12 February 2025, CODECO ambushed two taxi vehicles on the Katoto-Largu section, coded to Katoto (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri) taking all their goods.

Non-violent activity: On 11 February 2025, M23 gave 72 hours to IDPs in Lushagala Camp (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu) and Bulengo camp (coded separately) to vacate the camp and return to their village. M23 told the IDPs to destroy their shelter.
Displacement: On 10 February 2025, some IDPs left the 8th CEPAC and the Bulengo Camp (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu) after the M23 militia gave a 72-hour ultimatum to leave the camps the previous day. Several IDPs returned to their home villages in the Masisi territory.
Displacement: Around 10 February 2025 (as reported), several IDPs left the Kanyaruchinya Camp (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), taking refuge at public buildings in Goma or attempting to return to their village of origin after the M23 militia destroyed the IDP camps. M23 militia claimed Wazalendo forces were hiding in the camp.
Displacement: Around 10 February 2025 (as reported), several IDPs left the Rusayo 2 camp in Rusayo (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), taking refuge at public buildings in Goma or attempting to return to their village of origin.
Displacement: On 10 February 2025, more than 5000 people fled Sud-Kivu towards Kalemie (Kalemie, Tanganyika), in face of the M23 advance.
Property destruction: On 10 February 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group 'attacked' the residence of the territorial governor in Sange (Uvira, Uvira, Sud-Kivu). It is unclear if the target was present at the time. Security forces intervened to repel the attackers though it is unclear a clash took place. No further details.
Displacement: Around 10 February 2025 (as reported), several IDPs left the Nzulo 1, near Goma - Mugunga (Karisimbi, Goma, Nord-Kivu), taking refuge at public buildings in Goma or attempting to return to their village of origin after the M23 militia destroyed the IDP camps. M23 militia claimed Wazalendo forces were hiding in the camp.
Looting: On 9 February 2025, an unidentified armed group looted a money transfer house in the Butsili neighborhood of Beni (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu).
Looting: On 8 February 2025, ADF looted 632 goats, 105 sheep, 81 cows, and more than 100 chickens in four locations in the Bapere area: Kitevya and Masaki, both coded to Bapere town (Bapere, Lubero, Nord-Kivu), and Fungulamacho and Maeba (coded separately).
Looting: On 8 February 2025, ADF looted 632 goats, 105 sheep, 81 cows, and more than 100 chickens in four locations in the Bapere area: Fungulamacho (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu), Mayeba, Kitevya and Masaki (coded separately).
Looting: On 8 February 2025, ADF looted 632 goats, 105 sheep, 81 cows, and more than 100 chickens in four locations in the Bapere area: Maeba/Mayeba (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu), Fungulamacho, Kitevya and Masaki (coded separately).
Displacement: Around 8 February 2025 (as reported), a massive displacement has been observed in Kalehe Territory, along the National Route 2 (coded to Kalehe) (Kalehe, Sud Kivu). People are moving more than once, as the situation deteriorated in the places they had fled to: from Minova, Numbi, and Nyamasasa to Nyabibwe, until its occupation on 5 February, then to Kalehe until clashes on Thursday, and then to l'ile Idjwi and Bukavu.
Looting: On 8 February 2025, an unidentified armed group (likely FARDC and Wazalendo based on recent activity in the area) fired sporadic shots while looting and vandalizing shops and small markets in Bukavu (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu).
Looting: Around 7 February 2025, FARDC and Wazalendo forces looted from civilians in Murhesa (Kabare, Sud-Kivu).
Property destruction: Around 7 February 2025 (as reported), M23-RDF vandalized a shop owned by a journalist in Katana center (Kabare, Sud-Kivu).
Other: On 7 February 2025, the OHCHR (UN Human Rights Council) agreed to launch an urgent commission of inquiry into atrocities committed by all parties in Eastern DRC (likely to focus on Goma, due to the recent seizure by M-23, coded to Goma) (Goma, Nord-Kivu), This commission will investigate abuses of international human rights and humanitarian law, collect and preserve evidence, and identify responsible.
Other: On 7 February 2025, gunshots were heard in several neighborhoods of the city of Goma (coded to Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Security measures: On 7 February 2025, (as reported), the government of Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) established a curfew from 21:00 to 05:00, responding to the volatile security situation due to the progress of M23 towards South-Kivu. The movement of vehicles in and out of Uvira is prohibited after 18:00, as per the imposed restriction.
Movement of forces: Around 7 February 2025 (as reported), FDNB deployed reinforcement of one additional battalion around Bukavu, coded to the town of Bukavu (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). Burundi deployed 8,000 to 12, 000 soldiers since its military agreement with the Congolese government in September 2023.
Other: On 7 February 2025, the schools and universities closed for one day in Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu) due to the security concerns as M23-RDF were approaching Bukavu. The urban football alliance also suspended the local championship.
Movement of forces: Around 5 February 2025 (week of), 700 to 800 SANDF soldiers were sent by plane to Lubumbashi (Haut-Katanga). It is unclear whether those soldiers were sent to join the SADC mission in DRC (SAMIRDC) or as part of a bilateral ad-hoc deployment. The South African Parliament Defence Commission was not informed of the deployment.
Movement of forces: Around 5 February 2025 (as reported), 40 vehicles of UPDF forces and more than 1,000 soldiers were deployed as reinforcement in Boga (Baniari-Tchabi, Irumu, Ituri).
Recruitment: Around 5 February 2025 (as reported), FARDC recruited at least 300 women and men in Kolwezi (Kolwezi, Lualaba).
Displacement: Around 5 February 2025 (from 27 January - 11 February), after M23 seized Goma, at least 32,600 displaced people left their IDP sites (Kanyaruchinya, Don Bosco Ngangi, Kahembe, Bushagara) near Goma and returned to their villages in Nyiragongo territory, coded to territorial capital Kibumba (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu).
Displacement: Around 5 February 2025 (from 27 January - 11 February), following M23's occupation of Goma, at least 42,600 displaced people (7,100 households) returned to their home villages in Masisi territory, in health zones Sake, Kaduki, Kimoka, Kihindo and Sasha, coded to territorial capital Masisi (Masisi, Nord-Kivu).
Movement of forces: On 4 February 2025, an unspecified number of M23 jeeps were seen in Murambi (Masisi, Nord-Kivu).
Movement of forces: On 4 February 2025, 5 convoys of M23 jeeps arrived in Kisale, near Mukwija (Sud-Kivu).
Recruitment: On 4 February 2025, FARDC recruited more than 500 young women and men in Gemena (Gemena, Sud-Ubangi). The recruits were taken to a military camp for training and will join other FARDC soldiers to fight M23.
Other: On 4 February 2025, M23 started an unilateral ceasefire in the East of DRC, coded to Bukavu based on communique issuing place (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), according to a later communique dated 22 February.
Other: On 3 February 2025, gunshots were heard near the President's residence in Goma - Himbi, Nord-Kivu.
Movement of forces: Around 3 February 2025 (as reported), M23 reinforced its troops in Kisale, 10km from Nyabibwe and near Mukwija (Sud-Kivu).
Other: On 3 February 2025, M23 unilaterally declared a ceasefire for 'humanitarian reasons' in Goma, coded to Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu), which was overtaken by the group the week prior (coded separately).
On 3 February 2025, FARDC arrested the leader of Mayi Mayi (Saga Balende) in Beni (Beni, Nord-Kivu). No further details.
Looting: On 3 February 2025, FARDC looted 5 commercial vehicles coming from the market in Kabamba (Kabare, Sud-Kivu).
Looting: On 2 February 2025, an unidentified armed group ambushed seven motorbikes and looted several goods, including mobile phones, laptops and money, on national road 3, in Bunyakiri (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu). Police officers arrested 1 man.
Movement of forces: On 1 February 2025, a convoy of M23 was seen traveling toward Alimbongo (Batangi, Lubero, Nord-Kivu), causing civilians to return to Kirumba, where they had fled some weeks ago.
Displacement: Around 1 February 2025 (as reported), more than 1,600 IDPs returned to Tshabi (Baniari-Tchabi, Irumu, Ituri) after being displaced in Komanda due to conflict.
Looting: Around 1 February 2025 (as reported), M23-RDF looted companies and public establishments in an unspecified location in Goma, coded to Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). They stole 2 Land Cruisers, a van, and a safe containing 7,500 US dollars and 4 million Congolese Francs. They also looted the CENI headquarters and warehouses.
Movement of forces: On 1 February 2025, convoys of M23-RDF vehicles and walking troops were seen in Kirumba (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) going towards Alimbongo.
Displacement: Around 1 February 2025 (as reported), civilians fled the IDP site in Bushagara Camp (Goma, Nord-Kivu) following clashes M23/RDF and FARDC and their allies (coded separately). Many civilians are unsure of where to seek refuge.
Movement of forces: On 1 February 2025, the Ugandan forces reinforced their presence in unknown locations in Lubero territory, coded to the territorial capital Lubero (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu). The Ugandan forces are supporting FARDC forces against ADF militia in the territory.
Movement of forces: Around 1 February 2025 (as reported), the Minister of Public Administration launched a registration drive for youth volunteers in Bukavu city (Sud-Kivu) to join the FARDC and its allies against M23.

graphRAG_summary:
### Summary of Key Battles in the Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**Sud-Kivu:**
- **Uvira:** Intensive clashes between FARDC and Wazalendo occurred over several days, resulting in significant casualties. Key events include:
  - 15 February: 18 fatalities (DRC34827).
  - 16 February: 12 fatalities (DRC34826).
  - 18 February: 9 fatalities (DRC34862).
  - 19 February: 8 fatalities (DRC34857).
  - 25 February: 20 fatalities (DRC34996).
  - Medical facilities were affected, and civilian populations were displaced (DRC34827, DRC34862, DRC34857).

- **Kahuzi-Biega National Park:** M23 clashed with Wazalendo on 28 February, resulting in 10 fatalities (DRC35012).

- **Kamanyola:** Multiple clashes occurred, including:
  - 15 February: FARDC and Wazalendo clashed (DRC34868).
  - 17 February: Wazalendo clashed against FARDC (DRC34815).
  - 21 February: Twirwaneho clashed against FARDC and Wazalendo (DRC34853).
  - 25 February: M23 clashed with suspected Wazalendo and FDNB (DRC35010).

**Nord-Kivu:**
- **Lubero:** M23 engaged in multiple clashes with FARDC and Wazalendo, resulting in significant displacements:
  - 18 February: M23 clashed against FARDC in Musienene and Kimbulu, causing a massive displacement (DRC35094, DRC35095).
  - 20 February: M23 clashed against various armed groups, including Wazalendo, in multiple locations (DRC35181, DRC35182, DRC35183).

- **Bamate:** M23 attacked FARDC positions on 11 February, resulting in 14 fatalities (DRC34747, DRC34796).

**Ituri:**
- **Djugu:** CODECO clashed with an unidentified armed group on 16 February, resulting in 10 fatalities (DRC34811).
- **Walendu-Tatsi:** FPAC (Zaire) militia clashed with FARDC on 9 February, resulting in 5 civilian fatalities (DRC34724).
- **Nyamamba:** Zaire militia clashed with FARDC on 26 February, resulting in 3 fatalities (DRC35029).

**Kinshasa:**
- **Maluku:** FARDC clashed with Mobondo militia on 22 February, resulting in 6 fatalities (DRC34967, DRC35108).

**Mai-Ndombe:**
- **Kwamouth:** FARDC clashed with Mobondo militia on 7 February, resulting in 6 fatalities (DRC34665).
- **Plateaux:** FARDC clashed with Mobondo militia on 10 February, resulting in 2 fatalities (DRC34793).

**Tanganyika:**
- **Nyunzu:** An unidentified armed group clashed with FARDC on 13 February, resulting in 4 fatalities (DRC34885).

**Tshopo:**
- **Yahuma:** Residents clashed over customary succession and logging tensions on 6 February, resulting in 2 fatalities (DRC34650).

**Other Notable Events:**
- **Kalehe:** Multiple clashes between M23 and FARDC occurred throughout February, with varying levels of intensity and unknown casualties (DRC34670, DRC34671, DRC34674, DRC34680, DRC34683, DRC34684, DRC34685, DRC34739, DRC34748, DRC34756, DRC34763, DRC34765, DRC34768, DRC34769, DRC34
simple_summary:
### Summary of Key Battles in Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**Conflict Hotspots and Major Battles:**

1. **M23 vs. Wazalendo and FARDC:**
   - **Kahuzi-Biega National Park (February 28):** M23 clashed with Wazalendo, resulting in 7 Wazalendo and 3 M23 fatalities. (Event ID: 1)
   - **Katogota (February 27):** Suspected M23 clashed with suspected Wazalendo and FDNB, with heavy weapons heard. Casualties unknown. (Event ID: 2)
   - **Masisi Town (February 20):** Wazalendo clashed with M23, resulting in the death of an MSF worker and injury of a child due to stray bullets. (Event ID: 30)
   - **Various Locations (February 20):** M23 clashed with various armed groups, including Wazalendo, in multiple locations, resulting in several civilian fatalities. (Event IDs: 31-37)

2. **FARDC vs. Zaire and CODECO:**
   - **Masumbuko (February 26):** Zaire clashed with FARDC, resulting in 2 FARDC fatalities and a policeman briefly held hostage. (Event ID: 3)
   - **Nyamamba (February 26):** Zaire clashed with FARDC, causing significant displacement and at least 3 fatalities. (Event ID: 4)
   - **Djaiba (February 16):** CODECO clashed with FARDC and MONUSCO, with 3 houses burned. (Event ID: 46)

3. **FARDC vs. Mobondo Militia:**
   - **Maluko Commune (February 22):** FARDC clashed with Mobondo, resulting in at least 6 Mobondo fatalities. (Event ID: 5)
   - **Ntomo (February 22):** FARDC clashed with Mobondo, resulting in at least 3 Mobondo fatalities. (Event ID: 6)

4. **FARDC vs. Twirwaneho and RED-Tabara:**
   - **Mikenge (February 25):** Twirwaneho, supported by RED-Tabara, clashed with FARDC and Wazalendo, overtook the area. Casualties unknown. (Event ID: 8)
   - **Minembwe (February 25):** Twirwaneho, supported by RED-Tabara, clashed with Wazalendo and FARDC, overtook the area. Casualties unknown. (Event ID: 10)

5. **FARDC vs. CODECO and Zaire:**
   - **Buchama (February 8):** Zaire clashed with FARDC, resulting in FARDC pushing Zaire back and capturing one. (Event ID: 48)
   - **Buntsele (February 7):** FARDC clashed with Mobondo, resulting in 6 Mobondo fatalities. (Event ID: 49)

**Significant Displacements and Humanitarian Impact:**
   - **Nyamamba (February 26):** Significant displacement of civilians towards Kasenyi, Tchomia, Nyamusasi Camp site, and Uganda, with MONUSCO supporting the evacuation of 60 civilians. (Event ID: 4)
   - **Masisi and Surrounding Areas (February 18):** Massive displacement of around 100,000 people due to clashes between M23 and FARDC. (Event IDs: 21-23)
   - **Uvira (February 19):** Significant displacement of the population towards Burundi, Hauts Plateaux, Kalemie, and Moba due to clashes between FARDC and Wazalendo. (Event ID: 19)

**Other Notable Events:**
   - **Sange (February 19):** M23 overtook Sange following clashes with FARDC. (Event ID: 28)
   - **Kinshasa (February 27):** Police arrested 245 suspected bandits. (Event ID: 50)
   - **Goma (February 1):** Gunshots heard near the President's residence. (Event ID: 51)

**Human Rights and Civilian Impact:**
   - **Bukavu (February 28):** Unidentified armed group killed at least 5 people. (Event ID: 52)
   - **Kinshasa (February 7):** Schools and universities closed due
corpus:
On 28 February 2025, M23 clashed against Wazalendo in Kafurumaye, in Kahuzi-Biega National Park, coded to Kahuzi-Biega National Park (HQ) (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). 7 Wazalendo and 3 M23 dead.
On 27 February 2025, suspected M23 clashed against suspected Wazalendo and FDNB between Kamanyola and Katogota, coded to Katogota (Bafuliro, Uvira, Sud-Kivu). Heavy weapons were heard. M23 retreated towards Kamanyola. Casualties unknown.
On 26 February 2025, Zaire clashed against FARDC and police forces in Masumbuko (Bahema Nord, Djugu, Ituri). 2 FARDC dead. A policeman was briefly held hostage and freed some hours later around Nyamamba. The militiamen had conducted other attacks in the same location (coded separately).
On 26 February 2025, overnight, Zaire militia clashed against FARDC in Nyamamba (Djugu, Ituri) in the Lake Albert plain. A displacement of population was observed towards Kasenyi, Tchomia, Nyamusasi Camp site, and Uganda. MONUSCO supported the evacuation of 60 civilians by water, who were trapped between the clashes. FARDC pushed back Zaire away from Nyamamba and Tchomia surroundings. Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 3, and at least 15 wounded.
On 25 February 2025, for the third of three days, Twirwaneho supported by RED-Tabara 'violently' clashed against FARDC supported by Wazalendo and overtook Mikenge (Itombwe, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 25 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Wazalendo over control of the former MONUSCO based in Sange (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). At least 20 dead and 'dozens' injured.
On 25 February 2025, Twirwaneho supported by RED-Tabara clashed against Wazalendo supported by FARDC and overtook Minembwe (Fizi, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
Around 25 February 2025 (from 24 - 27 February), Zaire clashed with FARDC in Masumbuko (Bahema Nord, Djugu, Ituri). There was a total of 6 fatalities from the clashes. A specific clash was coded on 26 February with 2 fatalities; 4 fatalities remaining coded for this event.
On 24 February 2025, for the second of three days, Twirwaneho supported by RED-Tabara clashed against FARDC supported by Wazalendo in Mikenge (Itombwe, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 23 February 2025, FARDC clashed against M23 in Kipese (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 23 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Twirwaneho-M23-AFC in Mikenge (Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 23 February 2025, for the first of three days, Twirwaneho supported by RED-Tabara clashed against FARDC supported by Wazalendo in Mikenge (Itombwe, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 22 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Mobondo militia in Maluko commune, 5 km away from Mongata (Maluku, Kinshasa). At least 6 Mobondo killed. Sixty cows stolen the day before were recovered, and two weapons.
On 22 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Mobondo militia in Ntomo, 5 km away from Kwamouth (Plateaux, Kwamouth, Mai-Ndombe). At least (provisional tolls) three Mobondo killed and one weapon recovered.
On 22 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Mobondo militia in Maluko commune, 5 km away from Mongata (Maluku, Kinshasa). At least 6 Mobondo killed. Several cows looted and recovered (coded separately).
Around 22 February 2025 (as reported), M23 overtook Rusamambu (Walikale, Nord-Kivu), following clashes with FARDC. Casualties unknown.
On 21 February 2025, Twirwaneho clashed against FARDC and Wazalendo in the mountains surrounding Minembwe, coded to Minembwe (Fizi, Sud-Kivu). According to official declarations by FARDC at the time of the report, it was too early to tell who was controlling Minembwe as clashes were ongoing. Twirwaneho was signaled by a recent UN report as an ally of AFC/M23
On 21 February 2025, FARDC launched an attack on Twirwaneho in and around Minembwe (Fizi, Sud-Kivu), days after the killing of Twirwaneho leader Makanika (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo in Kahongole and Lushebere, coded to Lushebere (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), Masisi centre, Lwanguba, Kanii, Katale, and Kibuye (coded separately). 3 fatalities split across 6 events. Coded to 0.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo in Kanii (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), Masisi centre, Lwanguba, Katale, Lushebere, and Kibuye (coded separately). # people were killed. 3 fatalities split across 6 events. Coded to 0.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo in Katale (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), Masisi centre, Lwanguba, Kanii, Lushebere, and Kibuye (coded separately). At least 3 civilians were killed. 3 fatalities split across 6 events, coded as 1.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo in Lwanguba (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), Masisi centre, Katale, Kanii, Lushebere, and Kibuye (coded separately). At least 3 civilians were killed . 3 fatalities split across 6 events. Coded to 1.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo in Kibuye, close to Kihuma (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), Masisi center, Lwanguba, Kanii, Lushebere, and Katale (coded separately). 3 fatalities split across 6 events, coded as 1.
On 20 February 2025, Wazalendo clashed against M23 in Masisi town (Masisi, Nord-Kivu). Stray bullets reached a MSF base, killing a MSF worker and injuring a child. Combatant casualties unknown.
Around 20 February 2025 (as reported), M23 clashed against different armed groups, including Wazalendo, in Masisi Centre (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), Katale, Lwanguba, Kanii, Lushebere, and Kibuye (coded separately). At least 3 civilians were killed. 3 fatalities split across 6 events, coded as 1.
On 19 February 2025, M23 clashed against FARDC in Katondi/Katumbi (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). FARDC pushed M23 back towards Kitsambiro. Casualties unknown.
On 19 February 2025, M23 overtook Sange (Uvira, Sud-Kivu), following clashes with FARDC. No casualties.
On 19 February 2025, overnight, MONUSCO and FARDC clashed against CODECO in Sanduku (Djugu, Ituri), after CODECO set fire to three houses. CODECO was pushed back. There were no casualties.
On 19 February 2025, M23 clashed against FARDC and Wazalendo and overtook Rusamambu (Wanianga, Walikale, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 19 February 2025, for the fifth of at least five consecutive days, FARDC and Wazalendo clashed against each other in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). The reason of these clashes was that Wazalendo requested FARDC to leave their war material to them before leaving towards Kalemie. 17 fatalities including civilians, Wazalendo and FARDC split across two days, Coded as 8. FARDC allegedly also ransacked telephones and money, and damaged several houses.
On 19 February 2025, M23 clashed with FDNB and Wazalendo, subsequently taking control of the border post in Kamanyola (Walungu, Sud-Kivu). M23 retained some members from FDNB and Wazalendo. No fatalities.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against Wazalendo in Alimbongo (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), and towards the hills in Vutsorovya, Tchulo and Mambasa (coded separately) in direction to Butembo. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against Wazalendo in the hills of Vutsorovya and Tchulo, coded to Vutsorovya (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), and Mambasa in direction to Butembo, and Alimbongo (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against FARDC in Musienene (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) and Kimbulu (coded separately). Looting reported during clashes. A massive displacement was observed of around 100,000 new displaced people on the Alimbongo-Kitsombiro, Alimbongo-Kipese and BingiKasugho, especially towards Masereka, Musienene and Butembo. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against FARDC in Kimbulu (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) and Musienne (coded separately). Looting reported during clashes. A massive displacement was observed of around 100,000 new displaced people on the Alimbongo-Kitsombiro, Alimbongo-Kipese and BingiKasugho, especially towards Masereka, Musienene and Butembo. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against Wazalendo in the hills of Mambosa (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), Vutsorovya, Tchulo (coded separately) in direction to Butembo, and in Alimbongo (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, M23/AFC took control of Ndoluma (Lubero, Nord-Kivu) following intense clashes against FARDC, who ended up retreating from Mutongo, Mambasa and Kanyambi (coded separately). People and civil authorities were observed fleeing towards Lubero-center, and Butembo. Casualties unknown.
On 18 February 2025, FARDC and MONUSCO pushed back CODECO in Gokalu (Walendu Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri), as the group was attempting to attack the village. No further details.
On 18 February 2025, for the fourth of at least five consecutive days, FARDC and Wazalendo clashed against each other in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). The reason of these clashes was that Wazalendo requested FARDC to leave their war material to them before leaving towards Kalemie. 17 fatalities including civilians, Wazalendo, and FARDC split across two days, coded as 9. FARDC allegedly also ransacked telephones and money, and damaged several houses. The population in Uvira left massively towards Burundi, Hauts Plateaux, Kalemie and Moba.
On 18 February 2025, M23 clashed against FARDC and overtook Kitsambiro (Lubero, Nord-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
On 17 February 2025, AFC/M23 clashed against Wazalendo and the Burundian Army in Nyangezi (Walungu, Sud-Kivu). The latter two were supposedly defeated. Casualties unknown.
On 17 February 2025, for the third of at least five consecutive days, Wazalendo clashed against FARDC in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu), Kamanyola (coded separately) and other towns on N5 road when Wazalendo were trying to disarm or stop FARDC from retreating or deserting. Casualties unknown.
On 17 February 2025, for the first of at least two consecutive days, Wazalendo clashed against FARDC in Kamanyola (Walungu, Sud-Kivu), and Uvira (coded separately) and other towns on N5 road. Wazalendo were trying to disarm or stop FARDC from retreating or deserting. Casualties unknown.
On 16 February 2025, overnight, CODECO clashed against FARDC and MONUSCO in Djaiba (Djugu, Ituri) for some minutes until CODECO was pulled back. 3 houses were burned. This attack is part of a series of four consecutive attacks, seen as a retaliation. Casualties unknown.
Around 16 February 2025 (as reported), CODECO clashed with an unidentified armed group in Cafe / Datule (Djugu, Ituri). At least 10 fatalities.
On 16 February 2025, for the second of at least five consecutive days, Wazalendo clashed against FARDC in Uvira / Kalundu port (Walungu, Sud-Kivu), Kamanyola (coded separately) and other towns on N5 road. Wazalendo were trying to disarm or stop FARDC from retreating or deserting, by boat towards Kalemie. FARDC allegedly refused to hand out their weapons which caused the clash. 12 fatalities (fatalities coded according to Radio Okapi).
On 16 February 2025, Wazalendo and FARDC clashed against each other in Luvungi (Bafuliro, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.
Around 15 February 2025 (weekend of), Wazalendo and FARDC clashed against each other in Sange (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). Wazalendo looted a FARDC truck full of weapons and handed out rifles to passersby. Casualties unknown.
On 15 February 2025, CODECO clashed against Zaire in an attempt to attack Maze (Djugu, Ituri) for the second consecutive day. CODECO was pushed back. Unspecified number fatalities coded as 3.
On 15 February 2025, for the first of at least five consecutive days, Wazalendo clashed against FARDC in Uvira (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). 18 fatalities. The General Hospital of Uvira came under crossfire, forcing Medical activities to be halted, and patients were forced to take shelter to avoid being hit. Armed men also entered the hospital premises, moving around and shooting inside.
On 15 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Wazalendo in Kalundu (Uvira, Sud-Kivu) and Kasenga (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 15 February 2025, FARDC clashed against Wazalendo in Kasenga (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). Casualties unknown.

graphRAG_summary:
### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Explosions/Remote Violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

1. **Sud-Kivu:**
   - **27 February 2025:** Two explosions at a meeting in Bukavu's Place de l'Indépendance resulted in 17 fatalities and over 70 injuries. M23 accused the DRC and Burundian army, while FARDC blamed Rwanda and M23. (DRC35008)
   - **13 February 2025:** M23 reported that FARDC bombed densely populated areas in Kalehe, killing 10 and injuring 25. Congolese sources did not confirm the event. (DRC34792)
   - **11 February 2025:** Bombs fell on civilian houses in Munguahwere during clashes between M23 and FARDC. No fatalities were reported. (DRC34749)
   - **25 February 2025:** Twirwaneho reported that FARDC bombed two villages in Mwenga using a Sukhoi fighter jet and a drone, destroying buildings but causing no casualties. (DRC34994, DRC34993)

2. **Nord-Kivu:**
   - **9 February 2025:** M23 shelled FARDC positions in Ndoluma, resulting in 14 fatalities, including one civilian and 10 FARDC soldiers. (DRC34745)
   - **18 February 2025:** A farmer died after stepping on a landmine in Lese, likely planted by ADF. (DRC34847)
   - **11 February 2025:** M23 shelled FARDC positions in Kivisire, with unknown casualties. (DRC34753)
   - **20 February 2025:** A shell hit a humanitarian base in Masisi, with no reported casualties. (DRC35166)

3. **Ituri:**
   - **6 February 2025:** Three landmines planted by ADF detonated between Mama Neema and Mayi Safi, killing two people. (DRC34848)

4. **Sud-Kivu (Additional Reports):**
   - **19 February 2025:** A drone strike killed Michel Rukunda and five others, including a RED-Tabara leader, in Gakangala. The Congolese Press Agency attributed the strike to Rwanda, while Rwandan sources blamed FARDC. (DRC34846)
   - **6 February 2025:** M23/AFC claimed that FARDC bombed Nyabibwe, killing four civilians, including a child. (DRC34918)

**Conclusion:**
The month of February 2025 saw significant remote violence and explosions in the Democratic Republic of Congo, particularly in Sud-Kivu and Nord-Kivu. The incidents involved various armed groups, including M23, FARDC, ADF, and Twirwaneho, with accusations and counter-accusations among the parties. The high number of casualties and the destruction of civilian infrastructure highlight the ongoing conflict and the need for urgent intervention and resolution.
simple_summary:
### Summary of Key Developments: Explosions/Remote Violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, February 2025

**February 2025** saw a series of significant explosions and remote violence incidents in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), primarily involving clashes between various armed groups and the Congolese Armed Forces (FARDC).

1. **Bombing and Shelling Incidents**:
   - On **27 February 2025**, two explosives detonated at a meeting in Bukavu, killing at least 17 people and injuring over 70. M23 and the DRC/Burundian army accused each other of involvement (Event ID: 270225_01).
   - On **25 February 2025**, FARDC bombed two villages in Sud-Kivu using a Sukhoi fighter jet and a drone, destroying buildings but causing no casualties (Event ID: 250225_01, 250225_02).
   - Around **20 February 2025**, a shell hit a humanitarian base in Masisi, Nord-Kivu, with no casualties reported (Event ID: 200225_01).
   - On **19 February 2025**, a drone strike killed Michel Rukunda and five others in Fizi, Sud-Kivu. The responsibility for the strike is disputed between FARDC and the Rwanda Defence Forces (RDF) (Event ID: 190225_01).
   - On **18 February 2025**, a farmer was killed by a landmine in Beni, Nord-Kivu, likely planted by the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) (Event ID: 180225_01).
   - Around **15 February 2025**, suspected M23/RDF shelled Bukavu, destroying houses (Event ID: 150225_01).
   - On **13 February 2025**, FARDC allegedly bombed Kalehe, Sud-Kivu, killing 10 people and injuring 25, though Congolese sources do not confirm this event (Event ID: 130225_01).
   - On **11 February 2025**, bombs fell on civilian houses in Kalehe, Sud-Kivu, during clashes between M23 and FARDC, with no fatalities (Event ID: 110225_01).
   - On **9 February 2025**, M23 shelled FARDC positions in Lubero, Nord-Kivu, killing 14 people, including civilians and FARDC soldiers (Event ID: 090225_01).
   - Around **6 February 2025**, three landmines detonated in Ituri, killing two people (Event ID: 060225_01).
   - On **6 February 2025**, FARDC allegedly bombed Nyabibwe, Sud-Kivu, killing four civilians (Event ID: 060225_02).

2. **Clashes and Movement of Forces**:
   - On **25 February 2025**, Twirwaneho, supported by RED-Tabara, clashed with FARDC in Mwenga, Sud-Kivu, over three days, taking control of Mikenge (Event ID: 250225_03).
   - On **18 February 2025**, M23 clashed with Wazalendo in Lubero, Nord-Kivu (Event ID: 180225_02).
   - On **20 February 2025**, M23 troops were sighted in Lubango, Lubero, Nord-Kivu (Event ID: 200225_02).
   - Around **11 February 2025**, M23 overtook Muhongoza, Kalehe, Sud-Kivu (Event ID: 110225_02).

3. **Other Incidents**:
   - On **22 February 2025**, suspected M23 killed at least ten young men in Goma, Nord-Kivu, with varying accounts of the circumstances (Event ID: 220225_01).
   - Around **7 February 2025**, M23-RDF vandalized a shop in Katana, Sud-Kivu (Event ID: 070225_01).

The Congolese Press Agency said the drone strike was conducted by the Rwanda Defence Forces because Makanika had refused to collaborate with M23.
