On 30 April 2025, unidentified armed men attacked the residence of a human rights defender and member of the Justice and Peace ministry in Bukavu (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). There were no fatalities. The attackers attempted to break into the property but were deterred by guard dogs. The activist house was also targeted on February 2025.
On 30 April 2025, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed a civilian in Goma - Ndosho (Karisimbi, Goma, Nord-Kivu) for an unknown reason.
On 29 April 2025, CODECO killed two farmers in their fields in Aludja, located two kilometers from Itendey (Banyali-Kilo, Djugu, Ituri). Some sources say they were shot dead while others say they were killed with machetes.
On 29 April 2025, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed 2 civilians around Songo (Uvira, Sud-Kivu). 1 of the victims was found in Avenue du Marche, and the other in Avenue du Stade. The residents suspect that the victims were abducted and brought to the area.
On 28 April 2025, CODECO shot at civilians, injuring two, at the sawmill in Abelkoze (Banyali-Kilo, Djugu, Ituri). No further details.
On 27 April 2025, overnight, ADF attacked and killed 5 civilians in the Baswagha chiefdom, coded to Baswagha (Lubero, Lubero, Nord-Kivu). Several civilians were abducted, including three students.
On 27 April 2025, CODECO shot at a passenger bus on RN27 in Masikini (Djugu, Ituri). There were no fatalities. No further details.
On 27 April 2025, overnight, Zaire lashed and 'tortured' a young man to death in Djaiba (Walendu-Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri), accusing him of not paying the weekly 'contribution' expected by the armed group.
Around 27 April 2025 (as reported), an unidentified armed group attacked civilians in Banana (Mambasa, Mambasa, Ituri). 1 civilian was killed and 1 civilian was injured.
Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), M23 conducted 'forced recruitment operations' in Kabuga (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). No further details.
Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), M23 conducted 'forced recruitment operations' in Cirato and Kakenge in Kabare territory, both coded to territorial capital Kabare (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). No further details.
On 23 April 2025, an unidentified armed group 'arrested and assaulted' (no further information) a CENI agent in Kalehe (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu), after destroying electoral materials. No further details.
Around 23 April 2025 (as reported), Mayi Mayi (faction unspecified) killed 3 farmers in Bandikapau village, in Babila-Babombi chiefdom, coded to known location in Babila-Babombi, Njiapanda (Babila-Babombi, Mambasa, Ituri). A provincial MP said the attackers were a Mayi Mayi group newly installed in this area.
On 23 April 2025, an unidentified armed group injured an ANR (National Intelligence Agency) agent at his home (off-duty) at an unspecified location in Bukavu territory (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). Coded to Bukavu. No further details.
On 22 April 2025, an unidentified armed group (likely M23 as the group has control over the area) abducted approximately 50 youth from their homes in Buhama village, Kibati groupement (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), and brought them towards Rutshuru. No further details.
On 21 April 2025, a Wazalendo from CNPSC killed a Burundian civilian following a scuffle in Misisi (Ngandja, Fizi, Sud-Kivu).
On 20 April 2025, an unidentified armed group killed a man at his residence in Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). He was the Academic Director of Tuungane Institution.
On 20 April 2025, suspected M23 militants killed an MSF worker at his residence while he was sleeping in Goma - Birere neighborhood (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 20 April 2025, an armed group (likely M23 due to their presence and activity in the area) attacked and killed a couple while they were sleeping, fleeing conflict, in the forest of Kibati (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The reasons are unknown.
On 19 April 2025, suspected Wazalendo ambushed a bus, asked women to get off the bus to receive lashes, undressed one of them who had just had a cesarean and beat and tortured the driver along the RN4 route at PK23, coded to Ubundu (Ubundu, Tshopo). They also took money and phones from the passengers . This same vehicle was first ambushed at PK26 and then again at PK24. No information on injuries.
On 19 April 2025, suspected FDLR abducted a 'notable' chief, then beheaded him in Kisharo (also spelled as Kisharu), rural entity of Binza (Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu). His body was found by local farmers. This area is under control of M23.
On 17 April 2025, FARDC soldiers shot at civilians in Mukera (Mutambala, Fizi, Sud-Kivu). The soldiers were shooting to protest against the order to join the front in the highlands when their arrears haven't yet been paid. Three people were injured.
On 17 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group attacked an elected communal counsellor at his home in Kasuku (Kailo, Maniema), saying they had been sent to kill him. They violently hit him with bladed weapons. Attackers left when they heard police coming. They took with them 1000 USD and over 300 000 Congolese Francs (approximately 100 USD) as well as four phones, two laptops and one hard drive.
On 15 April 2025, an unidentified armed group attacked a Pentecostal pastor at his home in Goma - Virunga (Karisimbi, Goma, Nord-Kivu). They seriously beat him and stabbed him several times, including on his head. They also looted several valuable goods. The man survived.
On 15 April 2025, a journalist with Debout RDC disappeared after leaving his home in an unspecified area of Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu). He left his house to go to the office but never arrived. Five days earlier, he had received threats from an individual claiming to be an army general. The caller 'promised the worst' and called him a 'traitor' and a 'Rwandan'. The journalist had been reporting on allegations of abuses committed by FARDC in the village of Ihusi in Sud-Kivu.
On 14 April 2025, overnight, ADF, using bladed weapons, killed 4 civilians (two men and two women) in Kokola/Kokola Urouro (Oicha, Beni, Nord-Kivu). They also looted shops and set fire to 4 houses and 1 motorbikes. Several civilians were disappeared and one was injured. Civil society said ADF circulate freely in the area and called onto FARDC to organize patrols.
On 14 April 2025, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a man (belonging to FARDC, according to unofficial sources) near Shari locality, closest to the town of Bunia (Baboa-Bakoe, Bunia, Ituri).
On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group abducted the customary chief in Munigi village (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). No further details.
On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group attacked a residence in Goma - Majengo (Goma, Nord-Kivu), killing 3 family members, and injuring one family. The Congolese authorities pointed at M23 and its strategy of creating terror in the urban places.
On 13 April 2025, ADF attacked and killed at least five people while they were working in their fields in Makembi, coded to Milindi (Beni-Mbau, Beni, Nord-Kivu) and Makembi (coded separately). 5 fatalities split into two events, coded as 3.
On 13 April 2025, ADF attacked and killed at least five people while they were working in their fields in Makembi, coded to Inango (Beni-Mbau, Beni, Nord-Kivu), and Milindi (coded separately). 5 split fatalities. Coded as two.
On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group abducted the customary chief in Burambo village (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). No further details.
On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group attacked Goma - Ndosho (Goma, Nord-Kivu), looting phones and money from several houses, and injuring seriously one man. The Congolese authorities point at M23 and its strategy of creating terror in the urban places.
On 12 April 2025, Mobondo abducted two civilians in their fields at an unspecified location 18 kilometers east of Menko village, located in Kwamouth territory, coded to territorial capital Kwamouth (Kwamouth, Mai-Ndombe).
On 11 April 2025, Mayi Mayi (Raiya Mutomboki) attacked a group of civilians, over a customary power conflict in Bakondjo groupment, in Bakano sector, coded to Itebero, chef-lieu of Bakano (Bakano, Walikale, Nord-Kivu). One of the community parties in conflict used the Raiya Mutomboki to detain the other party members. During the altercation, at least 5 people were shot, from whom, 2 died and 3 were injured, one of them in critical state. Later that night after the attack, three more people were abducted, and their whereabouts remain unknown (coded separately).
On 11 April 2025, a suspected FARDC shot and killed a man in the Bungulu commune of Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu), for unknown reasons.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 attacked Kibua (Walikale, Nord-Kivu), Kibati and Mikumbi (coded separately). In Kibua, the group killed at least 12 people, including two women. Most of them were beheaded or shot by guns. The group also tortured and injured the doctor chief of Kibua health zones and the Director of the General Hospital of Kibua at the Kibua General Hospital. They also looted medicines and supplies.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 attacked Kibati (Walikale, Nord-Kivu), Kibua and Mikumbi (coded separately). In Kibati, the group killed at least 4 people, including 3 men and one woman. Kibati is still under M23 control.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 - 20 April), M23 killed 2 people (one taxi driver and one farmer) in Kigoma (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). M23 also burned several houses. Two children drowned in a river and died while tying to flee these events.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 shot and killed two people (one man and one woman), and beheaded a father and his son in Mutakato (Mutakato I) (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). 4 fatalities.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 shot and killed three young men in Shabunda (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). They were shot when they returned to the village to get their belongings to flee.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 ambushed a man in Wenga, Utunda groupement (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The man was returning to the village to follow up on the security situation.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), M23 shot and killed a person in Kashebere (Masisi, Nord-Kivu), still occupied. One more person disappeared and his whereabouts are still unknown.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), an armed group (likely M23 due to the period being already during M23 occupation of the rural commune of Walikale) shot and killed four people in the rural entity of Walikale (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The red cross found the bodies.
Around 10 April 2025 (between 2 April - 20 April), an armed group (likely M23 as the period coincides with the M23 occupation of the rural commune of Walikale) abducted a woman and her child in Ngora, Utunda groupement (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). They were seen going to the hospital. Their whereabouts remain unknown.
On 8 April 2025, CODECO attacked two unspecified villages in the Nizi area, coded to Nizi (Mambisa, Djugu, Ituri). They set fire to houses and to gold miners' machines. Casualties unknown.
On 8 April 2025, the Angolan Armed Forces (FAC) attacked the Lundu-Matende Refugee Camp near Tshela (Tshela, Kongo Central), leaving 7 children injured. FLEC-FLAC accused forces of targeting civilians. Motivation unknown/not reported.
On 8 April 2025, Zaire militia beat and injured a journalist in Mabanga (Mambisa, Djugu, Ituri) and confiscated the media equipment while he was covering a local official's visit. The militia accused him of taking photos without permission.
On 7 April 2025, ADF attacked civilians in Kandoyi, coded to nearby Bandiboli (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri). No further details. Casualties unknown.
On 7 April 2025, ADF attacked civilians in Sokotano (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri). No further details. Casualties unknown.
On 7 April 2025, an armed group in military uniform (likely M23 due to their control over this area) killed a moto taxi driver, who infringed the restriction to have only one passenger per moto-taxi in Goma - Katoyi (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 7 April 2025, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a man in Kanyaruchinya Camp (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). The author and reasons of the assassination are unknown.
On 7 April 2025, Wazalendo shot at a suspected thief in Baraka (Mutambala, Fizi, Sud-Kivu). They accidentally shot at their motorbike driver instead, who was injured. It was unknown what happened to the suspected thief.
On 7 April 2025, an unidentified armed group killed a young woman in her residence in Goma - Ndosho (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The attackers and reasons of the assassination remained unknown.
On 7 April 2025, an armed group (likely M23 due to their control over this area) shot and killed a 20-year-old young man in Goma - Kyeshero (Goma, Nord-Kivu). His family denied the version that he was killed during a patrol operation.
Around 7 April 2025 (between 2 - 11 April), suspected ADF or ICCN eco-guards (likely ADF based on the location and context of the event) killed 'at least' 11 farmers in Mbongya (Ruwenzori, Beni, Nord-Kivu). The attackers abducted the group on 2 April (coded separately) and their bodies found on 11 April.
On 6 April 2025, ADF armed with machetes attacked civilians in an unspecified location in Bandavilemba groupement, coded to one of the villages in the groupement, Luna (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri). They killed 8 civilians.
On 5 April 2025, Wazalendo killed a moto taximan in Kandali (Fizi, Sud-Kivu), when stopped at a pay barrier. The attack suspectedly was a product of altercate between a convoy of Wazalendo who were drunk and insulted the victim, who responded before being shot.
On 5 April 2025, overnight, ADF killed at least 3 farmers with machete, and injured three others in an unspecified location in Mambasa, coded to Mambasa (Mambasa, Ituri). A massive displacement of population was observed towards Mambasa Center and Mayan.
Around 5 April 2025 (as reported), ADF militia killed at least 6 civilians around Mayangose (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu). It was suspected that the victims were part of a group of eleven farmers abducted a few days prior (coded separately).
On 4 April 2025, CODECO attacked Juli-Jina village, coded to the chef-lieu of the chiefdom, Risasi (Bahema-Baguru, Djugu, Ituri), looting and taking a local farmer as a hostage (coded separately). Casualties unknown.
On 4 April 2025, CODECO abducted a local farmer after looting 7 goats of his property in Juli-Jina village, coded to the chef-lieu of the chiefdom, Risasi (Bahema-Baguru, Djugu, Ituri). His whereabouts remain unknown.
On 4 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group killed at least 10 people in two houses, most of them from the same family and their neighbors in Kabale-Katambi village, coded as Rusayo groupement (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu). One of them was an ex-candidate to deputy in 2023.
On 4 April 2025, an unidentified armed group attacked Saint Andre de Mumosho parish, in Mumosho (Kabare, Sud-Kivu), injuring 2 people and looting several value goods. No fatalities. The reasons for this attack are unknown.
On 4 April 2025, ADF killed three farmers in Tikwabalele and five others in Abulembi, both coded to nearby Idohu (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri).
On 4 April 2025, overnight, at least 20 M23 entered an hospital and shot at suspected former combatants (IDPs according to other sources) who were refuged for several weeks at the hospital in Goma - Kyeshero (Goma, Nord-Kivu) and refused to leave. It is unclear if the targets were former M23 combatants or from other groups. One person was killed and three others were injured. Two hospital staff members were beaten.
On 3 April 2025, suspected M23 killed residents of a house and looted its contents in Goma - Mabanga Sud (Goma, Nord-Kivu). Unknown number of victims coded as 3.
On 3 April 2025, Wazalendo shot dead a phone seller at his shop in Walikale (Walikale, Nord-Kivu), over unknown reasons.
On 3 April 2025, M23 shot dead a civilian in Bukavu - Muhungu (Ibanda, Bukavu, Sud-Kivu), after he refused to show them his ID and phone.
Around 2 April 2025 (as reported), ADF militia abducted an unspecified number of civilians from the Kasabinyole quarter in Beni city (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The victims' whereabouts remain unknown.
On 2 April 2025, ADF militia abducted eleven farmers and set fire to five civilian houses and 3 motorbikes in Mayangose (Beni, Beni, Nord-Kivu). The victims' whereabouts remain unknown.
On 2 April 2025, suspected ADF or ICCN eco-guards (coded ADF based on the location and context of the event) abducted 'at least' 11 farmers in Mbongya (Ruwenzori, Beni, Nord-Kivu). The attackers also set on fire the farmers' huts and motorbikes. Their bodies of the adducted were found on 11 and 12 April (coded separately).

graphRAG_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, April 2025

**Armed Group Activities and New Formations:**
- **New Rebel Group Formation:** Former AFDL child soldier Innocent Kaina announced the creation of the CNLC (National Coalition for the Liberation of Congo) in Ituri, aiming to challenge existing rebel groups and FARDC (DRC35382).
- **M23 Withdrawals and Reinforcements:** M23 withdrew from Walikale in Nord-Kivu, citing a goodwill gesture ahead of peace talks (DRC35425). However, they reinforced positions in several areas, including Nyabiondo and Kasopo (DRC35667, DRC35695).
- **ADF Activities:** The ADF imposed illegal barriers and taxes in Ituri, affecting farmers and civilians (DRC35469, DRC35588, DRC35586, DRC35587, DRC35590).
- **Mayi Mayi Fimbo Disarmament:** The Mayi Mayi Fimbo group officially joined the voluntary disarmament program in Tanganyika (DRC35536).

**Government and Political Activities:**
- **Elections:** Governors and senate elections were held in Kwilu and Nord-Ubangi provinces (DRC35375, DRC35377).
- **Government Actions:** The Congolese government signed an agreement with M23 in Doha, Qatar, committing to a truce and ceasefire (DRC35656). The government also signed a declaration of principles with Rwanda to promote peace and economic development in the Great Lakes region (DRC35657).

**Security and Military Developments:**
- **FARDC and UPDF Operations:** UPDF established a base in Bule, Ituri, to support FARDC operations (DRC35403). FARDC defused explosive devices in Ituri and Nord-Kivu (DRC35464, DRC35584, DRC35643).
- **Mobondo Activities:** Mobondo overtook villages in Kwilu and imposed illegal barriers on national routes, causing displacement and economic disruption (DRC35423, DRC35645, DRC35779).

**Humanitarian and Social Issues:**
- **Displacement:** At least 10,000 refugees from South Sudan crossed into Aru territory in Ituri (DRC35794).
- **Looting and Property Destruction:** Various armed groups, including M23 and Mobondo, looted medical supplies, shops, and homes, and destroyed property in several provinces (DRC35492, DRC35621, DRC35636, DRC35640, DRC35743, DRC35744).
- **Economic Impact:** The closure of banks due to M23's occupation led to delays in paying school teachers' salaries in Nord-Kivu (DRC35648).

**International Involvement:**
- **SADC Withdrawal:** SAMIRDC troops began a phased withdrawal from Goma to South Africa, ending their mission in the DRC (DRC35741).
- **Evacuations:** Disarmed military and police forces, along with their families, were evacuated from Goma to Kinshasa with the help of MONUSCO and ICRC (DRC35756, DRC35771).

**Notable Events:**
- **Former President Kabila's Activities:** Former President Joseph Kabila was suspected of meeting with M23 officials in Goma, leading to restrictive measures by the DRC government (DRC35619).
- **Mass Grave Discovery:** The remains of five farmers killed by ADF were found in Matembwe village, Ituri (DRC35687).

These developments highlight the ongoing instability and strategic maneuvers by various armed groups and government forces in the DRC, with significant implications for security, humanitarian conditions, and regional politics.
simple_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, April 2025

**Military Movements and Withdrawals:**
- **M23 Activities:** M23 reinforced their positions in several key areas, including Kasheke, Tchofi, Nyabiondo, Kasopo, Luberike, and Kavumu, indicating a strategic consolidation of control (27, 27, 24, 22, 21, 20).
- **SAMIRDC Withdrawal:** SADC troops began a phased withdrawal from Goma, moving through Rwanda to Tanzania, and then to South Africa, completing the process by the end of May (27).
- **FARDC and Police Evacuations:** FARDC soldiers and Congolese Police, who had been under MONUSCO protection since M23 occupied Goma, were evacuated to Kitona military base for reintegration (30).

**Diplomatic and Political Developments:**
- **Peace Talks and Agreements:** The governments of Rwanda and DRC signed a 'declaration of principles' in Washington D.C., committing to respect sovereignty and find a peace agreement by 2 May 2025 (25).
- **M23 and Kinshasa Agreement:** M23 and the Congolese government reached an agreement in Doha, Qatar, pledging to work towards peace, including a truce and eventual ceasefire (23).

**Conflict and Violence:**
- **Clashes and Attacks:** Multiple clashes occurred between M23 and Wazalendo, FARDC, and other armed groups in various locations, including Walikale, Kalehe, and Sud-Kivu (7, 29, 26, 22, 22, 14, 13, 12, 7, 6, 3, 2).
- **Civilian Casualties:** There were reports of civilian casualties and property destruction in areas controlled by M23, including the destruction of houses and looting of medical supplies (23, 20, 14, 13, 10, 7, 4, 2).

**Economic and Social Impact:**
- **Looting and Extortion:** M23 and other armed groups established illegal barriers and revenue collection points, looting and extorting civilians and transporters (30, 25, 25, 20, 18, 17, 13, 9, 9, 9, 8, 8, 8, 8, 8, 7, 4, 2).
- **Displacement and Humanitarian Crisis:** The conflict led to significant displacement, with refugees from South Sudan crossing into DRC and local populations fleeing due to violence and insecurity (15, 13, 10, 7, 4).

**Security and Law Enforcement:**
- **Armed Group Activities:** Various armed groups, including ADF, CODECO, and Mayi Mayi factions, continued their operations, resulting in civilian abductions, killings, and property destruction (28, 24, 23, 22, 17, 13, 13, 13, 13, 12, 11, 8, 7, 7, 4, 2).
- **Government Response:** FARDC conducted raids on properties belonging to opposition figures and former President Kabila, and engaged in clashes with various armed groups (26, 17, 15, 13, 12, 11, 8, 7, 6, 4, 2).

**Humanitarian and Developmental Efforts:**
- **Evacuations and Aid:** MONUSCO and ICRC facilitated the evacuation of disarmed military and police forces and their families from Goma to Kinshasa (29).
- **Elections and Governance:** Governors and senate elections took place in Kwilu and Nord-Ubangi provinces, highlighting ongoing governance activities despite the conflict (2).

These strategic developments underscore the complex and volatile security situation in the DRC, with significant military movements, diplomatic efforts, and ongoing violence affecting civilian populations and regional stability.

Their final destination is Kitona military base in Kongo Central as part of their reintegration process.

On 29 April 2025, M23 armed group seized administrative control of Kaziba chiefdom, coded to the chiefdom capital Lwanguku (Kaziba, Walungu, Sud-Kivu), before heading for Luhwinja in the Mwenga territory. Unknown if clashes took place.
Other: Around 29 April 2025 (as reported), disarmed military and police forces, and their families, were evacuated from Goma (Goma, Goma, Nord-Kivu) to Kinshasa with the help of MONUSCO and ICRC. The individuals had been under MONUSCO protection since M23 occupied Goma (coded separately).
Movement of forces: On 29 April 2025, SAMIRDC troops started a progressive withdrawal phase through Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu) land border with Rwanda until Tanzania, and then by air or sea to South Africa. The process is planned to be completed by the end of May. SADC chiefs informed M23 that they would withdraw their entire equipment together with their personnel, without exception. SADC had decided to end its SAMIDRC mission in mid-March.
Property destruction: Around 28 April 2025 (as reported), Mobondo destroyed the Bandundu high-voltage transformer, located in Tobakita, coded to Bandundu (Bandundu, Kwilu). This caused a power cut in Bandundu for six days. Motivation unknown.
Movement of forces: On 27 April 2025, M23 reinforced their position in Kasheke (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). Residents said they saw 'five truckloads' of combatants arrive in Kasheke and Tchofi (coded separately) and that some arrived by boat from Rwanda.
Movement of forces: On 27 April 2025, M23 reinforced their position in Tchofi (Buhavu, Kalehe, Sud-Kivu). Residents said they saw 'five truckloads' of combatants arrive in Tchofi and Kasheke (coded separately) and that some arrived by boat from Rwanda.
Recruitment: Around 26 April 2025 (as reported), M23 were carrying out recruitment drives across Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The group created a 'recruitment committee' which organizes recruitment sessions in Goma's various neighborhoods.
Non-violent activity: On 26 April 2025, FARDC raided a farm belonging to leading opposition figure Moise Katumbi, Together for the Republic and former governor of Katanga, in Futuka (Kipushi, Haut-Katanga). This happened a week after a similar operation on properties belonging to the Kabila family in Kinshasa.
On 25 April 2025, the governments of Rwanda and DRC, following talks in Washington D.C., coded to Kinshasa (Kinshasa), signed a 'declaration of principles' to promote 'peace and economic development in the Great Lakes region'. The declaration included a commitment to respect 'sovereignty and established borders' and to find a peace agreement by 2 May 2025 . The talks were facilitated by the U.S. Secretary of State.
On 25 April 2025, M23 withdrew from Kibati (Wanianga, Walikale, Nord-Kivu) over unknown reasons. The territory was likely overtaken by Wazalendo due to their presence in the area. M23 retreated towards Kashebere.
Looting: On 25 April 2025, M23 looted the CENI and ANR (intelligence agency) office in Walungu (Ngweshe, Walungu, Sud-Kivu), as well as the home of Republican Guard commander.
Movement of forces: On 24 April 2025, M23 coming from Masisi town reinforced their positions in Nyabiondo (Osso, Masisi, Nord-Kivu).
Movement of forces: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), M23 reinforced their positions in Kibati (Wanianga, Walikale, Nord-Kivu).
Mass grave: On 24 April 2025, the remains of 5 farmers were found in Matembwe village, west of Biakato (Babila-Babombi, Mambasa, Ituri). The victims were killed by ADF in October 2024.
Movement of forces: On 24 April 2025, a Mayi Mayi Kifuafua faction led by Sango Makucha entered Malembe village (Wanianga, Walikale, Nord-Kivu); causing residents to flee as they feared a clash between this faction and another one led by Shukuru Bulenda.
On 23 April 2025, the Congolese government and M23 announced they reached an agreement pledging to work towards peace following talks in Doha (Qatar), coded to Kinshasa (Kinshasa). It is the first agreement between M23 and Kinshasa since M23 resumed its activism in 2021. The two parties committed to working towards a truce and an eventual ceasefire after negotiations; as well as 'dialogues on the deep roots of the crisis'.
Property destruction: Around 23 April 2025 (as reported), M23 destroyed civilians' houses in Mutaho (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), accusing their residents of helping provision Wazalendo stationed in Virunga National Park.
Property destruction: Around 23 April 2025 (as reported), M23 destroyed civilians' houses in Kalangala, Rusayo groupement (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), accusing their residents of helping provision Wazalendo stationed in Virunga National Park.
Property destruction: Around 23 April 2025 (as reported), M23 destroyed civilians' houses in Rukorwe (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), accusing their residents of helping provision Wazalendo stationed in Virunga National Park.

Movement of forces: Around 21 April 2025 (between 20 - 22 April), M23 reinforced their positions in Luberike groupement, coded to known village in groupement, Mikumbi (Wanianga, Wlaikale, Nord-Kivu).
Looting: On 20 April 2025, M23 withdrew from the area known as 'haut plateaux' of Kalehe, specifically in Kasheke (Kabare, Sud-Kivu). On 20 April 2025, M23 withdrew from Bushaku (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu), as well as from Kabamba, Bugamanda, Lemera and Kasheke (coded separately) along the Bukavu-Kalehe route.

On 20 April 2025, M23 withdrew from Lemera (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu) and from Kabamba, Bugamanda, Bushaku, and Kasheke (coded separately) along the Bukavu-Kalehe route.
On 20 April 2025, M23 withdrew from Kabamba, Bugamanda, and Kasheke, coded to Lemera (Kalehe, Sud-Kivu) and Lemera and Bushaku (coded separately) along the Bukavu-Kalehe route.
Property destruction: Around 20 April 2025 (as reported), M23 moved its troops toward Kavumu (Kabare, Sud-Kivu), causing property damage along the way. They also looted Kahuzi-Biega National Park (HQ) (coded separately).

The DRC government responded with a series of restrictive measures against Kabila and suspended his political party (PPRD). According to the government, Kabila is suspected of having directly participated in the M23 occupation. A source from M23 indicated that he left for Namibia.
Other: Around 19 April 2025, (weekend of), the local population discovered four unexploded devices in Kibua (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). Two were found in a parking area and two more near the general hospital of Kibua. These devices are suspected to belong to Wazalendo or M23. The local population complains that the FARDC covered some of the devices with soil and has not yet defused them.

Other: Around 19 April 2025 (as reported), M23 resumed small boat transportation on Lake Kivu, coded to Bukavu (Bukavu, Sud-Kivu) for the Goma-Bukavu-Goma route, with the company SNCC.

Other: Around 18 April 2025, the government of DRC completed four months without paying the salaries of school teachers in Rutshuru, Masisi, Goma, and Nyiragongo, coded to Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The most affected are the teachers paid by CARITAS - Goma. The reason for this delay is the closure of banks due to M23's occupation.
Looting: Around 18 April 2025 (as reported), one or more unidentified armed groups established illegal barriers in several segments of Ilebo territory, coded to Ilebo (Ilebo, Kasai).
Non-violent activity: Around 17 April 2025 (from 15 - 18 April), FARDC raided a property belonging to former president Joseph Kabila, in Kinshasa - Limete (Kinshasa). This happened a few days after Kabila said he would return to DRC and Congolese political life. FARDC seized 19 cars and electrical goods (generators, batteries, converters, solar panels) and said they were looking for stolen military equipment.
Defusal: On 17 April 2025, UNMAS defused 5 explosive devices found in the Fataki area, coded to Fataki (Walendu Djatsi, Djugu, Ituri). The explosives were found after the clashes that opposed CODECO and UPDF the month prior.

Non-violent activity: On 15 April 2025, ADF released six hostages (3 women and 3 women) in Mayangose (Beni, Nord-Kivu), who had been taken hostage the month prior. It is unknown why ADF released the hostages.
Looting: Around 15 April 2025 (month of), Mobondo began imposing illegal pay barriers on users of national route 17 (RN17) connecting Mongata and Bandundu, via Kabuba and Batsongo, coded to Batshongo (Kenge, Kwango). The local population also reports cases of abductions and extortions.
Displacement: Around 15 April 2025 (month of), at least 10,000 refugees from South Sudan crossed the South Sudan-DRC border into Aru territory, coded as Aru (Aru, Ituri), taken refuge in Kole, Okaba, and Olendere, fleeing violence in their country.
Property destruction: On 14 April 2025, M23 destroyed civilians' houses whom they suspected of having sheltered Wazalendo in Mutao locality, Kibati groupement (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), during an 'operation de ratissage' (combing operation).
Other: Around 13 April 2025 (as reported), ADF started forcing civilians to work on extracting gold for direct benefit of the armed group in Bapere (Lubero, Nord-Kivu), in exchange of not being attacked or killed. It is unclear if they actually pay to them for their work or not.
Looting: Around 13 April 2025 (as reported), ADF imposed illegal barriers in Bampulu groupement, coded to Ofai, main town of the same chiefdom (Walese Vonkutu, Irumu, Ituri) and Mandondo (coded separately). The fee requested is 10 USD for farmers to enter their own lands.
Looting: Around 13 April 2025 (as reported), ADF imposed illegal barriers in Mandondo, coded to Bahaha, main town of the same chiefdom (Babila Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri), and Bampulu (coded separately). The fee requested is 10 USD for farmers to enter their own lands.
Looting: Around 13 April 2025 (as reported), ADF started charging a set of taxes to residents of Bakwanza groupement, coded to administrative HQ Bakwanza (Babila Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri), an identification fee of 10 USD as well as a monthly fee of 30 USD.
Looting: On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group ransacked a boutique in Goma - Katoyi (Goma, Nord-Kivu), taking phones, money and diverse goods, and the motorcycle of the business owner. The Congolese authorities point at M23 and its strategy of creating terror in the urban places.
Training: On 13 April 2025, hundreds of new young volunteers enrolled in the FARDC and started their military training in Kamina (Kamina, Haut-Lomami).
Property destruction: On 13 April 2025, overnight, an unidentified armed group ransacked several houses in Goma - Kyeshero (Goma, Nord-Kivu). The Congolese authorities point at M23 and its strategy of creating terror in the urban places.
Other: On 11 April 2025, FARDC handed 41 former ADF hostages to the civil society in Beni (Beni, Nord-Kivu). The hostages were freed from the hands of the ADF following a joint collaboration between FARDC-UPDF. Among them, there are 13 women, three nationals from Burundi, and one from Uganda.
Defusal: On 9 April 2025, UNMAS and AFRILAM detonated at least 21 RPG-7 planted by an unidentified armed group at least a year prior in Boga (Baniari-Tchabi, Irumu, Ituri), near a FARDC camp.
Looting: Around 9 April 2025 (as reported), M23 erected a barrier in Mubambiro (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu), charging transporters and merchants a fee to pass through.
Looting: Around 9 April 2025 (as reported), M23 erected a barrier in Mushaki (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu), charging transporters and merchants a fee to pass through.
Looting: Around 9 April 2025 (as reported), M23 erected a barrier in Bihambwe (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu), charging transporters and merchants a fee to pass through.
Looting: Around 8 April 2025 (as reported), FARDC, police, intelligence police and the General Directorate of Migration agents erected illegal barriers across Kabalo territory, coded to territorial capital Kabalo (Kabalo, Tanganyika), where they charge civilians illegal taxes to pass through.
Looting: Around 8 April 2025 (as reported), FARDC extorted phones and money from civilians and forced fishers to hand over their fish to them in Kabomba (Kabimba, Kalemie).
On 8 April 2025, Mayi Mayi Fimbo (also known as Fimbo na Fimbo) officially joined the voluntary disarmament program in Tanganyika province, during a ceremony with FARDC in Mulange (Kalemie, Tanganyika).
Looting: On 8 April 2025, ADF started charging a $10 tax to farmers in the villages of Kadika and Andioka in Babila-Bakwanza chiefdom, coded to another village in Babila-Bakwanza, Masiliko (Mambasa, Ituri).
Movement of forces: On 8 April 2025, 'columns of heavily armed' M23 were sighted going from Kavumu and Bukavu towards Kabamba-Kalehe, coded to Kabamba (Kabare, Sud-Kivu).
Looting: On 8 April 2025, ADF imposed illegal barriers in Kadika et Andioka villages, coded to Bahaha, main town of the same chiefdom (Babila Bakwanza, Mambasa, Ituri). The fee requested is known as 'jeton', and equals to 10 USD for farmers to enter their own lands.
Looting: On 8 April 2025, overnight, suspected ADF entered Baungatsu Luna, in the Bambuba-Kisiki groupement, Ben-Mbau sector, coded to nearby Eringeti (Beni, Nord-Kivu) and looted several kiosks, along with some domestic animals.
Looting: Around 7 April 2025 (as reported), FARDC set up three illegal barriers on the Kirungu-Kasenga road, particularly in Kalongo, Kinsuli, and Kakera, coded to Kabongo (also spelled as Kalongo) (Moba, Tanganyika) and Kasenga (coded separately). According to the Deputy of Moba denouncing this harassment, anyone refusing to pay was subjected to 'physical violence'.
Other: Around 5 April 2025 (as reported), CODECO closed (means unspecified) the axis route Largu-Katoto, coded to Largu (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri), which impacts socio-economic activities, such as food provision to Bunia city.
Around 4 April 2025 (as reported), Mobondo overtook 11 villages (the following villages are named in reports: Lwono, Nselemwebi, Kipanki, Makomako, Mvulabango) from FARDC in the Kisyangasi cluster, coded to nearest possible location Mayala (Bagata, Kwilu). The militia installed a parallel administration and imposed taxes. Residents fled.
Looting: Around 4 April 2025, suspected M23 looted medical supplies and medicines from Mongazi and Kishanga Health Centers, and Kibua Hospital and from private pharmacies, all coded in Kibua (Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The looting took place after M23 withdrew from Walikale on 2 April.
Elections/referendum: On 2 April 2025, governs and senates elections took place in Kwilu province, coded to provincial capital Bandundu (Bandundu, Kwilu). The elections took place in the provincial assembly as MP are the voters.
Elections/referendum: On 2 April 2025, governors and senates elections took place in Nord-Ubangi province, coded to provincial capital Gbadolite (Gbadolite, Nord-Ubangi). The elections took place in the provincial assembly as MP are the voters.
Looting: On 2 April 2025, Wazalendo, with reinforcement from other Wazalendo in Oleka 2 and Zanzibar, looted small shopkeepers in Lubutu (Lubutu, Maniema), after police confiscated one of their motorbikes.
On 2 April 2025, M23 withdrew from Walikale town (Walikale, Nord-Kivu), which was then overtaken by Wazalendo the same day and FARDC the day after. M23 said the withdrawal was a 'goodwill gesture' ahead of planned peace talks.
Change to armed group: On 1 April 2025, former AFDL child soldier, and RCD/CNDP/M23 member Innocent Kaina announced the creation of a new rebel group called CNLC: National Coalition for the Liberation of Congo (Coalition Nationale pour la liberation du Congo) in Aveba (Walendu Bindi, Irumu, Ituri). Kaina did not rejoin M23 when the rebellion resumed in 2021 due to tensions with M23's military chief, Sultani Makenga. CNLC's objectives have yet to be announced.
Non-violent activity: On 1 April 2025, 'armed and hostile' Wazalendo marched in Alunguli commune, in the city of Kindu (Kindu, Maniema) while heading to the front. This forced schools and the market to close down. They chanted slogans against their provincial coordinator, a Senator, accusing him of having embezzled governmental funds.
On 1 April 2025, UPDF established their base in some quarters in Bule (Bahema-Badjere, Djugu, Ituri), in order to carry out future operations with their allies FARDC in the area.

graphRAG_summary:
### Conflict Early-Warning Brief: Key Battles in the Democratic Republic of Congo, April 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

1. **Sud-Kivu:**
   - **Wazalendo vs. M23:** Significant clashes occurred between Wazalendo and M23 in various locations, including Nyangezi, Bashuku, and Kavumu. Notable incidents include an ambush by Wazalendo on M23 reinforcements near Toyota, resulting in 20 fatalities (DRC35387). Wazalendo and M23 also clashed in Mudaka, with unspecified combatant fatalities (DRC35504).
   - **FDNB vs. Twirwaneho:** FDNB, supported by FARDC and Mayi Mayi Biloze Bishambuke, clashed with Twirwaneho in Rugezi and Kabanju, resulting in at least 17 fatalities (DRC35565, DRC35564).

2. **Nord-Kivu:**
   - **M23 vs. FARDC/Wazalendo:** Multiple clashes occurred between M23 and FARDC/Wazalendo in Goma, resulting in 52 fatalities according to government sources (DRC35566, DRC35567, DRC35568, DRC35569). Additional clashes were reported in Masisi and Walikale, with varying levels of casualties (DRC35370, DRC35373, DRC35376).
   - **Mayi Mayi vs. Other Militias:** Clashes between different Mayi Mayi factions and other militias were reported in Ibanga and other locations, resulting in 2 fatalities (DRC35654).

3. **Ituri:**
   - **CODECO vs. FARDC:** CODECO factions clashed with FARDC in Budu/Budhu and other locations, resulting in at least 16 fatalities (DRC35700). Additional clashes were reported in Tchumbu and Kparanganza, with varying levels of casualties (DRC35462, DRC35461).
   - **UPDF vs. CODECO:** UPDF attacked CODECO positions in the Arr groupement, resulting in the burning of houses and civilian displacement (DRC35646, DRC35647, DRC35696).

4. **Tanganyika:**
   - **Unidentified Armed Group vs. FARDC:** An unidentified armed group ambushed and killed 6 soldiers on the Kalemie-Kabimba road, abducting a Chinese national and a Congolese woman (DRC35726). Additional clashes occurred between the same group and FARDC, resulting in 5 fatalities (DRC35727).

5. **Kwilu:**
   - **FARDC vs. Mobondo:** FARDC clashed with Mobondo in Kabilaya, resulting in 19 fatalities, including 13 civilians killed by Mobondo (DRC35385).

6. **Other Notable Incidents:**
   - **CRP vs. FARDC:** CRP attacked a FARDC navy base in Joo, resulting in 11 fatalities (DRC35546).
   - **Chinese-Mining Site Attack:** An unidentified armed group attacked a Chinese-operated mining site in Tobola 1, resulting in 3 fatalities (DRC35725).

**Conclusion:**
April 2025 saw a significant escalation in armed conflicts across the Democratic Republic of Congo, with numerous clashes involving various militias, FARDC, and other armed groups. The conflicts resulted in substantial civilian casualties and displacement, highlighting the ongoing instability in the region.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Explosions/Remote Violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, April 2025

In April 2025, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) experienced several incidents of explosions and remote violence, primarily in the Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu provinces. These incidents involved both improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and military actions, resulting in civilian casualties and property damage.

**Key Developments:**

1. **Bikale Neighborhood, Sake (Masisi, Nord-Kivu):** On April 13, 2025, an explosive detonated in the Bikale neighborhood, killing two people and injuring three more. The explosion occurred after children discovered and played with the device (DRC35613).

2. **Bahunde, Sake (Masisi, Nord-Kivu):** On April 16, 2025, an unidentified explosive device planted by an armed group exploded, killing one child and seriously injuring three others. The children were collecting scrap metal at the time (DRC35612).

3. **ITIG Cemetery, Goma (Karisimbi, Nord-Kivu):** On April 26, 2025, a young shepherd stepped on an explosive device, killing the child and several of his goats. The device was planted by an unidentified armed group (DRC35760).

4. **Walikale (Nord-Kivu):** On April 2, 2025, FARDC military drones launched strikes targeting M23 positions. The strikes reportedly disrupted phone services, but casualties were unknown (DRC35374).

5. **Walikale (Nord-Kivu):** On April 9, 2025, a grenade planted by M23 was accidentally detonated by a farmer, seriously injuring him. Additional explosives were discovered in the area but did not detonate (DRC35494).

6. **RN2, Kasheke (Kabare, Sud-Kivu):** Around April 20, 2025, M23 detonated bombs and fired shots to intimidate the population and force them to stay indoors along the RN2 road. They also looted several houses (DRC35634).

7. **Kibirizi (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu):** On April 23, 2025, an explosive planted by an unidentified armed group detonated, injuring three teenagers (DRC35761).

These incidents highlight the ongoing security challenges in the DRC, particularly in the eastern provinces, where armed groups continue to use explosives to intimidate and harm civilians. The involvement of both local and unidentified armed groups underscores the need for heightened security measures and community awareness to mitigate the risks associated with explosive devices.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Protests in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary:**

In May 2025, several protests occurred across the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), primarily driven by grievances related to government inaction, judicial decisions, and labor disputes. These protests were largely peaceful and resulted in no reported fatalities.

- **Kinshasa (DRC35826):** On 8 May 2025, RTNC press agents protested in Kinshasa to denounce the government's inaction. The specific slogans and demands were not detailed.

- **Sud-Kivu (DRC36859):** On 9 May 2025, family members in Bukavu, Sud-Kivu, protested to enforce a court decision awarding them land in the Panzi and Essence neighborhoods.

- **Ituri (DRC36860):** On 12 May 2025, clerks of the Ituri Court of Appeal in Bunia protested their working conditions, including bonuses, salaries, promotions, and asset transfers. They also initiated an indefinite strike.

- **Tshopo (DRC36845):** On 14 May 2025, teaching inspectors in Kisangani, Tshopo, started a strike and protested the non-payment of their bonuses since 2018.

These events highlight underlying issues of governance, judicial enforcement, and labor conditions that could escalate if not addressed promptly. Continuous monitoring and engagement with affected groups are recommended to mitigate potential conflicts.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Protests in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

In May 2025, several significant protest events occurred in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), highlighting various grievances and tensions within different sectors of society.

1. **Educational Sector Strike and Protest:**
   - On 14 May 2025, teaching inspectors in Kisangani initiated a strike and protest, demanding the payment of bonuses that have been outstanding since 2018 (Event ID: 1).

2. **Judicial Sector Protest and Strike:**
   - On 12 May 2025, clerks of the Ituri Court of Appeal in Bunia protested against poor working conditions, including unpaid bonuses, salaries, promotions, and asset transfers. The clerks also launched an indefinite strike (Event ID: 2).

3. **Land Dispute Protest:**
   - On 9 May 2025, family members in Bukavu protested to enforce a court decision awarding them two plots of land in the Panzi and Essence neighborhoods (Event ID: 3).

4. **Media Sector Protest:**
   - On 8 May 2025, RTNC press agents in Kinshasa protested against government inaction, though specific details of their demands were not provided (Event ID: 4).

5. **Vigilante Violence:**
   - On 8 May 2025, a mob in Birava lynched two suspected thieves following an attempted robbery, burning their bodies afterward (Event ID: 5).

6. **Military Offensive:**
   - On 14 May 2025, the M23 rebel group launched an offensive against Wazalendo positions near Masisi, though the exact location and casualties remain unspecified (Event ID: 6).

7. **Armed Group Violence:**
   - Around 7 May 2025, an unidentified armed group killed a commercial motorbike rider near Goma, with suspicions that the victim was killed elsewhere and brought to the area (Event ID: 7).

These events underscore ongoing issues related to labor conditions, land disputes, vigilante justice, and armed conflict in various regions of the DRC.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Riots in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

In May 2025, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) experienced several incidents of riots, primarily characterized by mob violence and vigilante actions. These events were concentrated in the provinces of Haut-Uele, Nord-Kivu, Sud-Kivu, Kasai-Oriental, Haut-Katanga, Tshopo, and Ituri. Below is a summary of the key developments:

1. **Haut-Uele Province**:
   - On 12 May 2025, rioters burned alive five individuals accused of being bandits at the Camp Mbele mining site near Moku (DRC36890).
   - On 2 May 2025, residents killed a suspected thief at the trading center in Moku (DRC35746).

2. **Nord-Kivu Province**:
   - On 1 May 2025, residents caught and killed three suspected thieves in Goma, burning three alive and killing one while trying to escape (DRC35745).
   - On 9 May 2025, a mob burnt alive a suspected thief in Goma (DRC35828).

3. **Sud-Kivu Province**:
   - On 2 May 2025, a mob killed four civilians in Bukavu, believed to be a case of mob justice (DRC35787).
   - On 2 May 2025, residents killed two suspected thieves in Bukavu (DRC35747).
   - On 8 May 2025, a mob killed two suspected thieves in Birava (DRC35825).
   - On 9 May 2025, a mob burnt alive two suspected thieves in Kalehe (DRC35830).
   - On 12 May 2025, a mob burned alive two thieves in Miti (DRC36907).
   - On 6 May 2025, a resident mob lynched a suspected thief in Bukavu (DRC35812).
   - On 9 May 2025, a mob killed a suspected thief in Miti Kabare (DRC35829).

4. **Kasai-Oriental Province**:
   - Around 1 May 2025, relatives of a suspectedly assassinated candidate attacked and killed the local chief in Kabote, setting fire to 35 houses (DRC35782).

5. **Haut-Katanga Province**:
   - On 12 May 2025, artisanal miners rioted at the Shambara mine in Kawama village, vandalizing infrastructure and attacking employees (DRC36886).

6. **Tshopo Province**:
   - On 7 May 2025, a group of young people clashed with the Police in Kisangani, resulting in one fatality (DRC36911).

7. **Ituri Province**:
   - On 14 May 2025, a riot over boundary limits occurred between residents of Kalia and Ambu villages, resulting in injuries and property damage (DRC36893).

These incidents highlight a pattern of vigilante justice and community-driven violence, often in response to perceived criminal activities. The presence of mob violence and the lack of effective law enforcement in these regions contribute to the escalation of conflicts. Immediate intervention and strengthening of local law enforcement mechanisms are crucial to prevent further escalation and loss of life.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Riots in the Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

1. **Inter-Community Violence:**
   - On 14 May 2025, a riot over boundary limits occurred between residents of Kalia and Ambu villages in Aru territory, resulting in several injuries, 9 houses set on fire, and 2 kiosks destroyed and looted. (Event ID: 14 May 2025, Kalia-Ambu)

2. **Mining Sector Unrest:**
   - On 12 May 2025, artisanal miners rioted at the Shambara mine in Kawama village, vandalizing infrastructure and attacking employees. Security services arrested 30 rioters. (Event ID: 12 May 2025, Shambara Mine)

3. **Mob Justice Incidents:**
   - Multiple incidents of mob justice were reported, where suspected thieves and bandits were caught, beaten, and burned alive. These incidents occurred in various locations, including Miti, Camp Mbele, Goma, Kalehe, Birava, Bukavu, and Goma. (Event IDs: 12 May 2025, Miti; 12 May 2025, Camp Mbele; 9 May 2025, Goma; 9 May 2025, Miti Kabare; 9 May 2025, Kalehe; 8 May 2025, Birava; 7 May 2025, Bukavu; 6 May 2025, Bukavu; 2 May 2025, Moku; 2 May 2025, Bukavu; 2 May 2025, Bukavu; 1 May 2025, Goma)

4. **Political and Ethnic Clashes:**
   - On 5 May 2025, clashes between Wazalendo and M23 resulted in fatalities in Walungu, Sud-Kivu. (Event ID: 5 May 2025, Walungu)
   - Around 1 May 2025, relatives of a suspectedly assassinated candidate attacked and killed the local chief in Kabote, setting fire to 35 houses. (Event ID: 1 May 2025, Kabote)

5. **Military and Security Forces Involvement:**
   - On 9 May 2025, FARDC soldiers shot randomly in Zongo, suspectedly in retaliation for the death of a colleague. (Event ID: 9 May 2025, Zongo)
   - On 13 May 2025, M23 arrested over a hundred residents in Ngangi II and Ngangi III, detaining those suspected of affiliations with FARDC or Wazalendo. (Event ID: 13 May 2025, Ngangi II and Ngangi III)
   - Around 3 May 2025, clashes between M23 and Wazalendo in Rushege resulted in population displacement. (Event ID: 3 May 2025, Rushege)
   - On 14 May 2025, M23 clashed with Wazalendo in Tchofi, Sud-Kivu. (Event ID: 14 May 2025, Tchofi)
   - On 4 May 2025, CRP attacked FARDC in Nyamamba, Ituri, resulting in several fatalities. (Event ID: 4 May 2025, Nyamamba)

6. **Displacement and Humanitarian Concerns:**
   - Around 3 May 2025, a massive movement of population was observed from Musenda, Kisaka, and Katundu following the occupation of Lunyasenge. (Event ID: 3 May 2025, Musenda)
   - Around 10 May 2025, M23 carried out operations to extract individuals suspected of being FARDC or Wazalendo members, resulting in the detention of at least 181 individuals. (Event ID: 10 May 2025, Goma and Nyiragongo)

**Conclusion:**
The Democratic Republic of Congo experienced a series of riots and violent incidents in May 2025, driven by inter-community tensions, mining sector unrest, mob justice, and political and ethnic clashes. These events highlight ongoing security challenges and the need for immediate intervention to prevent further escalation and humanitarian crises

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Violence Against Civilians in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

In May 2025, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) experienced a series of violent incidents targeting civilians, primarily in the provinces of Nord-Kivu, Ituri, and Kongo-Central. The violence was perpetrated by various armed groups, including the Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), CODECO, M23, and unidentified armed groups, as well as by members of the Congolese Armed Forces (FARDC) and police.

**Key Events:**

1. **Nord-Kivu:**
   - On 8 May, suspected ADF militia killed 18 civilians in Fungula village and 6 in Maseme village, leading to significant population displacement towards Njiapanda (DRC36870, DRC35824).
   - On 5 May, an unidentified armed group killed six people in Goma (DRC35806).
   - On 12 May, unidentified individuals, likely M23, burned alive four members of the same family in Kabale Katambi (DRC36880).
   - On 13 May, M23 shot dead two civilians in Kibati (DRC36864).
   - Throughout the month, M23 conducted large-scale operations, extracting hundreds of individuals from their homes in various locations, including Goma and Nyiragongo, to search for alleged FARDC and Wazalendo members (DRC36909, DRC36910, DRC36914, DRC36915, DRC36916, DRC36917, DRC36918, DRC36919, DRC36920, DRC36921, DRC36922, DRC36923, DRC36924, DRC36925).

2. **Ituri:**
   - On 9 May, CODECO killed four gold miners near Berunda (DRC36857).
   - On 14 May, Zaire attacked civilians in Tsenga village, killing three people, including two children (DRC36856).
   - On 12 May, ADF attacked civilians in Kyamata, killing the village chief (DRC36862).
   - On 14 May, CODECO ambushed internally displaced persons (IDPs) in Lenge village, killing an elderly man and looting goats (DRC36863).

3. **Kongo-Central:**
   - On 11 May, a FARDC soldier shot and killed three people, including a four-month-old infant, during a church service in Moanda (DRC36867).

4. **Kinshasa:**
   - On 9 May, Congolese police officers killed a 3-year-old child in unclear circumstances (DRC36865).

5. **Sud-Ubangi:**
   - On 9 May, FARDC soldiers shot randomly in Zongo, injuring a little girl with a stray bullet (DRC36879).

6. **Mai-Ndombe:**
   - On 7 May, a FARDC soldier shot a young man in Ngambomi village, leaving him in critical condition (DRC36877).

**Conclusion:**

The violence in May 2025 highlights the ongoing insecurity and human rights abuses in the DRC, particularly in the eastern regions. The actions of armed groups and security forces have resulted in significant civilian casualties and displacement, necessitating urgent humanitarian and security interventions.
simple_summary:
### Summary of Key Developments: Violence Against Civilians in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Key Events:**

1. **Zaire and CODECO Attacks:**
   - On 14 May, Zaire attacked civilians in Tsenga village, killing three people, including two children. The attack may have been a clash between Zaire and CODECO (Event ID: 1).
   - On 14 May, CODECO ambushed IDPs in Lenge village, killing an elderly man and looting 40 goats (Event ID: 2).
   - On 9 May, CODECO killed four gold miners near Berunda (Event ID: 30).

2. **M23 Operations:**
   - On 13 May, M23 shot dead two civilians in Kibati during an arrest operation (Event ID: 3).
   - M23 conducted mass arrests in Goma and Sake from 10-13 May, targeting suspected FARDC and Wazalendo members (Event IDs: 4-11).
   - On 12 May, unidentified individuals (likely M23) burned alive four family members in Kabale Katambi (Event ID: 12).
   - On 10 May, M23 launched a large-scale operation to extract individuals from their homes in multiple locations, detaining at least 300 people (Event IDs: 13-24).

3. **ADF Attacks:**
   - On 12 May, ADF attacked civilians in Kyamata, killing the village chief and setting houses on fire (Event ID: 14).
   - On 8 May, ADF killed six civilians in Maseme village and 18 in Fungula village (Event IDs: 25, 26).
   - On 7 May, ADF attacked civilians in Mambembe neighborhood, killing one and burning houses (Event ID: 28).
   - On 3 May, ADF killed two civilians in Kili and burned their motorcycles (Event ID: 34).

4. **FARDC Incidents:**
   - On 11 May, a FARDC soldier shot and killed three people, including a four-month-old infant, during a church service in Moanda (Event ID: 15).
   - On 9 May, FARDC soldiers shot randomly in Zongo, injuring a little girl (Event ID: 29).
   - On 7 May, a FARDC soldier shot a young man in Ngambomi village (Event ID: 31).
   - On 1 May, FARDC clashed with Wazalendo in Kakombe, with unspecified civilian injuries (Event ID: 39).

5. **Other Armed Groups and Mob Violence:**
   - On 10 May, unidentified armed groups shot and injured several people in Goma (Event IDs: 16-19).
   - On 9 May, a mob killed a suspected thief in Miti Kabare (Event ID: 32).
   - On 8 May, a mob killed two suspected thieves in Birava (Event ID: 33).
   - On 9 May, a mob burned alive a suspected thief in Goma (Event ID: 37).
   - On 1 May, residents burned alive three suspected thieves in Goma (Event ID: 40).

6. **Civil Unrest and Displacement:**
   - On 14 May, a riot over boundary limits occurred between Kalia and Ambu villages, injuring several people and destroying property (Event ID: 35).
   - On 12 May, rioters burned alive five people accused of being bandits at Camp Mbele mining site (Event ID: 36).
   - On 3 May, a significant influx of refugees was observed in Zapai locality, fleeing conflict (Event ID: 38).
   - On 12 May, suspected ADF looted over 400 cows in Boloku (Event ID: 41).
   - On 12 May, a mob burned alive two thieves in Miti (Event ID: 42).

**Conclusion:**
The month of May 2025 saw a significant escalation in violence against civilians in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with multiple armed groups, including Zaire, CODECO, M23, ADF, and FARDC, involved in attacks, mass arrests, and clashes. Civil unrest and mob violence also contributed to the instability, leading to civilian casualties, displacement, and property destruction. The situation remains volatile, with ongoing conflicts and the potential for further escalation.

On 14 May 2025, Zaire attacked civilians in Tsenga village, located in Jiba health zone, coded to Jiba (Walendu-Pitsi, Djugu, Ituri). Three people, including two children, were killed. Sources mention the attack could also have been a clash between Zaire and CODECO.
On 14 May 2025, CODECO ambushed IDPs who were looking for food in Lenge village, coded to nearby Bule (Bahema-Badjere, Djugu, Ituri). The IDPs were coming from their site in Tsukpa. CODECO killed an elderly man. 3 other people were disappeared and 40 goats were looted.
On 13 May 2025, M23 shot dead two civilians in Kibati (Wanianga, Walikale, Nord-Kivu). The killing occurred as M23 was arresting a group of 4 people, two of whom tried to escape, which is when they were shot dead. The other two are still missing.
On 13 May 2025, for the fourth consecutive day, M23 continued its mass arrest operation in various unspecified neighborhoods in Goma (Goma, Nord-Kivu) and Sake (coded separately). M23 said the goal of the operation was to tackle insecurity. It is unknown how many people were arrested on 13 May.
On 13 May 2025, for the fourth consecutive day, M23 continued its mass arrest operation in Sake (Bahunde, Masisi, Nord-Kivu) as well as Goma (coded separately). M23 said the goal of the operation was to tackle insecurity. It is unknown how many people were arrested on 13 May.
On 13 May 2025, M23 arrested over a hundred residents in Ngangi II (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu) and Ngangi III (coded separately). M23 searched houses and arrested people based off suspicions of affiliation with FARDC or Wazalendo, because they did not have IDs, or because of their hairstyle. All arrested were brought to Don Bosco stadium, where those able to prove their 'innocence' were released while others were brought to an unknown destination.
On 13 May 2025, M23 arrested over a hundred residents in Ngangi III (Bukumu, Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu) and Ngangi II (coded separately). M23 searched houses and arrested people based off suspicions of affiliation with FARDC or Wazalendo, because they did not have IDs, or because of their hairstyle. All arrested were brought to Don Bosco stadium, where those able to prove their 'innocence' were released while others were brought to an unknown destination.
On 12 May 2025, overnight, ADF attacked civilians in Kyamata (Baniari-Tchabi, Irumu, Ituri). They killed the village chief, set two houses on fire and looted goods.
On 12 May 2025, unidentified individuals (likely M23, due to the 'bouclage' operation carried during this period) burned alive four members of the same family in Kabale Katambi, in Rusayo groupement, coded to Rusayo (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu) for unknown reasons.
On 11 May 2025, a FARDC soldier shot and killed three people during a service at a Christian church in Moanda (also spelled as Muanda) (Moanda, Kongo-Central), including a four-month-old infant. The reasons for the attack are unclear. The soldier was detained by the community and handed over to military justice for judgment.
Around 10 May 2025 (weekend of), an unidentified armed group shot and injured two people in Goma - Mabanga Nord (Goma, Nord-Kivu), recorded as two separate events in the same location. In both instances, the perpetrators were using a motorcycle. In one incident, the unidentified armed individuals shot a female pharmacist as she left her pharmacy.
Around 10 May 2025 (weekend of), an unidentified armed group on a motorcycle shot and injured two individuals in Goma - Mabanga Nord (Goma, Nord-Kivu), categorized as two separate incidents in the same location. On 10 May 2025, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a young man at his home in Goma - Ndosho (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Around 10 May 2025, an unidentified armed group shot and seriously injured four people under unclear circumstances in Goma - Katoyi (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
Around 10 May 2025 (weekend of), M23 carried out an operation to extract at least 300 people from their homes (4,000 according to a Ministry of Interior report), suspectedly looking for FARDC and Wazalendo members in Rukoko (Nyiragongo, Nord-Kivu), and Kiheru, Murambi, Ngangi 1 and 2, Ndosho, Mugunga, Kyeshero, Katoyi, Majengo, Lac Vert, Sake, Kimoka, Munigi and Mutsa (coded separately). After apprehending the targeted individuals, who are mostly young men, they brought them to Kibumba and inspect their ID cards, tattoos, and physical condition to determine whether they are FARDC-Wazalendo members. Only a few people have been released, while the rest are still missing. At least 181 of those retained are of Rwandan nationality in an irregular migration status.

Around 7 May 2025 (as reported), a FARDC soldier shot a young man at point-blank range in Ngambomi village, coded to the provincial capital, Kwamouth (Plateaux, Kwamouth, Mai-Ndombe). He is currently hospitalized in critical condition.

MONUSCO pushed back the armed group, assisting the injured civilians and avoiding a potential massacre.
On 5 May 2025, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a civilian at the Bleu-band traffic circle in Butembo - Mukuna (Butembo, Nord-Kivu).
On 5 May 2025, an unidentified armed group killed six people, three young women from the same family at their residence, and three people from another family in Goma - Bujovu (Goma, Nord-Kivu).
On 3 May 2025, an unidentified armed group killed 2 civilians (a taxi motorbike rider and client) in Kili, closest to Lubero (Baswaga, Lubero, Nord-Kivu). The attackers also burned the victims' motorcycles before fleeing. Other passengers escaped into the bush.
Around 1 May 2025 (as reported), suspected Mobondo militia attacked civilians in Ibi area, closest to Mbankana (Maluku, Kinshasa, Kinshasa). A woodcutter was killed, and an employee of Acadec NGO was seriously injured.

graphRAG_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Key Strategic Developments:**

1. **Military Movements and Reinforcements:**
   - **M23 Activities:** M23 reinforced its troops and logistics in Kashebere, Nord-Kivu (DRC35786). The group also seized control of several strategic areas in Sud-Kivu, including Kabalole, Luduha, Luwinja, Lwashanja, and Idudwe, without clashes (DRC35784, DRC35785, DRC35815, DRC35816, DRC35817). M23 issued a seven-day ultimatum for the surrender of FARDC and Wazalendo forces in Walungu territory (DRC36905).
   - **FARDC Movements:** FARDC deployed reinforcements to the Kalemie-Kabimba axis road in Tanganyika following an ambush (DRC35773). FARDC regrouped in Kyavinyonge, Nord-Kivu, to reorganize its troops (DRC35835). FARDC also deployed to Kyavinyonge due to the expansion of M23 (DRC36895).
   - **Joint Operations:** A delegation of FARDC-UPDF arrived in Tchomia, Ituri, as part of collective efforts against armed groups (DRC35807).

2. **Displacements and Humanitarian Concerns:**
   - **Massive Displacements:** Significant population movements were observed from various locations in Nord-Kivu, including Katungu, Kisaka, Musenda, and Lunyasenge, due to the occupation of Lunyasenge (DRC35765, DRC35767, DRC35769, DRC35795). Hundreds of people fled to the central prison of Masisi Center (DRC35770).
   - **Refugee Influx:** Approximately 15,200 refugees from the Central African Republic arrived in Bas-Uele province (DRC36912).

3. **Looting and Extortion:**
   - **Extortion and Looting:** Wazalendo youth extorted and threatened civilians in Kindu, Maniema (DRC35742). Suspected ADF imposed taxes on farmers in Babila-Babombi chiefdom, Ituri (DRC35811). Suspected FDLR looted Buramba locality in Nord-Kivu (DRC36883). An unidentified armed group looted construction materials in Sud-Kivu (DRC36892).

4. **Political and Diplomatic Efforts:**
   - **Government Agreements:** The DRC and Rwanda submitted an agreement proposition to the U.S. Government, with planned harmonization meetings and finalization in June (DRC35768).
   - **Political Suspensions:** The Congolese government suspended the activities of ADCP, MLP, and UPC political parties, accusing them of supporting M23 (DRC36894).

5. **Security Measures:**
   - **Curfews and Restrictions:** A group, likely M23, set up a curfew in Goma-Ndosho due to worsening security (DRC36913). M23 suspended the activities of some civil society organizations in Kamanyola, Sud-Kivu (DRC36891).
   - **FARDC Actions:** FARDC gave Mbororo pastoralists 21 days to register in Nambia, Haut-Uele, threatening a large-scale operation against non-compliant individuals (DRC36887).

6. **Other Incidents:**
   - **Accidental Detonation:** CMC Nyatura militia accidentally detonated an RPG in Bambu, Nord-Kivu, resulting in 4 fatalities and 7 injuries (DRC35808).
   - **Road Blockades:** Mobondo militia blocked the RN17 road near Kinsele, Mai-Ndombe, preventing free movement (DRC35758).

These developments highlight ongoing conflicts, strategic movements, and humanitarian crises in various regions of the DRC, necessitating continued monitoring and potential intervention.
simple_summary:
### Strategic Developments in the Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Political and Diplomatic Developments:**
- The Congolese government suspended the activities of three political parties—ADCP, MLP, and UPC—accusing them of supporting the M23 rebel group. This move indicates a heightened effort to curb political opposition and perceived external influences (Event ID: 2025051501).
- The governments of the DRC and Rwanda submitted an agreement proposition to the U.S. government, aiming to finalize the agreement by June 2025. This diplomatic effort suggests a push for regional stability and cooperation (Event ID: 2025050501).

**Military and Security Developments:**
- The Congolese Armed Forces (FARDC) deployed troops to Kyavinyonge in response to the expansion of M23 activities, indicating a strategic move to counter rebel advances (Event ID: 2025051502).
- M23 shot down a FARDC drone in Walungu, highlighting the group's capability to challenge government surveillance and control (Event ID: 2025051503).
- FARDC gave Mbororo pastoralists a deadline to register, threatening a large-scale operation against those who do not comply, reflecting efforts to control and monitor local populations (Event ID: 2025051002).
- M23 issued a seven-day ultimatum for the surrender of FARDC and Wazalendo forces in Walungu, threatening to capture those who do not comply, demonstrating the group's aggressive stance (Event ID: 2025050901).
- M23-AFC seized control of several strategic areas rich in gold, including Kabalole, Luduha, Lwashanja, and Idudwe, indicating a push to secure resource-rich territories (Event IDs: 2025050601, 2025050602, 2025050604, 2025050605).
- M23 reinforced its troops and logistics in Kashebere, suggesting preparations for further military operations (Event ID: 2025050202).
- FARDC regrouped in Kyavinyonge to reorganize its troops, indicating efforts to strengthen military capabilities in response to rebel activities (Event ID: 2025050303).

**Humanitarian and Civilian Impact:**
- Massive displacements were observed from various locations, including Lunyasenge, Katungu, Musenda, and Kisaka, due to the occupation by armed groups and subsequent conflicts. These strategic developments underscore the complex and volatile security situation in the

simple_summary:
### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Key Battles in the Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

1. **M23 vs. Wazalendo (CMC-FDP) Clashes:**
   - **Bambu/Bambo (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu):** M23 and Wazalendo engaged in intense clashes over three consecutive days (14-16 May). Wazalendo regained control, pushing M23 back towards Kabizo/Butare. Six people were killed, and the MSF-supported hospital treated over 20 injured individuals (Event IDs: 1, 2, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16).
   - **Showa, Ngwaki, and Lwansihe (Osso, Masisi, Nord-Kivu):** Clashes occurred on 15 May, with unknown casualties (Event IDs: 3, 4, 5).
   - **Tchofi, Kasheke, Kabamba, and Mabingu (Sud-Kivu):** Multiple clashes on 14 May with unknown casualties (Event IDs: 6, 7, 8, 9).
   - **Kishishe/Kishishi (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu):** M23 overtook control on 14 May, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 17).
   - **Katasomwa (Buhavu, Kalehe, Sud-Kivu):** Wazalendo pushed M23 back towards Kasheke and Tchofi on 13 May, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 18).

2. **Zaire vs. FARDC Clashes:**
   - **Tsiku and Katoto (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri):** Zaire, supported by CRP, clashed with FARDC on 15 May. One FARDC soldier was injured, and MONUSCO deployed to protect civilians (Event IDs: 10, 11).
   - **Lopa Town (Bahema-Nord, Djugu, Ituri):** Zaire-CRP coalition attacked FARDC positions on 15 May, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 19).

3. **Other Significant Battles:**
   - **Lubutu (Lubutu, Maniema):** Wazalendo (Mayi Mayi Simba) clashed with FARDC overnight on 14 May over a misunderstanding, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 20).
   - **Kibabi and Ufamandu (Masisi, Nord-Kivu):** M23 clashed with PARECO/FF and Kifuwa-fuwa on 11 May, causing massive displacement (Event IDs: 21, 22).
   - **Kamiro 1 (Aru, Ituri):** An unidentified armed group attacked a military position on 10 May, injuring a DGM Migration agent and burning five houses (Event ID: 23).
   - **Luchiga and Lwashanja (Walungu, Sud-Kivu):** M23 overtook control on 6 May, with unknown casualties (Event IDs: 24, 25).
   - **Katungu (Lubero, Nord-Kivu):** M23 overtook control on 4 May, causing significant displacement (Event ID: 26).
   - **Kipabashi (Beni, Nord-Kivu):** An unidentified armed group clashed with UPLC on 3 May, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 27).
   - **Kashovu (Masisi, Nord-Kivu):** Wazalendo and FARDC clashed with M23 and Rwandan forces on 2 May, with unknown casualties (Event ID: 28).
   - **Lunyasenge (Lubero, Nord-Kivu):** M23 overtook control on 2 May, causing massive displacement (Event ID: 29).

4. **Other Incidents:**
   - **Goma and Sake (Nord-Kivu):** M23 continued mass arrests on 13 May, aiming to tackle insecurity (Event ID: 30).
   - **Kinshasa:** The Congolese government suspended the activities of ADCP, MLP, and UPC political parties on 15 May, accusing them of supporting M23 (Event ID: 31).
   - **Kyamata (Irumu, Ituri):** ADF attacked civilians on 12 May, killing the village chief and looting goods (Event ID: 32).

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Explosions/Remote Violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary:**

In May 2025, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) experienced several incidents of explosions and remote violence, primarily in the Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu provinces. These incidents highlight ongoing security challenges and the presence of various armed groups in the region.

**Key Developments:**

1. **Nord-Kivu Province:**
   - On 5 May 2025, a rocket explosion in the market of Bambu (Bwito, Rutshuru) resulted in the deaths of four individuals, including two women and a young child. Seven others were injured. The explosion occurred near a former police office occupied by the EPLC Wazalendo/CMC Nyatura militia, with a militia member suspected of mishandling the rocket (DRC35834).
   - On the same day, an Improvised Explosive Device (IED) planted by suspected ADF militia detonated on the Matuna-Kambau stretch in Kambau (Bapere, Lubero), injuring three civilians who were returning from their fields (DRC35810).

2. **Sud-Kivu Province:**
   - On 15 May 2025, the Congolese Armed Forces (FARDC) conducted a drone strike on Twirwaneho bases in Mikenge (Itombwe, Mwenga). The exact number of casualties from this operation remains unknown (DRC36899).

**Conclusion:**

The incidents in May 2025 underscore the persistent security threats in the DRC, particularly in the eastern provinces of Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu. The involvement of various armed groups, including the EPLC Wazalendo/CMC Nyatura and ADF militia, along with military operations by the FARDC, indicate a volatile security environment. Continued monitoring and conflict resolution efforts are essential to mitigate further violence and civilian casualties.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Explosions/Remote Violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, May 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

1. **Aerial Attack by FARDC:**
   - On 15 May 2025, the Congolese Armed Forces (FARDC) conducted a drone bombing on Twirwaneho bases in Mikenge, Itombwe, Mwenga, Sud-Kivu. Casualties are unknown (Event ID: 1).

2. **IED Attack by Suspected ADF Militia:**
   - On 5 May 2025, an improvised explosive device (IED) planted by suspected Allied Democratic Forces (ADF) militia detonated on the Matuna-Kambau stretch in Bapere, Lubero, Nord-Kivu. The explosion injured three civilians returning from their fields (Event ID: 2).

3. **Market Explosion in Bambu:**
   - On 5 May 2025, a rocket exploded in a market in Bambu (Bwito, Rutshuru, Nord-Kivu), resulting in the deaths of four people, including two women and a young child, and injuring seven others. The explosion occurred near a former police office occupied by the EPLC Wazalendo/CMC Nyatura militia, with a muzalendo militia member suspected of mishandling the rocket (Event ID: 3).

4. **Mob Violence:**
   - Around 9 May 2025, a mob attacked and killed a suspected thief in Miti Kabare, Kabare, Sud-Kivu (Event ID: 4).

5. **Clashes Between FARDC and M23:**
   - On 1 May 2025, FARDC forces clashed with the M23 rebel group on the hills above Uvira, Sud-Kivu. Casualties are unknown (Event ID: 5).

6. **M23 Advances:**
   - On 6 May 2025, the M23 rebel group clashed with the Wazalendo militia and overtook the areas of Luchiga and Lwashanja in Luhwinja chiefdom, Walungu, Sud-Kivu. The region is rich in minerals, particularly gold. Casualties are unknown (Event ID: 6).

**Conclusion:**
The month of May 2025 saw significant incidents of remote violence and clashes in the Democratic Republic of Congo, particularly in the eastern provinces of Nord-Kivu and Sud-Kivu. These events highlight ongoing conflicts involving various armed groups and the FARDC, with potential implications for civilian safety and regional stability.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Protests in Sudan, January 2025

**Summary:**
In January 2025, Sudan experienced two notable protest incidents. On January 24, residents in El Obeid, North Kordofan, staged a protest against US sanctions imposed on the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) commander (SUD33007). This protest was peaceful with no reported fatalities. On January 31, residents in Kambo, a settlement housing migrant workers near Al Kiremit in Al Jazirah, protested against a decision to build a fuel station on land they intended to use for constructing a school (SUD33278). This protest also remained non-violent with no reported fatalities.

**Key Points:**
- **Protest Locations:** El Obeid, North Kordofan; Kambo, Al Jazirah.
- **Protest Themes:** Political sanctions, land use disputes.
- **Outcomes:** Both protests were peaceful with no reported fatalities.
