Other: On 6 March 2025, the Canadian ministry of foreign affairs imposed sanctions on SAF commander-in-chief and Sudan head of state Abdel Fattah Al Burhan, and RSF commander Mohammed Hamdan Dagalo, due to their role in the violation of human rights during the SAF-RSF war (location coded to state capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum) and their refusal to agree to a permanent ceasefire.
Around 5 March 2025 (as reported), SAF regained control from RSF over Al Huda (Sharg An Neel, Khartoum) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). It is unclear if there were clashes.
Looting: On 5 March 2025, an RSF group (which claimed their relatives were assassinated in the frontlines) looted civilians phones and Starlink devices in Cinema street and Al Wadi neighborhood in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur).
Other: On 4 March 2025, a court in the White Nile issued a life sentence against a suspect due to violation of articles 26-50-51 of the Sudanese Criminal Law in Kosti (Kosti, White Nile), after they were accused of being RSF.
Looting: Around 4 March 2025 (between 3 March - 5 March), RSF looted civilians' belongings in blocks 1 and 3 of Khartoum - Eid Hussain (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum) and forced them to leave their homes at gunpoint in retaliation to an RSF member's body being found in the area on 3 March (unclear if he was killed by residents).
On 4 March 2025, RSF and allied armed and political figures (including members of NUP and DUP, whose groups claim they do not represent them), SPLM-N-Abdelaziz, SLM/A-Transitional Council, and GSLF signed a draft transitional constitution during a meeting in Nairobi, Kenya (location coded to state capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum). The draft constitution stipulated secularism, decentralization, dividing the country into 8 regions, and the formation of a new national army (the RSF and allies signed an agreement on 22 February to form a parallel government in RSF-controlled regions - coded separately).
Around 3 March 2025 (as reported), SPLM-N-Abdelaziz backed by RSF took control from SPLM-N-Agar (SAF allied) over Tanfona (Al Kurmuk, Blue Nile), unclear if there were clashes.
Around 3 March 2025 (as reported), SPLM-N-Abdelaziz backed by RSF took control from SPLM-N-Agar (SAF allied) over El Foj (Bau, Blue Nile), unclear if there were clashes.
Around 3 March 2025 (as reported), SPLM-N-Abdelaziz backed by RSF took control from SPLM-N-Agar (SAF allied) over Malkan (Bau, Blue Nile), unclear if there were clashes.
On 3 March 2025, SAF and Abu Tira regained control from RSF over the Abu Tira HQ in an unspecified location in Sharg An Neel (location coded to locality capital Ed Babkir, Sharg An Neel, Khartoum) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). It is unclear if there were clashes.
Around 3 March 2025 (as reported), SAF regained control from RSF over Al Kariab (Sharg An Neel, Khartoum) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). It is unclear if there were clashes.
Around 3 March 2025 (as reported), SPLM-N-Abdelaziz backed by RSF took control from SPLM-N-Agar (SAF allied) over El Tibilab (location coded to locality capital Bau, Blue Nile). It is unclear if there were clashes.
Security measures: On 2 March 2025, the governor amended the curfew period within the state from 12 am until 5 am across Northern state (location coded to state capital Dongola, Dongola, Northern), during the Ramadan holy month.
Movement of forces: Around 2 March 2025 (as reported), SAF deployed reinforcements in Ed Damazin (Ed Damazine, Blue Nile), in preparation to send them to Bau locality, in order to repel SPLM-N-Abdelaziz and RSF.
Movement of forces: On 2 March 2025, RSF withdrew to an unspecified location from Um Garfa (Bara, North Kordofan).
Security measures: On 2 March 2025, the governor amended the curfew period within the state from 1 am until 4 am across Red Sea state (location coded to state capital Port Sudan, Port Sudan, Red Sea), during the Ramadan holy month.
Movement of forces: On 2 March 2025, RSF withdrew to an unspecified location from Hamrat El Sheikh (Soudari, North Kordofan).
Weapons seizure: Around 2 March 2025 (as reported), SAF took over a building containing RSF weapons in the western sector of Omdurman (unclear if in western Um Bada locality or in western Omdurman city, location coded to state capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum).
Movement of forces: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), SAF, and Darfur Joint Forces/JSAM, deployed reinforcements in Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur), in preparation for attack on RSF around El Fasher.
Movement of forces: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), RSF, and a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), deployed reinforcements on 60 military vehicles in Madu, Mau, Sayiah, and Mellit (Melit, North Darfur), in preparation to repel the Joint force mobilized in Malha (coded separately).
Other: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), RSF opened training camps in SPLM-N-Abdelaziz in Blue Nile (location coded to SPLM-N controlled area Al Kurmuk, Al Kurmuk, Blue Nile).
Looting: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), RSF looted food supplies from community kitchens in Khartoum - Al Jarif West (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Movement of forces: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), RSF groups moved towards Jabal Aulia (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum) from unspecified locations in Khartoum to secure an emergency exit in case SAF in Al Gitaina and Al Manaqil arrive in the state.
Other: Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), SAF captured an unspecified number of Sudanese and foreign RSF in Soba East (Sharg An Neel, Khartoum) who were printing counterfeit money for RSF, and seized their equipment.
Movement of forces: Around 1 March 2025 (beginning of month), cargo jets landed at the airport, suspected of carrying SPLN-Abdelaziz reinforcement in Kauda (Heiban, South Kordofan).
Around 1 March 2025 (as reported), SAF regained control from RSF over Khartoum - Al Emtidad (Khartoum, Khartoum) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). It is unclear if there were clashes.

### Summary of Key Battles in Sudan, March 2025

**North Darfur:**
- **Malha (Al Malha):** Intensive clashes between the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) backed by the Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF. The RSF controlled the city after the Joint Forces withdrew, but claims of regaining control by the Joint Forces remain uncorroborated. Significant civilian casualties and displacement were reported, with 122 fatalities and 15,000 households displaced (SUD34374, SUD34294).

simple_summary:
### Summary of Key Battles in Sudan, March 2025

**Intense Combat and Strategic Maneuvers:**
- **El Fasher (North Darfur):** Heavy fighting occurred between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), backed by various militias. Significant casualties were reported, including civilians. Key events include the SAF regaining control over several neighborhoods and the RSF's strategic use of fighter drones and artillery (e.g., 31 March, 30 March, 29 March, 28 March).
- **Khartoum and Surrounding Areas:** Multiple clashes were reported in Khartoum and its suburbs, with both SAF and RSF attempting to secure strategic locations. Notable incidents include the SAF regaining control over key areas such as the presidential palace and various neighborhoods (e.g., 22 March, 21 March, 20 March, 19 March).
- **North Kordofan and Blue Nile:** The SAF and RSF engaged in several clashes, with the SAF regaining control over multiple towns and villages. Significant civilian casualties and displacements were reported (e.g., 27 March, 26 March, 23 March).

**Civilian Impact:**
- **Civilian Casualties:** Numerous civilian deaths and injuries were reported due to shelling, drone strikes, and ground combat. For example, on 31 March, 12 civilians were killed in Khor El Daliab (South Kordofan), and on 21 March, 203 civilians were killed in Malha (North Darfur).
- **Displacement:** Large-scale displacement of civilians occurred, particularly in North Darfur and North Kordofan. For instance, on 21 March, 15,000 households were displaced in Malha (North Darfur).

**Military Tactics and Equipment:**
- **Use of Drones and Artillery:** Both SAF and RSF extensively used fighter drones and artillery in their engagements. For example, on 31 March, RSF fighter drones targeted SAF in El Fasher, and on 29 March, SAF airstrikes targeted RSF in Ed Damazin (Blue Nile).
- **Strategic Maneuvers:** Both sides engaged in strategic maneuvers, including the SAF dropping humanitarian supplies in Zamzam IDP camp and the RSF's use of reinforcement troops and strategic fighter drones (e.g., 30 March, 29 March).

**Alliances and Defections:**
- **Allied Forces:** The SAF was supported by various allied forces, including the Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF and Sudan Shield Forces. The RSF was backed by militias described as Arab militias and the SPLM-N-Abdelaziz (e.g., 31 March, 29 March).
- **Defections and Changes in Allegiance:** There were reports of defections and changes in allegiance. For example, on 26 March, the Kenana group announced their support for SAF, and on 24 March, the JEM-New group announced their support for SAF.

**Humanitarian Concerns:**
- **Looting and Abductions:** Both SAF and RSF were involved in looting and abductions. For instance, on 24 March, RSF abducted more than 50 drivers in Tonjor (North Darfur), and on 25 March, SAF looted civilians' belongings in Bahri (Khartoum).
- **Mass Graves and Torture:** There were reports of mass graves and torture. For example, on 18 March, SAF discovered a mass grave in Omdurman court (Omdurman, Khartoum), and on 1 March, RSF tortured SLM/A-Transitional Council members in Korma (North Darfur).

**Security Measures and Non-Violent Activities:**
- **Curfews and Security Measures:** Governors amended curfew periods in various states due to insecurity. For example, on 2 March, the governor amended the curfew period in Northern state during the Ramadan holy month.
- **Non-Violent Activities:** There were reports of non-violent activities, such as traditional leaders from the Ngok Dinka and Misseriya communities committing to collaborating for peace in the Abyei region on 11 March.

This summary provides a concise overview of the key developments and battles in Sudan during March 2025, highlighting the intensity of the conflict, the impact on civilians, and the strategic maneuvers employed by both SAF and RSF.
corpus:
On 31 March 2025, RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), fighter drones targeted SAF, while SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, responded by artillery shelling and anti-aircraft fire in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur). The Joint forces claimed they killed and wounded 10 of RSF soldiers, destroyed a truck, and damaged many military vehicles. RSF fatalities coded as 5.
On 31 March 2025, RSF fighter drones targeted SAF, while SAF responded with anti-aircraft fire in Atbara (Atbara, River Nile). Casualties unknown.
On 31 March 2025, RSF backed by SPLM-N-Abdelaziz clashed with SAF in Khor El Daliab (Delami, South Kordofan). RSF overtook the area from SAF, and claimed they have killed 70 SAF soldiers, destroyed 7 military vehicles, and captured 6 vehicles. 12 civilians were killed. 557 households were displaced. Fatalities coded as 82 (70 SAF + 12 civilians).
On 30 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, and exchange of artillery shelling. SAF jet dropped humanitarians supplies for Zamzam IDP camp. The Joint forces claimed that they killed 10 of RSF soldiers, destroyed 16 military vehicles, in addition, 8-9 civilians were killed and 17 were wounded due to RSF shelling. A report mentioned that RSF killed 20 RSF soldiers who attempted to withdraw from El Fasher. Fatalities coded as 38 (30 RSF + 8 civilians).
On 30 March 2025, RSF fighter drones targeted SAF, while SAF responded with anti-aircraft fire in Atbara (Atbara, River Nile). Casualties unknown.
On 29 March 2025, RSF fighter drones targeted SAF, while SAF responded with anti-aircraft fire in Ed Damazin (Ed Damazine, Blue Nile). Casualties unknown.
On 29 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Libya Market (Um Bada, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of the market (RSF overtook the market on an unspecified day shortly after 15 April 2023) and seizing weapons left behind by withdrawing RSF. Casualties unknown.
On 29 March 2025, RSF backed by SPLM-N-Abdelaziz clashed with SAF backed by SPLM-N-Agar in Al Slik (Bau, Blue Nile). RSF overtook the area from SAF, who claimed that they have inflicted losses on RSF lives and equipment. Unspecified SAF fatalities coded as 10. 300 households were displaced.
On 28 March 2025, clashes between SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, and RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), continued in east, northeast, and southeast El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, RSF fighter drones, and artillery shelling. The Joint Forces claimed they have killed 50 RSF soldiers, destroyed 13 military vehicles, 4 trucks, in addition to many RSF soldiers withdrew from El Fasher.
On 27 March 2025, SAF airstrikes targeted RSF and a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), while RSF shelled artillery targeting SAF and Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur). Casualties unknown.
Around 27 March 2025 (as reported), SAF killed (described as 'destroyed') a large number of RSF (likely during an armed clash due to no report of shelling or airstrikes) in Al Shegilab (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 10.
On 27 March 2025, 3-5 RSF fighter drones targeted SAF and SPLM-N-Agar, while SAF responded with ground anti-aircraft fire in Ed Damazin (Ed Damazine, White Nile). 3 SAF and 1 SPLM-N-Agar were wounded. 267 households were displaced.
On 26 March 2025, SAF airstrikes targeted RSF in the RSF military camp in Tayba Military Base (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum) and SAF supported by Sudan Shield Forces regained control of the base. Casualties unknown.
On 26 March 2025, SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF fighter drones, targeted RSF and a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), while RSF shelled artillery targeting SAF in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur). The Joint Forces claimed they had killed 10 RSF soldiers and destroyed a jamming vehicle, in addition to 8 civilians who were killed and 5 wounded due to RSF shelling. RSF deployed reinforcement troops. 7 Joint Forces soldiers were killed and 2 were wounded. Fatalities coded as 25 (10 RSF + 8 civilians + 7 Joint Forces).
Around 26 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Al Jaded Al Thawra (Al Kamlin, Al Jazirah) and SAF regained control of the area (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). Casualties unknown.
Around 26 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Gadid Al Awamra (Al Kamlin, Al Jazirah) and SAF regained control of the area (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). Casualties unknown.
On 26 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Jabal Aulia (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum), with SAF drone strikes and artillery shelling being reported, and SAF regaining control from RSF over the area (RSF gained control of Jabal Aulia on 20 November 2023 - coded separately) and freeing an unspecified number of starved RSF captives. Sudan Shield Forces and General Intelligence clashed with RSF near Jabal Aulia bridge. Casualties unknown.
Around 26 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF, supported by Abu Tira and police forces, and RSF continued in Khartoum - Al Kalakla (Jebel Awlia, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of the area. Date of initial RSF takeover unclear, although RSF overtook civilians' homes in the area on 25 July 2023 (coded separately).
On 26 March 2025, SAF, supported by Abu Tira and other unspecified armed groups (coded as unidentified armed group), regained control from RSF over Al Bageir (including the SAF mechanized 1st infantry brigade HQ in the area) (Al Kamlin, Al Jazirah) (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). SAF claimed it killed a large number of RSF in the area (likely an armed clash due to no report of shelling or airstrikes). Unspecified number of fatalities coded as 10.
On 25 March 2025, residents militia (coded as Darfur communal militia) clashed with RSF and a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia) at unspecified location in Al Malha locality (location coded to locality capital Malha, North Darfur), after RSF looted 20 heads of camels. 5 RSF were killed.
On 25 March 2025, SAF claimed two RSF groups clashed with each other at an unspecified location around El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), due to disagreements on the leadership. Many were killed and wounded. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3.
On 24 March 2025, SAF airstrikes targeted RSF and a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia) in Kilo 10 in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), while RSF shelled artillery. SAF claimed they had destroyed 6 military vehicles, and RSF on 50 military vehicles withdrew due to a shortage of medicine supplies. Civilians casualties were reported.
On 24 March 2025, SAF claimed 2 RSF groups clashed in Juggu Juggu (Al Fasher, North Darfur), after the commander took soldiers salaries. Casualties unknown.
Around 24 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Khartoum city (Khartoum, Khartoum). Casualties unknown.
On 23 March 2025, clashes between SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, and RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), continued in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF fighter drones, RSF artillery shelling. The Joint Forces claimed they have killed 45 RSF soldiers and wounded 10, destroyed 7 military vehicles, damaged a truck, arrested 2 soldiers, regained control over Al Aafia health center building, Al Kifah, and Makraka neighborhoods, and 8 civilians were killed and 6 were wounded due to RSF shelling. Fatalities coded as 53 (45 RSF + 8 civilians).
On 23 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in neighborhoods 8 and 9 of Omdurman - Al Thawra (Karrari, Khartoum), with RSF drone strikes and artillery shelling and SAF anti-aircraft fire being reported. 1-3 civilians were killed and 2-8 others were injured.
On 23 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur). RSF attacked civilians. Casualties unknown.
On 23 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by SPLM-N-Abdelaziz, and SAF continued in Lagawa (Al Lagowa, West Kordofan). RSF overtook the town after SAF withdrew. RSF claimed they have inflicted losses on SAF lives and equipment, and captured 11 military vehicles. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in east, northeast, and west El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, and RSF artillery shelling. The Joint Forces claimed they had killed and wounded 10 of the RSF (fatalities coded as 5), destroyed 11 military vehicles and 2 trucks, and captured large quantities of weapons and ammunition, in addition to many civilians being killed and wounded due to RSF shelling (unspecified fatalities coded as 3). Fatalities coded as 8 (5 RSF + 3 civilians).
Around 22 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Ombada (Um Bada, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of Al Sabeel sector of the neighborhood (SAF has retaken control of the city on 29 December 2024). Casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, and RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), continued in and around Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur). RSF repelled the Joint Forces. Casualties unknown.
Around 22 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF, supported by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, and RSF continued in Omdurman - Abu Seid (Omdurman, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of the neighborhood (including Al Nakhil, Al Bustan, Al Mansoura areas - date of initial RSF takeover unclear). Casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in Jabel Eisa (Al Malha, North Darfur). RSF overtook the area. Casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in buildings near Khartoum - Khartoum International Airport (Khartoum, Khartoum). Casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Khartoum - Al Mogran (Khartoum, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of the area (date of initial RSF takeover unclear, although RSF overtook houses in the area around 30 July 2023 - coded separately). An unspecified number of SAF were killed, and SAF claimed it killed more than 100 RSF in Al Mogran and Al Amarat on 22 March. 100 RSF fatalities split across Al Mogran and Al Amarat and coded as 50 for this event. Unspecified number of SAF fatalities coded as 3. Total fatalities coded as 53 (3 SAF + 50 RSF).
On 22 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Khartoum - Downtown (Khartoum, Khartoum), with SAF regaining control of the general intelligence HQ buildings, the outskirts of Arabic market, and other buildings, and with RSF withdrawing towards Khartoum 2 and southern Khartoum. Casualties unknown.
On 22 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in Khartoum - Al Amarat (Khartoum, Khartoum), with RSF withdrawing from the neighborhood. SAF claimed it killed more than 100 RSF in Al Mogran and Al Amarat on 22 March. 100 fatalities split across Al Mogran and Al Amarat and coded as 50 for this event.
On 21 March 2025, SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, and RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), exchanged airstrikes, fighter drone strikes, and artillery shelling in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur). The Joint Forces claimed they have killed and wounded 10 of RSF, and destroyed 6 military vehicles. Unspecified RSF fatalities coded as 5.
On 21 March 2025, clashes between SAF supported by Sudan Shield Forces and RSF continued in southern Khartoum (unclear if Khartoum locality or city, location coded to locality capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum). Casualties unknown.
On 21 March 2025, clashes between RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF, backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes. RSF killed an unspecified number of the Joint Forces captives. Unspecified fatalities coded as 10. RSF attacked civilians and killed 203, including 17 community leaders, 63-68 were wounded in addition to 22 reported missing, civilians' houses and markets were looted on 20 March and 21 March (coded separately). 203 civilians' fatalities split across two days and coded as 101 for this event. Fatalities coded as 111 (10 Joint Forces + 101 civilians). 15,000 households - 250.000 people were displaced.
On 21 March 2025, clashes between SAF supported by the Revolutionary Battalions and RSF continued in the vicinity of the presidential palace in Khartoum - Downtown (Khartoum, Khartoum), with RSF drone strikes being reported and SAF regaining control of the presidential palace, Arabic market, and ministry buildings in the area (date of initial RSF takeover unclear). 3-5 SAF military journalists and civilian journalists were killed, SAF claimed it killed tens of RSF, while RSF claimed it killed 89 SAF. Total fatalities coded as 13 (3 SAF and civilians+10 RSF).
On 21 March 2025, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in the vicinity of Khartoum - Khartoum International Airport (Khartoum, Khartoum). Casualties unknown.
Around 20 March 2025 (as reported), clashes between SAF and RSF continued in southwestern Omdurman city (Omdurman, Khartoum), with SAF reinforcements arriving in the area to 'secure' and regain the western entry points leading to Khartoum city. Casualties unknown.
On 20 March 2025, armed individuals suspected to be Nuer community members clashed with local youth (likely members of the Ngok Dinka community who live in the area) between Wayeng and Myadol/Myordol villages in Rumameer Payam (Abyei disputed area), resulting in 1 fatality and the displacement of civilians from the area. The Nuer raided 170 goats from the locals.
On 20 March 2025, clashes between SAF supported by unspecified armed groups (coded as unidentified armed group) and RSF continued in Khartoum - Downtown (Khartoum, Khartoum), with SAF drone strikes being reported and SAF regaining control of the Kuwaiti Towers, Al Zaytouna hospital, 2 hospitals, the ministry of minerals, and the southern sector of the Mek Nimir bridge. 1 SAF was killed and SAF claimed it killed hundreds of RSF. Fatalities coded as 101.
On 20 March 2025, clashes between RSF backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in and around Malha (Al Malha, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, RSF strategic fighter drones, and artillery shelling. RSF controlled the city after the Joint Forces withdrew. The Joint Forces claimed later that they repelled RSF and regained control of the city (uncorroborated). RSF claimed they overtook the Joint Forces base, the locality building, and Central Reserve Forces base, killed 380 Joint Forces soldiers (uncorroborated), and the forces commander Abdalla Banah was wounded, released tens of civilian prisoners, and captured a large number of military vehicles and equipment. The Joint Forces claimed they repelled RSF offensives from three fronts, killed 93 RSF soldiers, including 8 commanders, wounded 77 (uncorroborated), and destroyed 4 military vehicles. Uncorroborated fatalities coded as 10 for each side. RAC denied the accusation of participating with RSF against the Joint Forces, and claimed the RAC defector factions were the ones who participated. RSF attacked civilians and killed 203, including 17 community leaders, and 63-68 were wounded in addition to 22 reported missing, and looted civilians' houses and markets on 20 March and 21 March (coded separately). 203 civilians' fatalities split across the two days and coded as 102 for this event. Fatalities coded as 122 (10 Joint forces + 10 RSF + 102 civilians). 15,000 households were displaced.
On 19 March 2025, clashes between SAF supported by Al Baraa Ibn Malik brigade and RSF continued in the vicinity of the presidential palace in Khartoum - Downtown (Khartoum, Khartoum), with SAF drone strikes and artillery shelling being reported. RSF claimed they received reinforcements in the area. More than 15 RSF were killed or injured (described as 'neutralized').
On 19 March 2025, clashes between RSF backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in Al Sinia camp near Chad borders (location coded to nearest populated area to the borders Tina, At Tina, North Darfur). Casualties unknown.
On 19 March 2025, clashes between RSF backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), and SAF backed by Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF, continued in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), with SAF airstrikes, fighter drones and artillery shelling. **North Kordofan:**

- **March 25:** SAF airstrikes in El Fasher killed 32 individuals, including 20 RSF soldiers and 12 civilians. (SUD34415)

- **March 27:** SAF airstrikes in Mellit resulted in unspecified casualties. (SUD34428)

**North Darfur:**
- **March 24:** SAF airstrikes in Tora, Al Fasher, resulted in 40-270 civilian fatalities and 63-400 wounded. (SUD34409)
- **March 10:** RSF drone and artillery strikes in Malha killed 35 individuals, including 19 Joint Forces soldiers and 16 civilians. (SUD34187)
- **March 20:** RSF shelling in El Fasher killed 6 civilians. (SUD34367)
- **March 23:** RSF drone strikes in Hillat Kuku killed 5-11 civilians. (SUD34431)
- **March 25:** SAF airstrikes in Abu Hamira resulted in unspecified casualties. (SUD34412)
- **March 26:** SAF airstrikes between El Fasher and Kutum resulted in unspecified casualties. (SUD34419)
- **March 27:** SAF airstrikes in Koma resulted in unspecified casualties. (SUD34426, SUD34427)
- **March 29:** SAF airstrikes in Shangil Tobay resulted in unspecified casualties. (SUD34592)
- **March 31:** SAF airstrikes in Dar El Salam resulted in no casualties. (SUD34566)

**Khartoum:**
- **March 27-31:** RSF shelling in Al Jumueia and Eid Al Hadd killed 92-94 civilians and injured hundreds. (SUD34551, SUD34642, SUD34643, SUD34641)
- **March 17:** RSF shelling in neighborhoods 8 and 10 in Omdurman killed 6-10 civilians. (SUD34378)

**South Darfur:**
- **March 14:** SAF airstrikes in Nyala resulted in unspecified RSF fatalities. (SUD34277)
- **March 31:** RSF soldier detonated a grenade in Qadira

### Summary of Key Explosions/Remote Violence Events in Sudan, March 2025

**March 2025** saw a significant escalation in remote violence and explosions across Sudan, primarily involving the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). Key developments include:

1. **High-Casualty Incidents**:
   - **Tora (Al Fasher, North Darfur)**: On 24 March, SAF airstrikes resulted in 40-270 civilian deaths and 63-400 injuries, with 20 reported missing. (Event ID: 24 March 2025)
   - **Al Jumueia and Eid Al Hadd (Omdurman, Khartoum)**: Between 27 March and 3 April, RSF attacks killed 92-94 civilians and injured hundreds. (Event IDs: 31 March 2025, 30 March 2025, 29 March 2025, 28 March 2025)
   - **Abu Shouk IDP Camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur)**: Multiple RSF attacks between 23 March and 31 March resulted in several civilian casualties. (Event IDs: 31 March 2025, 23 March 2025, 22 March 2025, 21 March 2025, 15 March 2025, 5 March 2025, 4 March 2025, 2 March 2025)

2. **Airstrikes and Drone Attacks**:
   - **SAF Airstrikes**: Numerous SAF airstrikes targeted RSF positions in various locations, including Nyala, El Fasher, and Khartoum. (Event IDs: 31 March 2025, 27 March 2025, 25 March 2025, 24 March 2025, 21 March 2025, 19 March 2025, 18 March 2025, 16 March 2025, 15 March 2025, 14 March 2025, 13 March 2025, 11 March 2025, 10 March 2025, 7 March 2025, 4 March 2025, 3 March 2025, 2 March 2025, 1 March 2025)
   - **RSF Drone Strikes**: RSF conducted drone strikes in Khartoum and other areas, causing civilian casualties and property damage. (Event IDs: 23 March 2025, 13 March 2025, 12 March 2025, 11 March 2025, 1 March 2025)

3. **Artillery Shelling**:
   - **Omdurman and Khartoum**: RSF and SAF engaged in intense artillery shelling in Omdurman and Khartoum, resulting in numerous civilian casualties and injuries. graphRAG_summary:
### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Protests in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary:**

In April 2025, Sudan experienced a series of protests across various regions, driven by a range of grievances and demands. The protests were largely peaceful, with no reported fatalities.

**Key Developments:**

1. **Economic and Trade-Related Protests:**
   - On April 2, 2025, fruit traders in Central Darfur (Golo) and North Darfur (Martal) protested, demanding the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) to open the road to El Fasher to facilitate the sale of their goods (SUD34638, SUD34639).

2. **Political and Historical Commemoration:**
   - On April 6, 2025, protests were held in Omdurman and Khartoum to commemorate the April 6, 1985, popular uprising anniversary (SUD34729, SUD34728).

3. **Military and Political Alliances:**
   - On April 10, 2025, Imart Tagawa in South Kordofan protested against the Sudanese Armed Forces (SFA) alliances with the RSF and SPLM-N-Abdelaziz (SUD34792).

4. **Humanitarian Concerns:**
   - On April 14, 2025, residents in Port Sudan protested against RSF attacks on the Zamzam IDPs camp and El Fasher (SUD34869).
   - On April 20 and 24, 2025, residents in Port Sudan again protested, condemning RSF attacks and the siege on Zamzam and Abu Shouk IDPs camps (SUD34953, SUD34955).

5. **Service and Infrastructure Issues:**
   - On April 20, 2025, residents in Kassala protested, demanding the restoration of electricity and the resignation of the state electricity company director (SUD34896).

6. **Labor and Employment Issues:**
   - On April 24, 2025, employees of a private company in Abyei protested over the late payment of salaries and benefits, blocking the entry and exit points of the UNISFA compound (SUD35031).

7. **Governance and Land Use:**
   - Around April 27, 2025, residents in Abu Gouta, Al Jazirah, demonstrated against the local government's sale of land and public areas without proper tenders or a formal bidding process (SUD35051).

**Conclusion:**

The protests in April 2025 highlight ongoing economic, political, and humanitarian issues in Sudan. While these protests were largely peaceful, the underlying grievances indicate potential areas for conflict escalation if not addressed promptly. Continuous monitoring and early intervention are crucial to prevent further unrest.
simple_summary:
### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Protests in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary of Key Protest Developments:**

1. **Local Governance and Public Services:**
   - Residents in Abu Gouta (Al Hasahisa, Al Jazirah) protested on 27 April 2025 against the local government's sale of land and public areas without proper tenders or bidding processes. (Event ID: 1)
   - Protests in Kassala (Madeinat Kassala, Kassala) on 20 April 2025 demanded the restoration of electricity and the resignation of the state electricity company director. (Event ID: 3)

2. **Humanitarian Concerns:**
   - Multiple protests in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea) occurred on 14, 20, and 24 April 2025, condemning Rapid Support Forces (RSF) attacks and the siege on Zamzam and Abu Shouk IDPs camps. (Event IDs: 4, 5, 6)
   - Employees of a private company in Abyei Town, Abyei County (Abyei disputed area) protested on 24 April 2025 over late payment of salaries and benefits, blocking the UNISFA compound. (Event ID: 2)

3. **Political and Historical Commemorations:**
   - Protests in Omdurman (Omdurman, Khartoum) and on 60 Street in Khartoum city (Khartoum, Khartoum) on 6 April 2025 commemorated the April 6, 1985, popular uprising anniversary. (Event IDs: 7, 8)

4. **Economic Disruptions:**
   - Fruit traders in Golo (Wasat Jabal Marrah, Central Darfur) and Martal (Tawila, North Darfur) protested on 2 April 2025, demanding the RSF to open the road to El Fasher for trade. (Event IDs: 9, 10)

5. **Security and Conflict Dynamics:**
   - Imart Tagawa staged a protest in Rashad (Rashad, South Kordofan) on 10 April 2025, denouncing SFA alliances between RSF and SPLM-N-Abdelaziz. (Event ID: 11)
   - RSF fighter drones targeted Ed Debba (Ad Dabbah, Northern) on 9 April 2025, resulting in 6 civilian fatalities. (Event ID: 12)
   - RSF fighter drones targeted the power station in Atbara (Atbara, River Nile) on 26 April 2025, with no fatalities reported. (Event ID: 13)

**Non-violent and Security Measures:**
   - RSF imposed restrictions on its members in East Darfur on 5 April 2025, banning the wearing of turbans, uniforms, and carrying weapons inside cities due to increased insecurity. (Event ID: 14)
   - The Governor renewed the state of emergency across White Nile state on 25 April 2025 due to regional insecurity. (Event ID: 15)

**Other Notable Events:**
   - Acting governor of South Darfur state dismissed 57 state employees in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea) on 28 April 2025, accusing them of supporting RSF. (Event ID: 16)

This summary highlights the key protest activities and related security developments in Sudan during April 2025, providing a snapshot of the ongoing conflicts and public discontent.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Riots in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

In April 2025, Sudan experienced notable incidents of civil unrest, specifically riots in North Darfur. On April 2, 2025, a riot occurred in the Sortine area of Kebkabiya, North Darfur, resulting in the death of one civilian. The riot was instigated by internally displaced persons (IDPs) who attacked and killed a civilian after accusing him of selling aid intended for IDPs (SUD34721). This event highlights ongoing tensions and potential for further unrest in the region due to resource scarcity and mistrust among different groups.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Riots in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary of Key Developments:**

In April 2025, Sudan experienced significant riot-related incidents, primarily involving internally displaced persons (IDPs) and armed groups. The month began with a violent altercation in North Darfur, where IDPs, armed with sticks, attacked and killed a civilian in Sortine (Kebkabiya) on 2 April. The civilian was accused of selling aid intended for IDPs (Event ID: 1).

Later in the month, on 13 April, a more severe incident occurred when the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), backed by a militia identified as the Darfur Arab militia, attacked IDPs fleeing the Zamzam IDP camp en route to Tawila. This attack resulted in the deaths of 15 individuals and the abduction of 25 women (Event ID: 2).

These events highlight ongoing tensions and violence in North Darfur, particularly affecting vulnerable IDP populations. The incidents underscore the need for heightened monitoring and intervention to mitigate further escalations and protect civilian populations.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Violence Against Civilians in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary:**

April 2025 witnessed significant violence against civilians in Sudan, with multiple incidents reported across various regions. The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) were the primary perpetrators, often targeting civilians on ethnic or political grounds.

**Key Developments:**

1. **Khartoum:**
   - **April 1:** SAF and Sudan Shield Forces killed 90 civilians in Tayba Al Hasanab, including Misseriya civilians targeted on an ethnic basis (SUD34594).
   - **April 6:** RSF killed 30 male civilians in Eid Al Hadd, continuing their attacks on Jumueia villages (SUD34725).
   - **April 27:** RSF held hostage, assaulted, and killed 25-31 civilians in Al Salha, accusing them of being SAF members. They also sexually assaulted women and imposed a curfew (SUD34988).

2. **West Kordofan:**
   - **April 22:** RSF attacked civilians in Al Zaafa village, killing 74-79 and wounding 178. They also abducted 17 civilians and burned the village (SUD34971).

3. **Sennar:**
   - **April 4:** SAF and Al Baraa Ibn Malik killed 35 civilians in Al Shigeg, accusing them of being RSF sympathizers (SUD34698).

4. **North Kordofan:**
   - **April 14:** RSF attacked civilians in Umm Shawa village, killing more than 18 (SUD34842).
   - **April 18:** RSF killed at least 1 civilian in Kazgil, wounding others (SUD34950).

5. **North Darfur:**
   - **April 13:** RSF, backed by a militia, attacked IDPs fleeing Zamzam IDPs camp, killing 15 and abducting 25 women (SUD34839).
   - **April 20:** RSF attacked multiple villages, including Hillat Salih and Um Tarjah, killing 20 civilians and displacing others (SUD34942, SUD34943).

6. **South Kordofan:**
   - **April 23:** RSF attacked civilians in Tongolo, killing 4 (SUD34965).
   - **April 28:** RSF attacked civilians in Awlad Younis, killing 5 and abducting others (SUD35046).

7. **Central Darfur:**
   - **April 26:** Militants shot and killed 2 civilians in Al Jananiya (SUD34994).
   - **April 27:** RSF, backed by a militia, killed 3-8 IDPs and abducted 40 aid workers and 50 civilians (SUD34989).

8. **Other Regions:**
   - **April 2:** SAF supported by unidentified armed groups killed civilians in multiple locations in Khartoum (SUD34595, SUD34596, SUD34597, SUD34598, SUD34599).
   - **April 22:** An unidentified armed group abducted 144 migrants/refugees in Kassala, raping and torturing women (SUD34897).
   - **April 28:** Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF attacked civilians in Ed Debba and Port Sudan, killing 2 in each location (SUD35003, SUD35006).

**Conclusion:**

The violence in April 2025 highlights the ongoing conflict and humanitarian crisis in Sudan. Both the RSF and SAF, along with various militias, have been responsible for numerous attacks on civilians, resulting in significant loss of life and displacement. The ethnic and political motivations behind these attacks underscore the deep-seated tensions and the urgent need for international intervention and peacekeeping efforts.

### Conflict-Early-Warning Brief: Violence Against Civilians in Sudan, April 2025

**Summary:**
April 2025 saw a significant escalation in violence against civilians in Sudan, with multiple incidents of killings, abductions, and sexual assaults reported across various regions. The Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), Rapid Support Forces (RSF), and various militias were involved in numerous clashes and attacks, leading to widespread civilian casualties and displacements.

**Key Developments:**

1. **Killings and Abductions:**
   - **Khartoum and Surrounding Areas:** Multiple incidents of civilian killings and abductions were reported. On April 29, SAF killed a lawyer in Al Qatati, Khartoum (Event ID: 1). On April 27, RSF held hostage, assaulted, and killed 25-31 civilians in Omdurman, accusing them of being members of various armed groups (Event ID: 15).
   - **Darfur Region:** The Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF attacked civilians in Ed Debba, killing 2 and wounding 1 (Event ID: 2). RSF abducted doctors, a Muslim Sheikh, and 8 women in various locations in South and North Darfur (Event IDs: 4, 5, 6).
   - **Kordofan Region:** RSF attacked civilians in Awlad Younis, South Kordofan, killing 5 and abducting others (Event ID: 10). In North Kordofan, RSF killed at least 1 civilian in Kazgil (Event ID: 28).

2. **Sexual Assaults and Enslavement:**
   - **Omdurman:** On April 27, RSF sexually assaulted an unspecified number of girls and women, forcing them into labor (Event ID: 15).
   - **North Darfur:** On April 28, RSF abducted 8 women in El Fasher, releasing them after 5 days (Event ID: 6).
   - **North Kordofan:** On April 18, militants abducted 18 women-IDPs, including minors, and raped 8 of them (Event ID: 31).

3. **Mass Killings and Displacements:**
   - **North Darfur:** On April 22, RSF attacked civilians in Al Zaafa village, killing 74-79 and wounding 178 (Event ID: 36). On April 20, RSF killed 20 civilians in multiple villages, including Hillat Salih and Um Tarjah (Event ID: 41).
   - **White Nile:** Around April 20, 6,039 households were displaced from multiple villages due to increased insecurity (Event ID: 69).

4. **Military Clashes and Airstrikes:**
   - **Khartoum:** On April 25, clashes between SAF and RSF continued in various locations, with RSF drone strikes destroying SAF fighter jets and weapons (Event ID: 59).
   - **North Darfur:** On April 11, clashes between RSF and SAF in Zamzam IDP camp resulted in 25-100 civilian deaths (Event ID: 51).

5. **Humanitarian Concerns:**
   - **Abyei:** On April 21, SLM/A-Nur declared a humanitarian emergency in Jebel Marrah and Tawila due to the displacement of over 3 million IDPs (Event ID: 66).
   - **Port Sudan:** On April 21, the Sudanese government and RSF agreed with the UN on aid delivery access and establishing UN logistical supply bases in Mellit and Tawila (Event ID: 71).

**Conclusion:**
The escalation of violence in April 2025 highlights the urgent need for international intervention and humanitarian aid. The ongoing clashes and targeted attacks on civilians underscore the volatile security situation in Sudan, requiring immediate attention to prevent further loss of life and displacement.

graphRAG_summary:
### Strategic Developments in Sudan, April 2025

**Key Developments:**

1. **Military Movements and Mobilizations:**
   - **RSF Activities:**
     - RSF seized weapons and looted civilian properties in Khartoum and North Darfur (SUD34623, SUD34627, SUD34628, SUD34629).
     - RSF mobilized significant forces in North and South Darfur, preparing for offensives (SUD34615, SUD34616, SUD34618, SUD34634, SUD34641, SUD34642).
     - RSF deployed reinforcements in West Kordofan and established new bases in North Darfur (SUD34732, SUD34735, SUD34862).
     - RSF overtook several areas, including Umm Adara in West Kordofan and El Mashayesh in South Kordofan (SUD34784, SUD35015).
     - RSF established a police force in East Darfur to combat insecurity (SUD34894).

   - **SAF Activities:**
     - SAF mobilized volunteers in North Kordofan and deployed troops in various regions (SUD34614, SUD34733, SUD35018, SUD35022).
     - SAF seized weapons from RSF in Khartoum and River Nile (SUD34711, SUD34986).
     - SAF received air defense systems in Port Sudan (SUD35011).

2. **Security Measures:**
   - Governors in River Nile, Northern, and White Nile states amended curfews due to insecurity (SUD34611, SUD34612, SUD34993).
   - SAF banned random bullet firing in El Fasher and dispersed a political seminar in Atbara (SUD35013, SUD35001).

3. **Armed Group Changes and Defections:**
   - Tamazuj announced general mobilization supporting RSF (SUD34619).
   - GSLF defected to SAF in North Darfur (SUD34754).
   - SLM/A-Minnawi and Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF saw significant defections to RSF (SUD34931, SUD34939).
   - Various ethnic groups and communal militias defected to or supported RSF in South Kordofan and Darfur (SUD34850, SUD34964, SUD34992).

4. **Humanitarian and Civilian Impact:**
   - Hundreds of civilians fled Omdurman due to RSF attacks (SUD34634).
   - Mass graves were discovered in Khartoum, attributed to RSF activities (SUD34637, SUD34724).
   - Significant displacements occurred in North Darfur and White Nile due to clashes (SUD34759, SUD34976).
   - Doctors in Nyala launched a strike due to RSF violence in hospitals (SUD34960).

5. **Diplomatic and Aid Efforts:**
   - Sudanese government and RSF agreed with the UN on aid delivery access (SUD34954).
   - The Humanitarian Aid Commission suspended activities of NGOs in South Kordofan (SUD34966).

These developments highlight the ongoing conflict and strategic maneuvers by both SAF and RSF, with significant implications for civilian security and humanitarian conditions across Sudan.
simple_summary:
### Strategic Developments in Sudan, April 2025

**Key Strategic Developments:**

1. **Military Movements and Deployments:**
   - **SAF Deployments:** The Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) deployed troops in Al Hamra and Wd Jabour to repel Rapid Support Forces (RSF) attacks (29 April). SAF also mobilized troops in El Obeid and received FM-90 Chinese air defense systems in Port Sudan (27 April).
   - **RSF Movements:** RSF overtook El Mashayesh from SAF without reported clashes (30 April). They deployed reinforcement troops in Ghubaysh and Lafat Tayba in preparation for counter-attacks (24 April). RSF also mobilized troops in Um Sayalah and Al Hamra (12 April).

2. **Conflict and Control of Territories:**
   - **Control of Key Areas:** RSF gained control over the Barno base in West Kordofan (26 April) and El Khowai from SAF (28 April). They also overtook Umm Adara and mobilized troops in Nyala (4 April).
   - **Clashes and Casualties:** Significant clashes occurred in El Fasher, Nyala, and Omdurman, with high civilian and military casualties. For example, clashes in El Fasher resulted in 92 fatalities (11 April) and 20 civilians killed in Umm Keddada (20 April).

3. **Strategic Alliances and Defections:**
   - **Alliances:** The General Intelligence Service dispersed a Sudanese Communist Party (SCP) seminar in Atbara (30 April). RSF established a police force in Ed Daein and received support from various ethnic groups and militias (20 April).
   - **Defections:** Over 311 RSF surrendered to SAF in El Obeid (25 April). Additionally, significant defections occurred from various armed groups to either SAF or RSF, including 7,000 SLM/A-Minnawi to RSF (22 April) and 6,000 Zaghawa and Masalit to Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF (24 April).

4. **Security Measures and Humanitarian Impact:**
   - **Security Measures:** SAF banned random bullet firing in El Fasher (29 April) and imposed curfews in White Nile and Northern states (3 April). RSF imposed a night curfew in El Geneina and launched a campaign to combat insecurity (15 April).
   - **Humanitarian Crisis:** Doctors in Nyala went on strike due to RSF violence (23 April). The Humanitarian Aid Commission suspended activities of 30 NGOs in South Kordofan (21 April). Significant displacement occurred due to insecurity, with 6,039 households displaced in White Nile (20 April).

5. **International and Regional Involvement:**
   - **International Agreements:** The Sudanese government and RSF agreed with the UN on aid delivery access and establishing UN logistical supply bases in Mellit and Tawila (21 April).
   - **Regional Tensions:** Clashes and tensions persisted in the Abyei disputed area, with cattle raids and abductions reported (16 April).

6. **Strategic Infrastructure and Logistics:**
   - **Infrastructure Attacks:** RSF targeted the power station in Ed Damer with fighter drones (26 April) and shelled the oil refinery station in Al Hagina (22 April).
   - **Logistics and Supplies:** SAF received reinforcement supplies in An Nahud and Babanussa (27 April and 22 April). RSF cargo jets landed multiple times in Nyala, likely bringing supplies (4 April).

These developments highlight the ongoing strategic maneuvers, alliances, and conflicts between SAF and RSF, with significant implications for security, humanitarian conditions, and regional stability in Sudan.

Non-violent activity: On 30 April 2025, the General Intelligence Service dispersed a SCP seminar and banned their meetings in Atbara (Atbara, River Nile).
Looting: On 30 April 2025, militants (coded as Darfur communal militia) looted 8 shops in Shaabi market (popular) in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur).
On 30 April 2025, RSF overtook El Mashayesh (Kadugli, South Kordofan) from SAF. No clashes were reported.
Security measures: On 29 April 2025, SAF banned random bullet firing in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), due to increased RSF attacks.
Movement of forces: On 29 April 2025, SAF deployed troops in Al Hamra (Bara, North Kordofan), in preparation to repel RSF attacks.
Movement of forces: On 29 April 2025, SAF deployed troops in Wd Jabour (Ad Diwaim, White Nile), in preparation to repel RSF attacks.
Property destruction: On 29 April 2025, RSF, backed by a militia (described as an Arab militia, coded as Darfur Arab militia), looted and destroyed MSF field hospital in Zamzam IDP camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur).
Change to armed group: On 28 April 2025, an unspecified Native Administration in Central Darfur (coded as Darfur communal militia) renewed their pledge to support RSF in the war against SAF in Zalingei (Zalingi, Central Darfur).
Other: On 28 April 2025, acting governor of South Darfur state dismissed 57 state employees in South Darfur in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea), accusing them of supporting RSF.
Other: On 28 April 2025, RSF in Al Salha occupied all health centers in Omdurman - Al Salha (Omdurman, Khartoum), turning them into a military hospital for their members, and preventing residents from accessing health services.
Movement of forces: Around 27 April 2025 (as reported), SAF received FM-90 Chinese air defense systems suspected to be from the Military Forces of Turkey, as two military jets landed in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea).
Movement of forces: On 27 April 2025, the SAF jet dropped reinforcement supplies in An Nahud (An Nuhud, West Kordofan).
Weapons seizure: Around 26 April 2025 (as reported), SAF seized an unspecified amount of weapons and ammunition from an armed group in Dongola (Dongola, Northern).
On 26 April 2025, RSF claimed to have gained control over the Barno base from SAF in West Kordofan (location coded to state capital El Fula, El Salam, West Darfur). No clashes were reported.
Around 25 April 2025 (as reported), more than 311 RSF surrendered to SAF in El Obeid (Sheikan, North Kordofan).
Security measures: On 25 April 2025, the Governor renewed the state of emergency across White Nile state (location coded to Kosti, Kosti, White Nile), due to insecurity in the region.
Movement of forces: On 25 April 2025, Sudan Shield Forces deployed troops to support SAF in battles in El Obeid (Sheikan, North Kordofan).
Change to armed group: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), more than 6,000 Zaghawa and Masalist joined Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF in Tina (At Tina, North Darfur).
Movement of forces: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), RSF deployed reinforcement troops in Ghubaysh (Ghubaish, West Kordofan), in preparation to repel SAF advances in Kordofan.
Change to armed group: Around 24 April 2025 (as reported), 5,000 Hawazmah-Baggara joined RSF (location coded to RSF stronghold in South Kordofan, in Dibebad, Al Quoz).
Strikes: On 23 April 2025, doctors launched a strike in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur), after an RSF militant opened fire inside the hospital (coded separately) and demanded their financial dues.
Non-violent activity: On 22 April 2025, RSF continued transferring suspected SAF captives from Khartoum to Nyala, as two trucks of captives in SAF uniform escorted by RSF crossed East Darfur from east to west (location coded to state capital Ed Daein, Ad Duayn).
Weapons seizure: Around 22 April 2025 (as reported), Abu Tira Intelligence raided a residence used by RSF and seized a large amount of their RPG weapons, shells, ammunition, and other military equipment in neighborhood 16 of Ombada (Um Bada, Khartoum).
Change to armed group: Around 22 April 2025 (as reported), 7,000 SLM/A-Minnawi with 200 military vehicles defected to RSF (location coded to North Darfur capital, where both troops are largely deployed, El Fasher, Al Fasher). SLM/A-Minnawi denied.
Movement of forces: On 22 April 2025, SAF jet dropped reinforcement supplies for the SAF 22nd Infantry Division in Babanussa (Babanusa, West Kordofan).
Other: On 21 April 2025, SLM/A-Nur declared a humanitarian emergency state in their controlled areas in Jebel Marrah and Tawila (Tawila, North Darfur), following the displacement of more than 3 million IDPs to their controlled area due to clashes between SAF and RSF in Darfur states.
On 21 April 2025, the Sudanese government and RSF agreed with the UN on aid delivery access and on establishing UN logistical supply bases in two locations, Mellit (controlled by RSF) and Tawila (controlled by SLM/A-Nur), in order to facilitate the delivery of the aid to El Fasher. The agreement was signed in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea).
Other: On 21 April 2025, The Humanitarian Aid Commission (government body) suspended the activities of more than 30 NGOs in South Kordofan, in Kadugli (Kadugli, South Kordofan), due to suspicions of intelligence activities.
Change to armed group: On 20 April 2025, RSF established a police force under the name of Federal Police forces in their control areas, with 100 vehicles in Ed Daein (Ad Duayn, East Darfur), in order to combat the insecurity.
Looting: Around 20 April 2025 (as reported), SAF looted civilians' belongings in South the Belt (Janoub Al Hizam) (location coded to Khartoum - Al Azhari, Jebel Awlia, Khartoum - location of latest SAF targeting of civilians in Janoub Al Hizam) and extorted residents arrested on suspicion of collaborating with RSF for money.
Recruitment: On 20 April 2025, RSF mobilized large numbers of recruits to train them in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur), to build a new army to leave the dependency on ethnic mobilization. The recruits were initially mobilized in Um Dafoug, Tulus, Kass, Al Balabl, and Kabra areas in South Darfur.
Displacement: Around 20 April 2025 (from 12 - 24 April), 6,039 households were displaced from multiple villages between 12 - 20 April including Al Hafeer, Al Akdab, Al Shawafa, Al Shatowi, Hillat Sheikh Ahmed, Kadaba, Al Hasseen, Goz Albeida, Sheikh Al Siddiq, Um Arada and Al Alaga (Um Rimta, White Nile) with additional 1,759 households were displaced between 21 - 24 April from Al Eitsam, Eid Um Uosh, Wad Alshegil, Sharafat, Alushara, Wad Hamari, Shekiri, Al Shegeeg, Almarakha, and Wad Al Kamat villages, due to increased insecurity.
Defusal: On 20 April 2025, the Hazardous Materials team of the Civil Defence Service removed 2 shells from the Civil Defence Service HQ building and 11 shells from Al Neelain towers, planted by an unspecified armed group, in Khartoum city (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Change to armed group: On 18 April 2025, Native administration of unspecified ethnic groups (coded as South Kordofan communal militia) defected from SPLM-N-Abdelaziz to SAF in Kabus (Rashad, South Kordofan).
On 17 April 2025, 3 RSF with a vehicle surrendered to SAF in El Obeid (Sheikan, North Kordofan).
Security measures: Around 17 April 2025, Sennar governor issued a directive banning the firing of weapons during celebrations and carrying weapons in public spaces (location coded to state capital Sennar, Sennar, Sennar).
Non-violent activity: On 17 April 2025, RSF closed Gadra market - many events of violence were reported in this market, coded separately- in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur), due to increased insecurity in the market.
Around 17 April 2025 (from 16 - 17 April), SAF Military Intelligence arrested more than 50 civilians in Abu Shouk IDP Camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur), accusing them of collaborating with RSF, and calling civilians to flee El Fasher in response to SFA call for civilians to flee El Fasher and surrounding IDPs camp (coded separately).
Movement of forces: Around 16 April 2025 (as reported), RSF deployed air defense system (FK-1000 or FK-2000) around the airport in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur).
Around 16 April 2025 (as reported), RSF established a base to store weapons and ammunition in Bir Margi (Kernoi, North Darfur).
Non-violent activity: Around 16 April 2025 (as reported), RSF besieged tens of IDPs who fled Zamzam IDP camp during the clashes between 11 - 13 April (coded separately), and prevented them to go back, in Ndjamena (Al Fasher, North Darfur)
Change to armed group: On 16 April 2025, JEM-Mohamed Bushara defected from JEM-Suleiman Sandal, and relieved Suleiman Sandal of his duties as head of the group, and announced their support for SAF in Port Sudan (Port Sudan, Red Sea).
Movement of forces: On 16 April 2025, RSF deployed reinforcement troops in Lafat Tayba (Al Quoz, South Kordofan), in preparation to repel SAF forces.
Looting: On 16 April 2025, unidentified armed individuals suspected to be from the Nuer community from South Sudan's Unity State raided an unspecified number of cattle in Shegeg area (Abyei disputed area).
Security measures: On 15 April 2025, the Governor imposed 7 PM - 5 AM curfew in El Fasher (Al Fasher, North Darfur), after RSF overtook Zamzam IDPs camp (coded separately).
Other: On 15 April 2025, a court in the Northern issued a life sentence against a suspect due to violation of article 51/A of the Sudanese Criminal Law in New Halfa (Halfa Aj Jadeedah, Kassala), after they were accused of being RSF.
Other: On 15 April 2025, the commander of RSF Mohamed Hamdan Daglo announced the formation of Unity and Peace government (parallel government) with allies who signed the Sudan Founding declaration in Nairobi in February (coded separately), (location coded to RSF stronghold Nyala, Nyala Janoub, South Darfur).
Non-violent activity: Around 15 April 2025 (month of), RSF imposed a night curfew and launched a negative phenomenon campaign to combat insecurity in El Geneina (El Geneina, West Darfur). The RSF captured 80 suspects, weapons, and drugs.
Change to armed group: On 14 April 2025, Native administration of unspecified ethnic groups (coded as Darfur communal militia) announced their support for RSF in the war against SAF, and the RSF parallel government in Bulbul (El Salam, South Darfur).
Weapons seizure: Around 14 April 2025 (as reported), Abu Tira seized signal jamming devices and a drone system in an RSF leader's place of residence in western Omdurman (location coded to area with SAF-RSF clashes in the past week, west of Omdurman - Ombada, Um Bada, Khartoum). RSF fled the house after Abu Tira arrived.
Around 13 April 2025 (as reported), RSF backed by SFA overtook a road between Amiet market and Kadugli and Dilling cities (location coded to populated area in the road between these locations, Kharasan, Keilak, West Kordofan). Unclear if after clashes or not.
Movement of forces: Around 12 April 2025 (as reported), RSF mobilized troops in Um Sayalah (Bara, North Kordofan), in preparation to attack SAF in Ad Dwium.
Movement of forces: Around 12 April 2025 (as reported), RSF mobilized troops in Al Hamra (Bara, North Kordofan), in preparation to attack SAF in Ad Dwium.
Displacement: Around 11 April 2025 (from 5 - 11 April), 90-917 households were displaced in Zamzam IDP camp (Al Fasher, North Darfur) and El Fasher. The SFA called civilians on 5 April to evict El Fasher city, Aboja, Abu Shouk, and Zamzam IDP camps to evict the military operations area through safe corridors to be displaced to SFA controlled area in Korma, and SLM/A-Nur in Tawila, and claimed 8,500 households responded to their call between 5-11 April. SLM/A-Nur accused INGOs of collaborating with SFA. The IDPs Coordination rejected the call. SAF claimed the SFA published a video of escorting civilians in the Shagarah area, not in the Zamzam IDP camp.
Movement of forces: Around 10 April 2025 (as reported), RSF in a 'large' number of vehicles left blocks 2, 3 and 4 of Dar Al Salam, neighborhood 37, Al Amiriya, and Gandahar in Ombada (Um Bada, Khartoum) and moved toward North Kordofan (likely due to clashes with SAF in Um Bada - coded separately).
Security measures: On 10 April 2025, the Manaqil locality security committee (likely SAF due to SAF authority over security matters in security committees) issued a directive banning the firing of weapons during celebrations and carrying weapons in public spaces (location coded to locality capital El Managil, Al Manaqil, Al Jazirah) to 'promote security'.
Movement of forces: Around 9 April 2025 (as reported), Darfur Joint Forces/JSAMF mobilized troops in Karnoi (Kernoi, North Darfur), in preparation to defend the area and El Fasher.
Other: On 9 April 2025, unspecified ethnic Native Administrations signed a document and pledged to control all their ethnic group members, prevent illegal gathering, and combat negative phenomena in El Geneina (El Geneina, West Darfur), following increased insecurity.
Weapons seizure: On 8 April 2025, General Intelligence Service seized 6 Goryunov, 2 DShK, and 6 Kalashnikov rifles, in addition to large quantities of ammunition from an unidentified armed group in Shendi (Shendi, River Nile).
On 8 April 2025, Kawahala and Kajaja signed a cessation of hostilities agreement in Al Abbasiya (Abassiya, South Kordofan). No further information about the tensions between the two militias.
Movement of forces: On 7 April 2025, RSF mobilized troops in Mershing (Mershing, South Darfur), in preparation for an offensive in El Fasher.
Non-violent activity: On 7 April 2025, RSF banned Starlink networks in Manawashi (Mershing, South Darfur), in order to prevent information leaks to SAF about RSF military movements.
Other: Around 7 April 2025 (as reported), unspecified authorities (likely SAF due to their on-ground presence in the state) opened all bridges linking Khartoum city with Omdurman and Bahri (location coded to state capital Khartoum, Khartoum, Khartoum) after they regained control of Khartoum city (coded separately).
Mass grave: Around 6 April 2025 (as reported), unspecified individuals discovered an unspecified number of graves of suspected detainees at RSF prison in Soba prison of Khartoum - Soba West (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Change to armed group: On 6 April 2025, 380 GSLF with 32 military vehicles led by Colonel Abdo Babiker Hashim Kweim defected to SAF in North Darfur (location coded to state capital El Fasher, Al Fasher, North Darfur), following the alliance between GSLF and RSF.
Displacement: Around 6 April 2025 (from 1 - 6 April), 530 households were displaced from Abu Hamira (Um Kadadah, North Darfur) and Al Rokab, due to increased insecurity.
Movement of forces: On 5 April 2025, RSF deployed reinforcements in Wad Bandah (Wad Bandah, West Kordofan).
Movement of forces: On 5 April 2025, FACT troops crossed the borders from Chad to Darfur to support RSF in the war against SAF (location coded to the nearest location to the borders, Adre, El Geneina, West Darfur).
Defusal: Around 5 April 2025 (as reported), the National Mine Action Center removed unexploded shells (likely from clashes between SAF and RSF, coded as unidentified armed group) on Nile street in Omdurman city (Omdurman, Khartoum) in preparation for the reopening of the street for the public (the street likely became inaccessible after the break out of clashes on it between SAF and RSF on 15 April 2023 - coded separately).
Weapons seizure: Around 5 April 2025 (as reported), SAF seized an unspecified amount of RSF weapons in Omdurman city (Omdurman, Khartoum).
Non-violent activity: On 5 April 2025, RSF banned its members from wearing a kadmol (turban mask), wearing uniforms, or carrying weapons inside cities in East Darfur (location coded to state capital Ed Daein, Ad Duayn), due to increased insecurity.
Recruitment: Around 4 April 2025 (as reported), RSF mobilized 50,000 fighters in a training camp in Ed Daein (Ad Duayn, East Darfur).
Mass grave: Around 4 April 2025 (as reported), an unspecified group (likely SAF due to its control of the territory since around 26 March - coded separately) discovered tens of graves containing 10-15 bodies each, killed by RSF on unspecified days, in International University of Africa in Khartoum - Al Mujahdeen (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Movement of forces: On 4 April 2025, RSF cargo jet landed 5 times in Nyala (Nyala Janoub, South Darfur), likely bringing reinforcement supplies or transferring soldiers due to previous activities. The cargo jet also landed on 6 April.
On 4 April 2025, RSF overtook Umm Adara (Keilak, West Kordofan). SAF withdrew from the area in October 2024.
Looting: On 4 April 2025, Bani Fadol-Hamar looted a Hamar civilian vehicle in An Nahud (An Nuhud, West Kordofan). The vehicle was later restored.
Security measures: On 3 April 2025, the Governor amended the curfew period within the state from 10 pm until 5 am across the River Nile state (location coded to state capital Ed Damer, Ad Damar, River Nile), due to insecurity in the region.
Security measures: On 3 April 2025, the Governor amended the curfew period within the state from 10 pm until 5 am across Northern state (location coded to state capital Dongola, Dongola, Northern), due to insecurity in the region.
Movement of forces: On 3 April 2025, SAF mobilized 4700 volunteers in El Obeid (Sheikan, North Kordofan).
Change to armed group: On 3 April 2025, Tamazuj announced general mobilization supporting RSF in the war against SAF, in Darfur and Kordofan regions (location coded to West Kordofan capital El Fula, El Salam).
Non-violent activity: On 3 April 2025, RSF set up checkpoint in the water source in Qawz Bishara (Ar Rahad, North Kordofan), and prevented civilians from accessing the water.
Other: On 3 April 2025, the governor of South Kordofan state dismissed many communities and native administration leaders in Ghadeer locality, including mayor of Hawazmah-Dar Ali-Baggara, in Kadugli (Kadugli, South Kordofan), after they were accused of supporting RSF and SPLM-N-Abdelaziz.
Movement of forces: On 2 April 2025, RSF sent troops on 2000 military vehicles to attack SAF in Northern and River Nile state, from unspecified location (location coded to northeast RSF controlled area in Darfur, Rahib, Al Malha, North Darfur).
Recruitment: On 2 April 2025, 20,000 RSF graduated training in Domia (Nyala Shimal, South Darfur).
Displacement: Around 2 April 2025 (as reported), hundreds of civilians fled Omdurman - Al Jumueia (Omdurman, Khartoum) due to RSF attacks in the area (coded separately).
Weapons seizure: Around 1 April 2025 (as reported), police forces seized a large number of RSF artillery and shells in Jebel Awlia locality (location coded to locality capital Jabal Aulia, Jebel Awlia, Khartoum).
Looting: Around 1 April 2025 (as reported), SAF looted civilian houses in Khartoum - Nasir Extension (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Looting: Around 1 April 2025 (as reported), SAF looted civilian houses in Khartoum - Burri (Khartoum, Khartoum).
Looting: Around 1 April 2025 (as reported), RSF looted civilians phones and MTN network devices Ed Al Beada (Kelemando, North Darfur), RSF attempted to forcibly recruit youth in the village.
Looting: On 1 April 2025, individuals suspected to be from the Twic Dinka and Nuer communities of Angeth village raided between 250 and 300 goats in Awal (Abyei disputed area). The stolen animals belonged to the Chief of Awal and 2 other residents (likely members of the Ngok Dinka community, who live in the area). Locals unsuccessfully pursued the raiders.

graphRAG_summary:
### Summary of Key Battles in Sudan, April 2025

**North Darfur:**
- **El Fasher and Surrounding Areas:** Intense clashes between the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), backed by a Darfur Arab militia, and the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF), supported by the Darfur Joint Forces, continued throughout April. Significant battles occurred on April 11, 16, 23, and 24, resulting in high civilian and military casualties. Notable events include:
  - **April 11:** Heavy fighting in El Fasher and Zamzam IDP camp, with significant civilian casualties and destruction of military vehicles (SUD34781, SUD34776, SUD34778).
  - **April 16:** Continued clashes with RSF fighter drones and artillery shelling, resulting in 127 fatalities (SUD34827).
  - **April 23:** Battles in multiple locations around El Fasher, with high civilian and military casualties (SUD34932, SUD34936).
  - **April 24:** Ongoing clashes with artillery shelling and drone strikes, leading to 75 fatalities (SUD34934).

**South Kordofan:**
- **Khor El Daliab:** On April 3, RSF, backed by SPLM-N-Abdelaziz, clashed with SAF, resulting in 70 fatalities and the displacement of 5,000 people (SUD34581).
- **Ambir:** On April 7, RSF and SAF clashed, with RSF overrunning the area and causing civilian casualties (SUD34753).

**White Nile:**
- **Al Hilba:** On April 10, clashes between RSF and SAF resulted in 37 fatalities, including civilians and military personnel (SUD34770).

**West Kordofan:**
- **Umm Adara:** On April 10, clashes between SAF and RSF resulted in 20 fatalities (SUD34775).
- **Multiple Locations:** On April 4, clashes between Bani Fadol-Hamar and an unspecified Hamar clan resulted in 21 fatalities and significant displacement (SUD34718, SUD34720).

**South Darfur:**
- **Nyala:** On April 13, clashes between Rizeigat-RSF and Misseriya-RSF resulted in 11 civilian fatalities (SUD34829).

**Khartoum:**
- **Ombada and Al Safwa Complex:** On April 20, clashes between SAF and RSF resulted in 11 fatalities, including a General Intelligence officer (SUD34916).
- **Multiple Locations:** Ongoing clashes throughout April, with varying levels of casualties and displacement.

**North Kordofan:**
- **El Obeid:** On April 1, clashes between RSF and SAF resulted in unspecified fatalities (SUD34586).
- **Sumayh:** On April 3, clashes between RSF and SAF resulted in 11 fatalities (SUD34587).

**Blue Nile:**
- **Al Slik:** On April 8, clashes between SAF and RSF resulted in 10 fatalities and significant displacement (SUD34743).

**North Darfur (Additional Events):**
- **Umm Keddada:** On April 11, clashes between RSF and Shugara-Berti resulted in 52 civilian fatalities and significant destruction (SUD34778).
- **Various Dates:** Multiple clashes between RSF and SAF, resulting in varying levels of casualties and displacement.

**Other Notable Events:**
- **Abyei:** On April 6, clashes between Titbaai and Nuer members resulted in unknown casualties (SUD34646).
- **Merowe:** On April 5, RSF fighter drones targeted the dam and SAF's 19th Infantry Division, resulting in a power outage (SUD34692).

This summary highlights the key battles and their impacts, providing a concise overview of the conflict in Sudan during April 2025.
simple_summary:
### Summary of Key Battles in Sudan, April 2025

**El Fasher, North Darfur:**
- **Intense Clashes and Civilian Casualties:** El Fasher experienced significant fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), often backed by militias. Key incidents include:
  - **29-30 April:** SAF regained control of Al Khowai after RSF initially overtook the town. (Event IDs: 20250430003, 20250430002)
  - **29 April:** RSF and SAF engaged in heavy artillery shelling, resulting in civilian casualties. (Event IDs: 20250429002, 20250429003)
  - **28 April:** Clashes in Abu Shouk IDP Camp and El Fasher resulted in numerous civilian deaths and injuries. (Event IDs: 20250428003, 20250428004)
  - **27 April:** Continued shelling and drone strikes led to civilian injuries. (Event IDs: 20250427001, 20250427002)
  - **23-24 April:** Heavy fighting with significant civilian casualties, including the burning of parts of Zamzam IDP Camp. (Event IDs: 20250423003, 20250423004, 20250424004)
  - **22 April:** SAF and RSF engaged in fierce battles, with SAF claiming to have killed a large number of RSF soldiers. (Event IDs: 20250422001, 20250422002)
  - **21 April:** RSF artillery shelling resulted in multiple civilian deaths. (Event IDs: 20250421001, 20250421002)
  - **19-20 April:** Continued clashes with significant civilian casualties and displacement. (Event IDs: 20250420001, 20250419001, 20250419002)
  - **16 April:** Heavy fighting with high civilian casualties. (Event IDs: 20250416001, 20250416002)
  - **15 April:** RSF fighter drones targeted SAF, leading to civilian injuries. (Event IDs: 20250415001, 20250415002)
  - **14 April:** RSF artillery shelling resulted in civilian deaths. (Event IDs: 20250414001, 20250414002)
  - **13 April:** RSF overtook Zamzam IDP Camp, resulting in significant civilian casualties and displacement. (Event IDs: 20250413002, 20250413003)

  - **11 April:** RSF and SAF engaged in heavy artillery shelling, resulting in civilian deaths. (Event IDs: 20250411001, 20250411002)

  - **9 April:** Heavy fighting with civilian casualties. (Event IDs: 20250409003, 20250409004)
